PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The Petition of certain citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth:
That all legitimate business expenses incurred in earning or producing assessable income should be allowable deductions.
That the proposed Capital Gains Tax is an unwarranted burden on the rural sector, which will severely affect its long-term viability.
That the delay by the Government in introducing the legislation into Parliament is causing confusion and hindering farmers in the organisation of their affairs.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government introduces the Capital Gains Tax legislation without delay and that the Australian Democrats join with the Opposition to defeat the proposed legislation.

PETITION.TITLE: Pine Gap Defence Space Research Facility
PETITION.PARA: To the Hon. President and members of the Senate in Parliament Assembled:
The petition of the undersigned shows:

(1) The Agreement between the United States of America and Australia concerning the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap may be terminated by either Government on one year's notice from 19 October 1986.
(2) In the event of war between the United States and the Soviet Union, access by the United States to Pine Gap facilities makes it a probable nuclear target.
(3) Access by all nations to Pine Gap's capacity to monitor and verify compliance with existing and future nuclear limitations treaties could contribute to world peace and security.
(4) The people of Australia are entitled to be consulted, through their representatives in Parliament, on any extension or modification of the Agreement affecting their lives, security and welfare.
And your petitioners humbly pray that:
(1) The Agreement between the United States and Australia concerning the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap be terminated one year from October 1986.

(2) Public discussion and inquiry be instituted into the feasibility of negotiating a new agreement with the United Nations during the International Year of Peace offering the verification facilities of the Pine Gap base to all nations.
(3) Any agreement concerning the future use of Pine Gap be referred to Parliament for ratification.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: African National Congress: South West Africa People's Organisation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament Assembled:

The Petitioners of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: that the humble petitioners respectfully believe that the representatives in Australia of the African National Congress and the South West Africa Peoples Organisation should not have to suffer unending financial problems related to the cost of rent, food and clothing, and the maintenance of two small offices run on the most austere basis.
Your petitioners therefore pray and urge the provision of:-
1. Official recognition of A.N.C. and S.W.A.P.O. as the legitimate representatives of the people of South Africa and Namibia.
2. Financial support to the offices and representatives of the African National Congress and the South West Africa Peoples Organisation to promote the anti-Apartheid cause.
3. Additional financial support for the official representatives of the A.N.C. and S.W.A.P.O. to assist the humanitarian needs of Namibian and South African refugees who are victims of Apartheid.
4. Scholarships for South African and Namibian refugees. These to be provided through the A.N.C. and S.W.A.P.O. education departments.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Petrol Retailers
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament House assembled.

We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, humbly pray that the parliament act to outlaw the practice of the large petrol companies also controlling petrol retail outlets in competition with independent petrol distributers and retailers who they supply, thus acting in a position of unfair competition, and leading to the large companies exerting unconscionable pressure on those independent distributers and retailers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian Bill of Rights Bill is a harmful, dangerous and divisive proposal, the provisions of which are authoritarian and anti-democratic.
Your petitioners therefore pray:
That the Senate rejects this Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS ADMINISTRATION (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill returned from the House of Representatives without amendment.
[COGNATE ORDERS:
PRESCRIBED GOODS (GENERAL) ORDERS: 111A]
Motion for Disallowance

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That Orders 100C and 100D of the Prescribed Goods (General) Orders, as contained in Prescribed Goods (General) Orders as amended (Amendment) (being Export Control Orders No. 7 of 1986) and made under the Export Control Act 1982, be disallowed.

As I have indicated in previous debates-I have debated this matter previously with many other honourable senators-this matter has become affectionately known as the Mudginberri debate, and the orders have become known as the Mudginberri regulations. In other words, the Government has brought in regulations to get around the fact that it was sorely bruised in the Mudginberri dispute and that the Federal Court of Australia has since ruled that the Minister for Primary Industry has an obligation, not a discretion, to provide export services where that is necessary for our export products, in this case meat, to be inspected and have a certificate before being exported. The motion that I have moved and the one I am yet to move will disallow Prescribed Goods (General) Orders 100c, 100d and 111a. Order 100c is so-called staff safety provision, 100d is the cooling-off and negotiating period provision, and 111a is an all embracing cop-out for the Minister, a rewrite of the old national interest provision.

When this matter was debated before and the motions for disallowance were moved, I postponed the debate so that negotiations could take place between the industry and the Government. Those negotiations have taken place and the industry is not satisfied with the result. We in the Opposition are but reacting to the industry concerns about the rewriting of these regulations. In other words, the words have been changed but the Minister still has plenty of opportunities to cop out, to use discretionary power, and sees himself under no obligation to provide those very necessary services.

The Order 100C which concerns staff safety, is, I suppose, a real cop-out. In other words, the Government is saying that it has no faith in the rule of law in this country. I understand as well as anybody else, and probably more than a lot of other people, what potential violence can mean in a situation such as the Mudginberri situation. However, having said that, one can understand that if this regulation were allowed to stand there would be greater potential for violence because we would see the heat of an industrial dispute rise astronomically. People should realise that if that happened and the whole situation degenerated into violence, the Minister would have an immediate cop-out. We do not agree with 100C; that is one of the regulations we are moving for disallowance.

As I said, there is all the protection in the world, under civil law, for people in the case of violence in such a situation. The police are available, but I suggest that on occasions such as this the Government seems reluctant to bring in the police. In this particular incident we had picketers breaching all the Government's own regulations and camping in Kakadu National Park. Nobody else would be allowed to do that. No one else would be allowed to camp there, breaking down the flora in the area. Any other person would have been arrested and removed straight away. Yet there was a reluctance right from the start by this Government to use the police to remove the picketers and so allow the meat inspectors to get on with the job.

As I have indicated, 100D is concerned with a cooling off or negotiating period. Honourable senators can imagine that if that regulation were allowed to stand the cooling off could take a considerable time-I suppose any time that the Minister may wish. In the meantime a meat works could be going broke, men could be laid off, and our meat not exported, with the result that other countries would pick up those export markets. Order 111A is a rewrite of the old national interest provision, which really is the ultimate cop-out. Under that order the Minister could use almost any excuse not to provide the very necessary meat inspection services which are essential before our products can be exported and accepted by other countries.

So for that reason, and for all the other reasons I have indicated in past debates, the Opposition is not in agreement with the regulations that have been brought in. We allowed time for consultation. That consultation has taken place and the industry is not happy. The industry has indicated to us and, I believe, to the Australian Democrats that it is not happy with these provisions. The industry believes that there is an obligation-the Federal Court has indicated that there is an obligation-not a discretion to provide these services. I would have thought that in a time of the massive current account deficits that this Government is facing it would be doing everything possible to enable exporters to export, so putting us in a more favourable position. I would have thought that a government so founded on and so governed by the union movement would have embraced an opportunity for management and workers to sit down and talk, as happened in Mudginberri, look at their situation and decide on work conditions. Workers could be paid a good wage based on their productivity and at the same time the owner of the meatworks could make a reasonable profit. Thus both the owner and the workers would enjoy the benefits of such an arrangement. I would have thought that a government with the history of this Government, based as it is on the trade union movement, would have embraced that course without equivocation. Yet, the old diehards in the union movement could see that their power would be broken and more power would go back to the people on the work floor. They could not abide by such an outcome. So the Government has once again bowed to the wishes of the union leadership and has not taken into consideration one little bit the feelings of the people on the work floor. For all those reasons I have moved the first motion standing in my name. The motion will be debated cognately and I will move my second motion at a later time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this motion for disallowance we are really debating the double standards of this Government. Through these regulations the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) is proposing to change his responsibilities for providing meat inspectors to an export meat firm which may be experiencing difficulties because of industrial action. There are two new sets of regulations before the Senate. One makes minor changes to the Export Meat Order No. 448 whereby the application for the services of meat inspectors is no longer made directly to the regional office but now to the Secretary to the Department of Primary Industry. This may seem to be a small change but it is significant in the light of other regulation changes which are more disturbing.

SPEECH.PARA: The other change adds two new orders. Order 100a is entitled `handling of applications'. It is worth noting exactly what it says. The Order reads:

The Secretary may, in determining whether to make the services of an authorized officer available, being services referred to in an application made by the occupier of a registered establishment under orders, have regard to-
(a) the availability of authorized officers for performing services at the place and time described in the application;
(b) such other considerations consistent with good management practices as he thinks fit, including the welfare and safety of authorized officers; and
(c) the general interests of the agricultural and fisheries export industries.

Honourable senators will see that the first change is not insignificant since, under the new arrangements, applications for meat inspectors will not go direct to the regional office but to the Secretary to the Department. Of course, that means centralisation of authority. That centralised authority now has a discretion-an option-whether to provide meat inspectors or other officers as required or not to supply them as the Secretary thinks fit. These powers are wide and vague enough for any excuse to be found for not sending the requested officers.
There is a similar new additional discretion for the Minister for Primary Industry in new Order 111a, entitled `Directions by Minister', which reads:

Notwithstanding anything provided in orders, where the Minister considers that it is desirable, taking into account the national interest, that a decision which may be made by the Secretary under orders is made in a particular manner, so as to achieve a particular result, the Minister may direct the Secretary to make that decision in that manner or in such manner as will achieve that result.

What do these new regulations mean? They mean that the Minister may override courts of law, such as the Federal Court of Australia, by saying that he is not obliged to provide officers when requested because he is `taking into account the national interest'. They provide him with a perfect cop-out to make deals with trade unions and to preserve the disastrous accord.

How did the need for these regulations arise? Of course, we all know of the Mudginberri dispute, a dispute at a small abattoir in the Northern Territory. We know that the workers were very happy about a system of payment based on productivity rather than the antique and costly tally system which is used elsewhere and which has forced many abattoirs to close. We also know that their union, the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union, objected to this satisfactory scheme, expelled the Mudginberri workers from the union and set up a series of pickets which were ruled illegal by the Federal Court but which brought the work of the abattoir to a halt because the meat inspectors refused to cross the picket lines. We know that the Minister for Primary Industry ordered the meat inspectors of his own Department on four occasions to cross the picket line and to carry out meat inspections at Mudginberri. The inspectors refused. There was a simple solution for the Minister under the circumstances to circumvent loss of meat export sales from Mudginberri. A request went to the regional office of meat inspectors. This request was passed on to the Minister to authorise and license Northern Territory meat inspectors to act as inspectors for the Commonwealth. This could have been done immediately to allow for the export of Mudginberri meat. But the Minister refused to license new meat inspectors and the result was a lost contract to export meat to Taiwan at a value of $2.5m and a loss of other contracts as well.

Mudginberri is a relatively small concern, with export contracts valued at $5m a year. But the abattoir has been successful and efficient in bringing down the costs of cattle handling from $140 a head to about $40 a head through its system of productivity payments instead of tally payments. On 19 December, the Federal Court of Australia ruled:
We are of the opinion that there was no discretion, but a duty to provide inspectors, and that the applications for inspectors made on behalf of Mudginberri should have been considered on that basis.

I recommend the reading of the judgment of the Federal Court to all honourable senators. It makes very interesting reading and is available in the Library. We can now see the reasons for these new regulations. The Minister does not want to be in a position where he is obliged to provide meat inspectors on request; he wants to keep in sweet with the unions; he needs discretionary powers so that he can abrogate his responsibilities in the name of the national interest. The trouble with these regulations is that they are likely to have far-reaching and disturbing effects. They create a dangerous precedent. If the Minister can change the regulations so that he no longer has a duty to provide services, why cannot all other Ministers follow suit? When will we see regulations which will allow another Minister a discretion rather than an obligation to send the police across a picket line? Will another Minister have a discretion, not a duty, to send in fire-fighters? It is simply another example of the Government abrogating its responsibilities in order to kowtow to union pressures.

The Mudginberri dispute was a classic example of trade union action against efficiency and cost control. Remember, the cost of cattle handling under this system, which is thoroughly liked by the workers concerned, was cut from $140 per head to $40. This dispute has cost Mudginberri and its workers and has also cost the community in lost sales overseas. If these regulations are passed, they will allow a Minister to sidestep his responsibilities-and this at a time when we have to borrow $1,000m a month in order to support our current standard of living. This is a step away from economic efficiency. If the AMIEU had known that the Minister would honour his responsibilities and was certain to provide meat inspectors, the union would not have bothered to picket Mudginberri in the first place. These new discretionary powers available to the Minister will encourage more and more illegal pickets, with disastrous results to our meat export trade, which for beef and veal is worth at least $1.1 billion a year or 4.5 per cent of our total exports. If we allow these new regulations to go through, the unions will be set on the road to destroying this important export trade. It is urgent that unions be brought back and kept under the rule of law. These regulations, if passed, will enable the Minister to manipulate the law in the name of discretion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition's disallowance motion refers to Prescribed Goods (General) Orders 100C and 100D, and in this cognate debate we are also considering 111A.1 and 111A.2. It is interesting in this debate that two things seem to have been overlooked. The first, is that the export orders we are dealing with cover all inspection processes. They do not look at meat in particular but at meat, grain, eggs, dried fruit and a whole range of matters. The second, is the very easy way in which, in any political debate, ill-will and bad motives can be directed to anybody who happens to hold an opposing view. That is a pity, I think, because what we are attempting to do here is to look at something with regard to the provision of a service to export industries. What we ought to be trying to do is make sure that what is in place in terms of regulations is what we feel is most appropriate for the export orders and for the economy, taking into consideration a number of subsidiary matters with regard to the staff who have to fulfil that particular essential service. I do not think it is all that useful to throw around accusations as Senator Hamer did, as they do not seem to me to go to the matters in hand.

SPEECH.PARA: I look first of all at 111A and 111B. The problem with these orders stems essentially from the notion of the national interest. I must admit that I found it very difficult to conceive of situations where one might, in fact, perceive the national interest to be so involved. I suppose, if one worked hard at it, one could come up with some but we are, after all, talking not in the area of defence or security where one may wish to take actions, but rather in the area of the provision of a technical essential service where in the so-called national interest we are not going to take actions.

I admit that the operation by omission in terms of the national interest must be seen to be a very small area and one, I think, that one would be hard pressed to come up with. The various propositions that one would want to refer to would refer to the possibility of widening industrial disputes and the possibility that the removal of these inspectors may be seen as a method of not provoking further industrial disputes in other parts of Australia which might be more damaging to the economy than the original one. That is probably the area that we are looking at.

If that is the case, I find difficulty with the notion of having this in subordinate legislation. I know that the Government has said in its explanatory statement in regard to these orders that it is not unusual for a Minister to have such power. Indeed, if one looks at that in a broad sense, that may very well be true. In fact, early this morning I found three Acts made by the Fraser Government which have almost identical propositions in them, but those powers are in the Acts themselves. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) might be able to come up with something better than the Department of Primary Industry came up with last time. He will know that none of the items raised in the last debate referred to this particular operation we are talking about here.

I have not been able to find where these types of regulations have been provided for in subordinate legislation. There is an important point in that regard. If there are no new items other than the ones that were rehearsed during the last debate, I do not believe that it is an appropriate course in subordinate legislation to engage in an activity of giving a Minister such wide-ranging discretions as are contained in these particular regulations. I think it is much more an item for substantive legislation than for regulation because the way it is worded, indeed, is quite wide. It is worded such that, where the Minister considers that it is desirable, taking into account the national interest, that a decision which may be made by the Secretary under the orders is made in a particular manner, so as to achieve a particular result, then following consultation, the Minister may direct the Secretary to the Department of Primary Industry to make such a decision. In other words, the hinge point is that the Minister is merely required to consult. That is a relatively simple matter. He does not have to take into account the consultation in any shape or form. Having engaged in that consultation and having taken into account the national interest, which, of course, he is able to discount, essentially the Minister will do something that he considers to be desirable. So this is a very wide-ranging provision. I believe that it ought to be debated as part of substantive legislation and certainly not as part of delegated legislation.

I return to orders 100C and 100D in which we are confronted with two other different propositions. For the sake of completeness, it is important to mention that the Government has divided this division up. Order 100A deals with the availability of staff which is certainly acceptable to everybody. Order 100B deals with occupational health or safety, and that is also acceptable to everybody. Essentially, those two orders overcome the problem that is involved in a very rigorous interpretation of the Federal Court's decision with regard to the requirement to provide inspectors unless it is impossible to do so. Orders 100A and 100B avoid that situation. They also avoid placing a significant impost on the industry. It is probably for that reason, if for no other reason, that the industry is also very happy with 100A and 100B. If the rigorous interpretation of the Federal Court decision with regard to that impossibility ruling were to be carried out, undoubtedly a significantly large number of inspectors would have to be provided to achieve the 50 per cent recovery rate required as a matter of policy and that would add significantly-possibly between $1m and $2m-to the industry's bill.

I return to orders 100C and 100D. Order 100D really gives quite a wide discretion. The comments I made previously on order 111 can be applied in part to 100D. However, I find that 100C is the most difficult order. This relates to the protection of officers from violence. That is a situation that we have to look at seriously. We have to take into account the protection of officers and their families. Undoubtedly, in these types of industrial disputes, tempers would run pretty high and one would find that the notions of physical violence and intimidation, although not necessarily an acceptable part of those industrial disputes, are certainly an understandable part of them. When people's livelihoods are on the line tempers undoubtedly run high. We have to be very careful with regard to the disallowance of 100C.

I have endeavoured to look at 100c from the point of view of how it will be made operational and what other protections are available for officers and their families from any risk of physical violence or of intimidation. I say again that the wording is widely put. For example, the word `intimidation' is one which presumably could have an enormous range. The definition surely must cover psychological intimidation. If it does not there would not be much protection for families from threatening phone calls.

Looking at the question of psychological intimidation, probably the favourite word in any dispute is `scab'. Presumably it is not illegal to call anyone a scab; at least I am not aware that it is illegal. However, it does indicate an attitude on the part of trade unionists to the people that are said to be scabbing. The use of that term indicates subsequent retribution with regard to employment practices and the way that the unionists react to those people on the job. Thus, it could be seen as a fairly tough word and its use might be said to be intimidation. If the word is read in that way and if I have not stretched the point too far, presumably the secretary would know that on any picket line the word `scab' will be used of anyone who is trying to cross that picket line and hence he would be able, because of the risk of that word being used, to withdraw services. In almost any case where there is a picket line, the secretary would be entitled to withdraw those services. It is in that wide reading that we find a great deal of concern in the industry.

Let us look at the legal situation in relation to the first part-the threat or the risk of physical violence. Undoubtedly an officer would not be considered to be acting improperly if he did not attend work in the face of physical violence. I cite the case of a bank clerk who hands over someone else's money when he is confronted by a gun. In those circumstances that bank clerk would not be considered to be thieving and no court would ever convict him. In other words, it is surely not contained within the contract of any inspector that he must submit himself to physical violence. In those circumstances, it does not seem to me that we need anything other than the protection of the common law and the other statutes relating to grievous bodily harm or inflicting bodily harm. There is a panoply of laws already in place for the protection of people.

It is also a requirement of the police force that if a risk of physical violence is there-and I remind honourable senators that with regard to this particular regulation advice must be sought from police officers-it follows that the police have an obligation to protect. Hence if they have an obligation to protect, we do not need the regulation. The police are already under an obligation to carry out that protection. If the police are not present at the site then presumably they do not consider that there is a risk of physical violence. If they thought there would be physical violence, they would be there. In almost every conceivable circumstance of the picket line example, we would be confronted with a situation in which either there were obligations on the police to provide protection or there was no obligation on the part of the inspector to submit himself to physical violence. Hence an inspector would be excused from engaging in that activity.

In support of the contention I put forward, I refer to the Commonwealth's application for leave to appeal in relation to the Federal Court judgment we have already heard about today. In the discussion of that, Chief Justice Gibbs commented about violence. His comments seem to support the type of proposition I have just put. The Commonwealth Government's legal representative put the proposition that would have meant that the Commonwealth Government had a responsibility to provide a service in a situation where violence was threatened. Essentially that is rehearsed in order 100C-that is, the regulation itself. In other words, Chief Justice Gibbs could almost have been commenting on 100C when he said:
The Commonwealth would in such a situation be bound to protect the inspectors in the course of their duties.

In other words, the Commonwealth has an obligation to protect inspectors from risks of violence. He further commented that to do otherwise would be to suggest that the Commonwealth Government should bow to any act of lawlessness that happens to affect it. Those two comments are well taken. Firstly, the Commonwealth already has an obligation and hence does not require 100C. Secondly, to include 100C seems to suggest that the Commonwealth should bow in the face of lawlessness-which I do not believe this Government or any other government would wish to espouse. With regard to that aspect, I merely refer to the Government's very strong and commendable action against the lawlessness exhibited by the Builders Labourers Federation, and the willingness of this Government to adopt unpalatable solutions with regard to that union. This Commonwealth Government already has, within the last couple of weeks, made a very strong stand against lawlessness on the part of unions, and I would have thought, then, that it is in complete agreement with the proposition put by Chief Justice Gibbs in his refusing to allow that appeal to go ahead.

For those reasons, I believe that to disallow 100C is a responsible course to take. The breadth of 100C would go almost to the point of allowing anything to occur and allowing that essential service to be withdrawn under almost any imaginable circumstances that would arise in an industrial dispute. Hence the Australian Democrats, on the basis of those propositions, would accept the Opposition's motion for disallowance of 100C, 100D and 111.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Collard, who moved on behalf of the Opposition the disallowance of two orders before the Senate. At the outset I declare that I have a financial interest in the export of beef, but my interest is minor and insignificant compared to the national interest here. As Senator Hamer said, the meat and veal trade for Australia is worth $1.5 billion a year and provides 4.5 per cent of our exports. At a time when we have a huge balance of payments problem and a huge overseas debt, every cent we can earn from exports is vitally important.

SPEECH.PARA: The ability to earn money from primary products, which make up nearly 40 per cent of our exports, gets less day by day. Part of that is due to the fact that countries that formerly could not produce food from their own resources can now do so, but part of it is due to the negligence and the incompetence of this Government. We can see that very clearly in the meat markets, in the way that we lost the market in Korea and in our diminishing share of the Japan market; and various other export markets which have not been maintained, and certainly not developed by the present Government.

We have to be a reliable supplier to maintain these markets. That turns on the quality of the product we are providing and reliability with respect to time. If we have a contract, we have to meet it. Part of being a reliable supplier also turns on having an inspection service so that we can guarantee the quality of the beef that we are exporting. The inspection services are provided, under a monopoly, by the Commonwealth Government. If we have a monopoly, we have certain obligations and responsibilities-and this Government failed to recognise and honour these at the time of the Mudginberri dispute. We had the Full Federal Court of Australia pulling the Government up and making it recognise that it had a obligation, since it had the monopoly service with respect to meat inspection, as a sequel to Mudginberri. This morning, the Opposition is trying to make the Government face up to those responsibilities and to honour them.

In the light of the Full Court decision the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) brought out some orders which in effect allowed him to decide when those services of meat inspection were provided. They came broadly in two parts. They provided a loophole for the Minister to act and a loophole for the Secretary to the Department to act. Basically, those grounds were that if the unions did not like what was going on, the Minister could withdraw the service. Quite properly, the Senate rejected those orders. The sequel to that has been the provision of a new set of orders. I do not propose to go through them. Previous speakers in the debate have done so. Essentially we are back to the position we were in before. We have a Minister who defines the national interest and makes a great spiel about it. But basically when the Minister talks of the national interest he is talking about the union interest. The union interest simply is not the national interest.

The Minister makes quite a thing about the safety of his officers. That is a very proper concern for a Minister. But the proper approach is to remove the cause, the threat to the safety of the officers. We have long passed the time in our society when people could physically intimidate and use physical violence against other members of the community. After all, the Senate is involved in the longest debate we have had since Federation on human rights. Surely, if we have a concern for human rights, it follows that we can settle differences between various sections of the community without resort to physical violence and intimidation. If the Minister is concerned about the safety of his meat inspectors, the correct thing for him to do is to ensure that the police force removes the bully boys of the union movement from the picket line.

Section 45d of the Trade Practices Act prevents secondary boycotts. But if the Minister goes outside into the Australian community he will learn that outside the union movement, the Australian community does not accept the right of unions to impose a primary boycott. Let me put that in simple terms. If the unions want to go on strike, that is fine. No one minds people joining unions. That is one of their basic entitlements in this society. But we have reached a stage in Australia today where, if people do not want to work and others do, there is no longer community support for the right of a primary boycott-the picket line of unionists who stand on the footpath and deny access to other people who wish to go into a place either to take their place in the work force or to deliver goods and services to that industry.

It will take a very long while for a Labor Government to recognise that point but it happens to be a fact in the community in which we live today. The practical application of it is that, if the Minister has a problem of safety with his inspectors, he puts in the police force and gets rid of the troublemakers. The unions do not have the right to live beyond the law. I cannot physically assault Senator Grimes with impunity even though he does not agree with me. Precisely the same argument applies to people in the industrial field. If they do not get on they do not have a right to intimidate or stand over others. We have to grow up and take this point to its practical conclusion. The Opposition is quite opposed to these orders. They reflect a lack of moral integrity on the part of the Minister in that he will not face up to his obligations and see that this essential service for Australia, which must be provided if we are to maintain our meat markets, is maintained for the national interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion of disallowance moved by Senator Collard. By way of background, the Federal Court of Australia held in the Mudginberri dispute that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) did not fulfil his ministerial obligations to provide meat inspectors. By not acting, he was aiding and abetting militant officials of the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union in an effort to destroy the jobs of people who had made a legitimate arrangement with the operator of a particular abattoir. That arrangement guaranteed higher productivity and higher wages to the men employed there. The problem for the AMIEU was that it saw that arrangement as the breakdown of an out of date tally system which, if allowed to occur, would flow on to other abattoirs and affect the latter day Luddite approach of too many radical union officials in this country.
—That should go down in history, that one!

—Unfortunately we are not talking about history; we are talking about the present. Under new order 100c, one of the orders to which we are opposed, the Secretary to the Department of Primary Industry, in determining whether to make an inspection service available, may have regard to the need to protect staff members and their families from violence which may result from being directed to attend a place for inspection duties. As this has already been canvassed by my colleagues, I will not go into it in a lot of detail, except to say that I find it appalling that a person cannot go about his normal duties without the protection of the law which every other person in society expects. As we know, the trade union movement in this country has the attitude that it is above the law, that it does not have to fit within the law, that it can do things others cannot do.

SPEECH.PARA: The other order to which we are opposed, order 100d, entitles the Secretary to make a temporary determination, in effect, without withholding services for a fixed period to facilitate the early resolution of an industrial dispute. This is very blatant. All it means is that the order will enable the forced capitulation of an operator. There is no other reason for the existence of that order. Order 111a empowers the Minister to direct the Secretary to make decisions in what he calls the national interest. Again, there is only one purpose in that; that is, to stop the flow on of productivity improvements to the rest of the industry. As Senator Macklin has outlined, any reason can be given for relying on the national interest to withhold the provision of meat inspectors.

All in all, I have felt that the reintroduction of these orders was not fair dinkum; that if the Minister for Primary Industry was acting in the interests of the industry and looking towards improving our productivity and our balance of payments, he would have directed these orders to one or two areas. One would have been-I can understand this-the inability of the Department to perform because of, say, a frivolous request. For instance, it would be foolish for an operator to ask for 100 meat inspectors and so on. That point could easily have been covered. The other point I think would have been better covered by a type of force majeure provision. For example, if meat inspectors were called to a particular site and were unable to get there because of a flooded creek or other reason, that would be perfectly understandable, but a simple force majeure provision would have covered it entirely.

Finally, it appears that the time has come for meat inspections to be carried out by National Association of Testing Authorities-approved private sector inspection groups, as is the case with other export commodities throughout Australia. These work very well. They are in competition with one another. If a person does not show up or does not perform, the solution is very simple: The other bloke is called in. I therefore support Senator Collard's motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot see any mention of Mudginberri or of any other particular issue in the terms of these orders.
—Well done.
—If Senator Collard can point it out to me there will be a free meal for tonight over the most pleasant bottle of wine. Order 100c states:

SPEECH.PARA: 100c. The Secretary may determine whether to make the services of an authorized officer available, being services referred to in an application made by the occupier of a registered establishment under orders, and may, in making that determination, have regard to the desirability of protecting each authorized officer and members of his or her family from the risk of physical assault.

Those who oppose this order say: `No, we are not going to give that protection to the officer or to the children. We refuse to give that protection under this order'. That will be the effect of disallowing--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not talking to a Richmond jury.

—That is all right. I have given that away. It used to be South Melbourne until it was purloined by Dr Edelsten. Senator Macklin says that the Minister for Primary Industry ought to send the police to the establishment in question. With great respect to Senator Macklin, that is the most unusual proposition I have heard for a long while. It is a unique proposition that a Federal Minister or a Federal secretary can direct State police and it is a unique proposition that a Minister of a State can direct the police. The police force is an independent body paid by the State, by the taxpayers. Some might say that that is an area in which we could make some savings.
—Is that true in New South Wales?
—It is absolutely true. Ministers cannot direct the police as to what to do.
—I did not say they could.

—Senator Macklin has said: `I will deny this protection to these people because the police ought to do something'. Why should the police do something? Senator Macklin says that the police ought to do it because the Minister says so. The fact of the matter is that there is no obligation on the police to go to an establishment where violence is threatened. In fact, there is no obligation on the police to move unless they have knowledge of an offence that has been committed.
—There is an obligation.
—There is no obligation for the police to attend. Senator Macklin is wrong about that, with the greatest respect.
—Don't forget he comes from Queensland.

—I suppose so. I thank Senator Robertson. All I can say is that in regard to any normal State, any other State, Senator Macklin's analysis is absolutely wrong. He is now proposing to deny these people the protection that would otherwise be available to them. Well, that is a decision that Senator Macklin has made. Order 100d.1 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Secretary may make a temporary determination not to make the services of an authorised officer available, being services referred to in an application made by the occupier of a registered establishment under orders, if the Secretary believes that such a course will lead to the early resolution of an industrial dispute . . .

What has now been said here is: `We do not want an end to a dispute, no matter what industry it is in. We do not desire to end the dispute if it means holding off these officers for a period'. Senator Macklin says: `No, let us be gung ho about this. Let us enter the valley of death. Let us charge, come what may'. It is heady stuff, and Rudyard Kipling would no doubt be more than impressed with that approach, but whether it is good for this country to be led down this path is very much another matter. It may or may not be a responsible course when we consider that if a dispute is in the process of being resolved, if it is about to have a proper resolution, that resolution will be destroyed, postponed or otherwise affected because this Senate was unable to create a situation whereby people could be held back while the dispute was being settled.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the inability at Mudginberri?

—That is the trouble. Senator Parer talked about the Luddites of the past. I remind Senator Collard that we cannot live in Mudginberri forever. Here Senator Collard is saying that, where a dispute can be solved and where an element of settlement of that dispute is the withholding for some period of these inspectors, he will nevertheless not let that be an element in the settlement of the dispute. He is denying that as a part of the mechanics upon which that dispute may be settled. Again, that is real Rambo stuff.
—More Crocodile Dundee, I think.
—I will accept that correction; it is Crocodile Dundee stuff.
—I cannot see anything here about Crocodile Dundee.
—No; that will no doubt be moved as an amendment later in the proceedings. Order 111a.1 states:

SPEECH.PARA: Notwithstanding anything provided in orders, where the Minister considers that it is desirable, taking into account the national interest, that a decision which may be made by the Secretary under orders--

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the national interest?
—It continues:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . following consultation with each relevant industry body, whose views the Minister shall take into account, direct the Secretary to make that decision in that manner or in such manner as to achieve that result.

Everybody knows what the national interest is, although it varies in definition from person to person. An honourable senator opposite asked what `the national interest' means. Again, I offer anybody a free meal over a great bottle of wine if at some stage in the very lucid debates in this House that person has not used the term `the national interest'. What it actually means is another matter. If one takes into account the national interest, what has been said by the disallowance of this regulation is that the desire to put people through such a process, to have police lines, to have a very vigorous confrontation, overcomes the desire to take into account the national interest. That is exactly what the regulation means: That those opposite are setting aside considerations of the national interest because they consider, for whatever reason, that it is more appropriate to take the vigorous Rambo style of approach to industrial relations. That is what they are saying. Regulation 111a.2 states:

In this order, `relevant industry body', for the purposes of a proposed direction in relation to a matter, means a body which represents, at a national level, the interests of the occupiers of registered establishments which are likely to be affected by decisions.

Even though that is taken into account, people cannot bring themselves, in the national interest, to take an approach which may resolve disputes. Those opposite would create a very rigid system which people cannot go outside. Such a rigid system would be very bad, particularly in industrial relations. No doubt that will be debated again and again, but if a rigid system were created in which people were forced into certain positions and were constrained by the most draconic of strait-jackets into such positions, there would not be settlement of disputes. All honourable senators know that. That is the great tragedy. Discretion would have been left. An area would have been created in which people could move, first, to look after the meat inspectors, who, after all, are the people who will take the brunt in this matter, not us. Regulations could have been put forward to protect them. Honourable senators opposite are denying regulations put forward in the national interest to help resolve industrial disputes in the only way that is ultimately possible.

The effect of the argument throughout has been that because there was an industrial dispute the resolution of which those opposite believe was achieved in the wrong fashion-rightly or wrongly, but legitimately such points of view can be taken-regulations which have general application throughout the industry are denied. To take that approach simply on the basis of a single incident seems, with great respect, to be fairly short-sighted. It is most unusual, because most honourable senators opposite are very long-sighted and broad in their vision; but this time they have confined themselves too much. That is most regrettable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that Senator Cooney is the third Labor senator to speak in this debate. This is the second time that the matter has been discussed here. Senator Cooney was described here the other day as being an old war-horse that the Australian Labor Party sends in to bat whenever it is on a sticky wicket. He does very well. That last contribution was a most entertaining romp. I can understand how he got involved not only with Rambo but with Crocodile Dundee and the charge of the Light Brigade through the valley of death.

SPEECH.PARA: I happened to be on the bus that was driving through Kakadu National Park with a group of National Party senators. We were inspecting the Ranger uranium mine. By the way, we had a permit to travel. We came across the Mudginberri picket. It was the most pathetic-looking picket that I have ever seen. It was certainly a desecration of the Kakadu National Park. We immediately took action to report the picketers to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis). That was the first time that the whole situation was brought to the knowledge of the Australian public. We were able to warn people of this militant union action that was having such a detrimental effect on their fellow workers, as has happened with so much other union action.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fancy you being interested in the workers. That is a laugh. It would not be Pendarvis you are worried about?
—I am pleased that Senator Robertson is listening.
—But I know something about it; that makes a difference.

—All right, we will talk about what the honourable senator said, because apart from Senator Button, who replied to Senator Collard in the original debate, Senator Robertson was the only Labor senator who spoke. I think he spoke in the end more in exasperation than anything else. He made a few points. He condemned the Pendarvis family and their behaviour.
—I did nothing of the sort. I did not condemn Pendarvis.

—The honourable senator did; he condemned the Northern Territory Government for its actions. He said that most honourable senators had read their speeches and were trotting out old union-bashing speeches that they had kept in their bottom drawers. He also condemned the National Party as not being representative of rural interests.
—That is correct, too. I must have made a good speech.

—I have just had it handed to me. The only substantive point that the honourable senator made was that the regulations had been introduced because of an inadequacy in the legislation found by the court. That is just not so. He said that the Government had taken action. He tried to defend the Government's action in the Mudginberri dispute. He said that four times it had asked its staff to cross the line. It had stopped the pay and allowances of the three officers involved in causing the dispute. Not only that, he defended the union's action very heavily and seemed to blame everyone else and be quite prepared to support the union's disobeying of court orders.
—That is not quite right.
—I will read from the Senate Hansard, 19 March 1986, page 1228:

SPEECH.PARA: The decision not to cross the picket line was made not by the Federal Government but by the union involved, the Meat Inspectors Association. It is perfectly proper for members of a union to take a decision in an industrial situation which they believe they ought to take.

That is in the face of the court decision telling them to get back to work. The honourable senator used the same quotation as did Senator Button. I will read it from Senator Button's speech as he read it a little better than did Senator Robertson. Senator Button said, as reported on page 1217 of the same Hansard:
In making the amendments the Government of course recognises that discretionary powers exist in other Commonwealth legislation where services are provided by government authorities.
I do not quite see the relevance of that. He continued:

The Federal Court said, without expressing a view one way or the other: `. . . that for practical reasons (it may) be desirable that the duty be . . . qualified; if so it would seem to be a . . . matter for the Minister to make an appropriate order'.

So the court has not expressed an opinion and has not ordered the Government to do anything. It just expressed a view. That is all I will say about that. Another point that Senator Robertson made was that the Northern Territory Government had provided $2m to buy the meat from the Pendarvis family and store it in Darwin and some months later-note that, because there would be an enormous cost-supplied it back to Mr Pendarvis for the same money and did not charge him for the cold storage of the meat in Darwin. He seemed to think that that was fair compensation for Mr Pendarvis. He seemed to think also that the Northern Territory Government had operated as a subversive authority in undermining the union's power. After all, in this case the fundamental dispute concerned the undermining of the union's authority to be the sole negotiator for wages. The whole dispute starts from that point. No one could deny that the Pendarvis family lost quite a deal in cash in this dispute, but it has won an enormous victory in other areas.

Curiously, about a month or so ago I was in the little town of Biloela, which has a meatworks that was undergoing a strike similar to the Mudginberri one. Once again there was illegal use of pickets. Not only that but the picket had actually threatened physical damage to the inspectors who tried, during one whole day, to get into the meatworks to inspect the meat because of the likelihood that the meat would go off. The meatworks had only a cool store and was not able to freeze the meat. I drew this matter to the attention of the Government. The Government said: `We are in the middle of changing the regulations to give the Minister the discretion as to whether he supplies meat inspectors'. This was when the Minister, as a result of a decision of the court, was in a position of being obliged to provide meat inspectors. Obviously this was a move by the Minister to absolve himself of that responsibility.

The unions were then on the move to expand this type of illegal use of picketing powers to the Bowen meatworks. It became obvious then that all the small meatworks in Australia would be subjected to this sort of union pressure. In other words, a concerted campaign was about to be launched. It is because of that that the Opposition and, thankfully, the Australian Democrats, who for once are doing the right thing, are determined to oppose the attempt to remove responsibility from the Minister. We want to put the job fairly and squarely back on him so that meat inspection services are one of the obligations that he has to satisfy. Therefore, I support Senator Collard's motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a couple of very quick points. I support Senator Collard in this debate. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) in his speech of 29 April stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the issue is still being clouded by the emotionalism attached to Mudginberri and by political considerations of the organisations concerned.

Also I congratulate Senator Cooney on his attempt to bring emotionalism into the debate and for his attempt to tell us all about the movie he saw last night. Mr Kerin does not want to be in a situation in which he has to provide export inspection services once a picket line has been established. However, I think that as the Minister for Primary Industry he has a duty to the country and to the industry to do so. That situation will apply under our motion. Finally, there are four critical areas at stake. I would like to quote from what another person said earlier in the debate:

The first is the capacity of a government to provide essential services which it must, by law, provide. The second is the capacity of a government to act independently of the commands and power of the ACTU. The third is the freedom of the individual Australian worker to negotiate his own conditions of employment outside the direct involvement of the unions. The fourth is the freedom of Australian industries to conduct their business free of government and trade union domination.
I thank the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) for allowing me to make these few remarks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask Senator Brownhill who made the remarks he quoted.
—Mr Hunt.

—That makes it all different. It is my duty as Manager of Government Business in this place to do the first darg every morning. I therefore end up listening to some interesting debates, and this morning's debate has been one of them.
—You will be able to write a new clinical casebook.

—Yes, I will. This morning I have heard honourable senators talking about old war horses getting caught on sticky wickets. I have heard honourable senators talking about Rambos being involved with Crocodile Dundee. Honourable senators have certainly taken a mixmaster to the metaphors. God knows what else has happened here this morning. We have heard two sorts of debate on the other side of the chamber. My friend Senator Cooney was sorely provoked into joining this debate. He referred to members of the Liberal and National parties as members of the Rambo brigade. Basically they said that they did not like these regulations because the Government was doing what it always does, which is to cave in to the trade unions and do their bidding. At least Senator Macklin on the other side pointed out that if one read the newspapers this week and last week and saw what was going on with the Builders Labourers Federation one would realise that we are being criticised by other people for union bashing. I suppose if the Government is being criticised on both counts, as it is, it cannot be doing so badly.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition's general argument was that the Government was caving in to the trade unions and that the Minister for Primary Industry wanted the right to do the bidding of the trade unions and did not want to be in a position where he had to go counter to the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union. I suppose that is typical of the sort of thing we get from the other side. Of course, we heard some interesting arguments. I remember Senator MacGibbon in particular saying that it was absolutely out- rageous for the Minister to claim that he wanted to take into account the national interest in his application of these regulations. Senator MacGibbon said that it was a cop-out and that the Minister should, under no circumstances, use this cop-out. However, then he said: `I want to declare my self-interest in this dispute because I earn a bit of money from meat exports, but the most important thing is the national interest'. He did what all politicians do in this place. They stand up and wave their arms around-I suppose I am one of them-and say what is important is the national interest. However, when someone else uses that argument we say: `You can't do that; it is a cop-out. You cannot use nasty generalised terms such as that'. They are the sorts of debating points we hear from honourable senators such as Senator MacGibbon.

Senator Macklin supports the disallowance. I can count and therefore will not keep honour- able senators very long. Senator Macklin pointed out that in fact the Government was not just kowtowing to the Australian Council of Trade Unions or any other trade union group. He gave some examples. He gave what I thought were some pretty reasoned points as to why he went along with the disallowance of the orders. We therefore see one group of honourable senators opposite supporting the motion for political reasons and another group at least attempting to give principled reasons for what it is about.

Senator Macklin said that he opposed regulations 111A.1 and 111A.2 because they were wrong in principle. He said that such provisions should have been in principal legislation and not in subordinate legislation. He said that he could understand that people would want to use the reason of national interest but that, in fact, if one wanted to do that one should put it into the principal legislation. I suppose that is a fair enough argument. In fact, it is an argument that has been accepted by the Minister for Primary Industry. Senator Macklin said that if the concern expressed that ministerial direction should be provided in the principal Act rather than in orders and subordinate legislation were the only concern despite the fact that the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances did not have any problem, he would certainly be agreeable to amending the Export Control Act 1982 and repealing the relevant orders at that time. But he pointed out that he was doing what had been done in the past and what other governments had found to be appropriate and, maybe some people would say, expedient. If Senator Macklin holds to that principle strongly I suppose he will vote for the disallowance of these orders and there is nothing I can do about it. However, I think he should have thought about whether it was worth while going to this extreme.

Senator Macklin found order 100d a bit broad. Other honourable senators opposite seem to believe that this is a dreadful example of kowtowing to the trade unions. I think we should remember, as the Minister has pointed out, that most industrial disputes in this country, particularly most industrial disputes involving meat inspection staff, are in fact local disputes of a short duration which are resolved by the conciliation process at the local level. I think it is very unwise to suggest that there should not be a cooling off period, which is what order 100d provides, or that it is not up to the Minister, even after consulting with the industry, to provide for a short cooling off period. Such a suggestion would inevitably lead to our doing what apparently people on the other side are perfectly happy for us to do. The police will come in and the dispute will be inflamed not only at the local level but also at a national level. What is a local dispute will be turned into a national dispute. Inspectors will be forced to work regardless of the circumstances and regardless of the merits of the case and the action that has been taken by the people on strike, the employees who are involved in the industrial dispute. That is the very sort of thing that has caused such a problem in industrial relations in this country. That is in fact a recipe for a disastrous industrial situation.

This sort of approach in fact takes out of the hands of the Minister and out of the hands of the people with whom the Minister may be consulting, including management and owners, any flexibility and in fact leaves all the flexibility and all the power in the hands of the unions. If that is what the Opposition wants to do, go ahead and do it. However, I think it is madness and stupidity. It is the sort of thing that under the Fraser Government led to all of the airlines being out; it is the sort of thing that led to all the air traffic controllers being out; and it is the sort of thing that led to the mad disputes that we had in the late 1970s and early 1980s because of what Senator Cooney has called this Rambo-like attitude in which people bare and beat their hairless chests and turn a local dispute into a national dispute. That is absolutely stupid.

TALK.START.PARA: —But in both Mudginberri and Biloela the courts had told them to go back to work-in both cases.

—The Minister actually did that in the Mudginberri dispute. However, what I am talking about here is a local dispute which involves a bit of strife. It is clearly a local dispute and a local issue. The Minister, in consultation with management, is able to say: `Look, we will have a cooling off period. We will not demand that the meat inspectors cross the picket line and cause all sorts of strife because this is going to be over in a day or two'. The Opposition wants the Minister to say to the meat inspectors and the coppers: `In you go'. In that case a local dispute will be turned into a big brawl which becomes a national dispute. If that is what the Opposition wants to do, okay. But that is stupid; it is stark raving mad.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the same argument applies to order 100c. Again, in a dispute of the Mudginberri type, the Opposition is asking the Minister to say to the meat inspectors: `Go in there, irrespective of whether or not you are going to get a thump under the ear'. The Opposition is asking the Minister to send in the police in what is a highly emotional situation. Again, the whole dispute would be expanded. That is the sort of industrial relations that we have had in the past. That is the sort of industrial relations situation which led to the highest number of disputes and man hours lost in the late 1970s and early 1980s. This is not happening now. In the last three years the number of man hours lost through disputes has been at a record low level because, among other things, we have a sensible approach to industrial relations.

The disallowance motions will obviously go through. I remember being in the French Senate and an old French senator saying to me: `Many times in this place, Monsieur le Senateur, my opinion has been changed by a brilliant case and brilliant debate, but never my vote'. I think it is a pity that that is what is going to happen here. The Minister has tried to take a sensible approach to a difficult situation. He has tried to provide regulations which, of course, he needs to interpret and apply sensibly. No one is arguing about that. Ministers and governments can do stupid things with regulations which are brought down in this place. Of course, these regulations, as with any legislation, require sensible application and interpretation.

I can understand that those who take the view that what this Government is about is just doing the bidding of the unions will make the sorts of speeches they have made today. I believe that that view is demonstrably wrong. I do not believe that most of the people who put that view today believe it. I believe that Senator Macklin's arguments may be arguments of principle. However, they are wrong in principle and involve a wrong application of principle. I think it is a pity that the Opposition has taken such a view of these regulations. The Government and the Minister obviously will have to consider what their approach will be when the orders are disallowed. However, if they are to be disallowed, so be it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I would like to comment briefly in closing the debate. I might take this opportunity to try to win myself a free dinner, although I might have to pay for the bottle of wine. Senator Cooney said that Mudginberri has not been mentioned. I remind Senator Cooney that the orders were brought down in response to a court judgment in regard to a Minister's responsibilities following what had happened in the Mudginberri dispute. The Federal Court of Australia said that the Minister had an obligation and not a discretion. These new regulations were brought in as a result of this judgment to give the Minister, as we have said in this debate and in previous debates, an out.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Grimes said that disputes such as the one at Mudginberri could escalate. He said that there was just a bit of strife at Mudginberri. I might remind honourable senators opposite the workers at the abattoir did not put up the picket line at Mudginberri. They will find that the picket line was certainly put up by people from outside the meatworks and probably by people from outside the Northern Territory itself. A group of meat workers recognised that the meatworks could not continue if it operated in the way it was being run. As a result, they decided to sit down with their employer and work out a suitable set of conditions and salaries whereby they could be pretty well paid and the operation could be viable. That happened. The employees of the meatworks were receiving very good wages and the employer had a chance to make a profit to enable the meatworks to keep going. An outside group of people, albeit members of the employees' union, from outside the meatworks and even from outside the Territory, put up the picket line.

Coincidentally, as I mentioned in a previous debate, the meat inspectors involved in this dispute once lived on the site of the meatworks. However, some months prior to the dispute they were moved from that site, for what I now see as cynical reasons, to the Jabiru township. As a result, it was imperative that they cross the picket line that was put up by people from outside the area in breach of the Kakadu National Park regulations. So let me make the point quite clear that a suitable arrangement had been reached between the workers and the employer. The workers were not on strike and they did not seek the assistance of anybody else in their union or in any other union.

So this situation has arisen. In those circumstances the Federal Court of Australia found that the Minister had an obligation, not a discretion, to provide the necessary inspection services. In the light of that we believe that these orders which have been brought down have provided a cop-out. I understand the feelings of Senator Macklin about 100c, and indeed I share them, but I still believe that under the civil laws of this land anybody whose health or life is under threat does have the protection of the civil authorities. That is how it should be. The example used by Senator Grimes of somebody who is likely to get a thump under the ear if he goes into the meatworks I think is covered under 100B, which we are not seeking to disallow.

Senator Cooney, Senator Grimes, myself and just about every other honourable senator have referred to the national interest. It is as broad as it is long. It probably varies from Minister to Minister. But this situation, as I indicated in my previous remarks, gives the Minister a cop-out. Mention was made of the cooling off period. For how long do we have a cooling off period? I appreciate the necessity for a cooling off period and I appreciate the necessity for discussions and the fact that that can work; but in an incident such as the one that provoked these orders and the original arguments, for how long would we go on? The cooling off period could go on for ages and ultimately a meatworks, an industry, or whatever could be brought down financially so that it would never open again. There has to be some point where a Minister says to his employees: `You have an obligation, otherwise this industry will go to the wall and men will lose their jobs'. It is on that basis that we are opposing these orders through the motion I have moved.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Collard's) be agreed to.

ROW.ENTRY: (Senator Button did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Missen).

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Collard) agreed to:

That Order 111a of the Prescribed Goods (General) Orders, as contained in Prescribed Goods (General) Orders as amended (Amendment) (being Export Control Orders No. 7 of 1986) and made under the Export Control Act 1982, be disallowed.

DEBATE.TITLE: BARLEY RESEARCH LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1986DRIED FRUITS LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1986LIVE-STOCK EXPORT CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1986LIVE-STOCK SLAUGHTER LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1986MEAT CHICKEN LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1986PIG SLAUGHTER LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1986DAIRYING INDUSTRY RESEARCH AND PROMOTION LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 30 April, on motion by Senator Walsh:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the debate on these Bills was adjourned yesterday I was speaking about the fact that the rural sector was suffering crippling problems at the hands of this Government because of the lack of action by the Government to ease the fundamental problem facing the rural sector of this country-namely, a very vicious and ever increasing cost squeeze. The Government's decision to disallow various tax relief measures for farmers and its existing high interest rate policy which has crippled not only the rural sector but also small business in Australia generally, has as I said yesterday prevented many rural producers from reaping the benefits of technological innovation, which to an important degree is what the Barley Research Levy Amendment Bill 1986, the Dried Fruits Levy Amendment Bill 1986, the Live-Stock Export Charge Amendment Bill 1986, the Live-Stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill 1986, the Meat Chicken Levy Amendment Bill 1986, the Pig Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill 1986 and the Dairying Industry Research and Promotion Levy Amendment Bill 1985 are all about.

SPEECH.PARA: I mentioned yesterday a small entrepreneurial engineering firm in the country centre of Swan Hill, in my own State of Victoria, which makes innovative and specialised disc ploughs-a company by the name of Grizzly Engineering Pty Ltd. Because of the policies of this Government in the area of taxation and other areas, that firm has suffered a drop in sales and interest repayment increases that are equivalent to no less than the wages of four employees each week. The impact of these types of policies by the Government has been borne out by figures released recently by the Trade Machinery Association of Australia. Those figures show that tractor sales have dropped by 52 per cent in the first quarter of this year and grain harvester sales are down by 40 per cent. Indeed, in the past year, agricultural machinery manufacturers in Australia have shed staff to the tune of 40 per cent, and total costs of the rural downturn to the agricultural machinery industry, from reduced sales, are around $70m.

It has been widely reported that the purpose of the recent jaunt by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to the United States of America was to promote the interests of Australian agriculture, yet no sooner did he leave the United States than we learnt of the fruits of this exercise-Australian wheat growers have lost a market in North Yemen, worth more than $36m, to their United States counterparts. In the past 15 years Australia has been the total supplier of wheat to North Yemen, a trade averaging some 300,000 tonnes of wheat per annum. The United States now, through its subsidy arrangements under its export enhancement program, has effectively cut off this valuable source of Australian wheat sales. It is no wonder that the rural community in Australia is amazed, concerned and disgusted with the Hawke Government's rhetoric of consensus and fine-tuned diplomacy at the expense of Australia's rural producers.

This episode is characteristic of the failure of the Australian Labor Party and the Hawke Government to recognise that they can no longer deflect the plight of the rural community on to international causes. The plight of the rural community in Australia is due primarily to domestic causes and causes which are directly related to the economic policies of this Government. It is time, obviously, for the Government to put its own house in order. The fact of the matter is that the rural economy is facing a decline in international competitiveness, just as the Australian economy as a whole is facing a decline. It is highlighted though, in particular, by deteriorating balance of payments and balance of trade figures. The current account deficit in our balance of payments has almost doubled, from $7.3 billion in 1983-84 to an annual rate of $14 billion after the first nine months of 1985-86. An historic event is reflected in those figures-the Hawke Government is the first government to oversee a current account deficit greater than $1 billion in a single month. The Government has done that not just in a single month but in six out of the last nine months of this financial year.

A major factor in our deteriorating balance of trade is that our goods for sale on the international market are too expensive. Quite frankly and quite simply, we are no longer competitive. the Hawke Government is primarily responsible for this. First, the wages policy in the name of the accord promises to increase labour costs by a minimum of 13 per cent over the next 12 months. Our annualised inflation rate is now 9.2 per cent and there is every indication that we will be back to double digit inflation during the next 12 months. The latest Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development forecasts are that unit labour costs of our major trading partners will be around 4 per cent and, with inflation, even lower than that. Our inflation rate is now more than twice the OECD average and more than five times that of Japan. Today, at 2.4 times the OECD average, Australia's relative inflation performance is worse than in any 12 month period since 1961. Even in 1961 it was just a temporary blip. If one excluded that blip, our relative inflation performance over the last 12 months has been the worst since comparative figures for Australia, other Western countries and OECD countries were first collected. We have the worst inflation rate on a relative basis that we have ever had in our history.

No wonder our economy is going downhill and no wonder we are becoming increasingly uncompetitive in the world scene. This wider reality is the fundamental cause for the wide range of increasing costs facing Australian farmers and service industries, causing their products, as I say, to be too expensive relative to those of their overseas counterparts. During the lifetime of this Government, major costs for farmers and the industries that serve them have increased dramatically compared with those of our major trading partners. I have already mentioned the differentials in wages and in inflation, but I will mention a few other areas.
