In the area of interest rates it is disappointing and, indeed disastrous for Australian entrepreneurs, such as the small innovative company Grizzly I cited as an example, to learn that their Japanese counterparts are paying 5 per cent interest on their loans while the Grizzlys of this world-the Australian manufacturers-are paying around 20 per cent on their loans from the banks.

The story is the same for farmers. Indeed, over the period 1980 to 1984 interest rates have increased by 45 per cent. Another increase which has been receiving publicity lately, and which leaves everything else in the shade, is the 55.1 per cent increase each year in the coffers of the 20 largest unions in Australia for the past six years-a cumulative increase of something like 500 per cent. When one compares that with the cost pressures and the income receipts or the rural sector and the private sector as a whole in Australia, the comparison becomes even more startling, stark and of concern.

Another area of concern on the cost side is transport costs. They have increased for Australian producers by 52 per cent over the past six years. In Canada, one of our major competitors in the rural sector, transport costs have increased by 37 per cent, compared with our 52 per cent increase. In the United States of America, over the same period, transport costs have actually decreased by 18 per cent. These comparisons reflect the fact that the Australian farmer, small businessman and entrepreneur are being grossly damaged and disadvantaged by the policies of this Government. They reflect the fact that Australians with entrepreneurial spirit are being stifled by a government which either blames the other fellow-the international community-or refuses to recognise the warning signals and acknowledge that unless costs are reduced and incentives restored, Australian living standards will continue to decline.

Australia will not see an expansion in its research and development activities unless a climate that encourages and towards people is established. Given the fact that the Government's policies in that area are working in the opposite direction from what is needed, the important benefits that would emerge from the legislation that we are now debating will be greatly diminished. The Government must get its level of spending down so that the high tax burden can be reduced. The Government must change its high interest rate policy. More flexibility must be introduced so that due consideration is taken of the capacity of producers to absorb increases in wages. We can no longer afford to pay wages that feed inflation, increasing costs and, inter alia, declining competitiveness. Only when a climate of reduced costs and stability has been engineered will we see real inroads in the development of Australia's research and development program.

The Opposition is totally at odds with the Government on the question of introducing changes in the Australian environment that are necessary to draw out and derive the benefits which legislation of the type we are now debating is supposed to provide. As I understand from the Press recently, the Labor Party's slogan for the next election will be `fairness'. The Labor Party should tell that to the Australian farmer and producer. When it comes to the rural sector, the word `fairness' is not in Labor's dictionary.

What we will do when we return to government is produce a more competitive and cost conscious environment which will allow the rural sector to grow and have the opportunity to flourish. That will involve a strategy which is totally alien to that which this present Government pursues. The strategy that we will follow involves a freer labour market sensitive to the ability to pay of individual industries and enterprises. We will introduce a taxation system which, far from clobbering every producer, be he rural or otherwise, who wants to get up and have a go to produce more wealth within the economy-the path that Labor has so relentlessly pursued in the past three years-will reward effort and initiative and will not discriminate against jobs, exports or business in general.

We will tackle the question of the balance of power between unions and employers and other groups in our community in order to restore our position as a reliable supplier. The overwhelming increase in the last three years in the balance of power in favour of the trade union movement and in particular of certain militant trade unions is one of the root causes of the problems we now face. As I have intimated and as the Opposition has many times stated, we will also reduce the costs and restrictions on rural and other producers in this country by removing excessive government control and regulation. These things are absolutely vital if our rural sector is to prosper and if we are to derive the benefits from technology and research and development, without which we will continue to slip further down the scale of international living standards. Economically viable rural industries are vital to the living standards of all Australians, no matter where they live, whether they be rural or metropolitan Australians. This Government has neglected that fundamental point. It is the key point of difference between the Government and the Opposition. It is a point on which the Opposition will be placing primary emphasis when it returns to government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the Senate is considering the Barley Research Levy Amendment Bill 1986 and various allied Bills. Each Bill provides for increases to the maximum rate of levy on produce for research activities, broadly to a level of 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production. In most cases the operative rates of levy are between 0.1 per cent and 0.2 per cent of the gross value of the product. These Bills do not automatically raise the operative rates. They provide for increases in the levy as required by the industry to be set by regulation in consultation with various industries. Levy payments up to the operative rate will be matched by the Commonwealth and the benefits accrued through our export earnings will go to all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: Research is important in all industries, not only in rural industries. No doubt research helps farmers to improve their techniques, but I must say that, by and large, our farmers are amongst the most efficient farmers in the world. They operate at the lowest cost of product at the farm gate. They also operate their farms at one of the lowest cost capital values in the Western world. Yet the farm sector is receiving some of the lowest returns to capital. This is sad because I do not believe that one can overemphasise the importance of primary industries to the Australian economy.

I want to use the debate on these Bills to talk about some of the problems that all rural industries are experiencing. All too often this Government has shown a tendency to highlight the so-called glamour industries such as tourism, mining and high technology. But when all other industries have been fully exploited or have simply expired, we will still need our pastoral and agricultural industries, irrespective of the low image which they have in the eyes of this Government. Compounding the problem is the fact that many people think of agricultural industries as being heavily subsidised, even though the reverse is the truth. Whilst agriculture funds a substantial part of general industry assistance elsewhere in the economy, assistance to the farming sector comprises only a small part of overall government subsidies.

Basically, increases in farm costs are well in excess of upward movements in the consumer price index. They are jeopardising the viability of our agricultural sector. When one considers that 35 per cent of family farms will have a zero or negative income this year and that the average income per family farm will be only about $7,600, one realises that a great number of rural people are living below the poverty line.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would make more out of peanuts, would you not, Senator?

—I say to Senator Elstob that we do not grow peanuts so I do not make anything out of peanuts. It will be very difficult to make money from the soya beans and maize that we planted because we had a very dry season in Queensland and we will be lucky if we meet our expenses. I found a cutting from one newspaper in which Mr Ian McMaster, who is the retiring leader of the South Eastern Queensland Graziers Association, said that rural industry was averaging an income of only $4,270 a year with 35 per cent of farmers facing nil income with no access to meaningful security benefits unless they walked off their properties. That is very sad. He maintained that 12,000 family units were at risk, meaning that the properties would be sold up. Contrary to what the banks were saying, this trend had already started and many more producers were being refused carry-on funds. The family is the basic unit of society and we do not want to see rural families disintegrating because of the tremendous financial problems confronting them. I am sure that Senator Elstob, as Chairman of our Standing Committee on Social Welfare, would be the last person to want to see that happen. Mr McMaster went on to say that the future of world agricultural trade and the political and seasonal outlook for rural Australia were `abysmal'. That makes me feel very sad indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: Primary producers are not helped by the fact that they have to pay income tax from the first dollar earned. That action was taken by this Government and I consider it to be most unfair. Every other section of the community has a tax threshold of about $5,000. To illustrate this I cite the case of two people who live on the land in our area. They have incomes of little more than $3,000 after they have paid all their expenses. Out of that, from the first dollar, they have to pay $1,200 tax, which seems to be so unfair that I can really hardly believe that it is true. There are many factors that have contributed to the problems of rural Australia since this Government came to power in 1983. For example, look at the increase in interest rates. No business or farm can survive with interest rates of 20 per cent or more. Indeed, no family trying to buy its own home can afford the increased payments necessary because of rising interest rates on home loans. Regrettably there is a vast difference between the 20 per cent in Australia and interest rates in the United States, Germany and Japan which range from 5 to 9 per cent. Now, of course, we have inflation riding high in Australia. It is up to 9 per cent, although I heard Senator Short say in his speech that it was 9.2 per cent. In overseas countries which are our competitors on the world market inflation is falling and in some cases it is down as low as 2 per cent.

Rural Australia cannot afford the high fuel taxes imposed by this Government. Farm fuel budgets are 20 per cent higher than they should be. Although there is a full rebate on diesel excise, petrol makes up about 40 per cent of the fuel used on farms. All the rural industries mentioned in these Bills-dried fruits, barley, livestock, chickens, pigs and dairying-all need and use fuel. We all know that when the world price of petrol was rising the Government put up petrol prices; now the world price of fuel has fallen the Government will not pass on the fall to motorists. On 14 April I asked a question in the Senate of the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans), inquiring whether he was aware that since January 1983 excise duty on fuel had increased from 6.155c a litre to more than 15c a litre. I asked him whether he thought that that was as good as income tax at around 30c in the dollar. In his answer-and Senator Evans is pretty good at giving long answers-he finished up by saying:

When one buys a gallon of petrol, one is buying something more than petrol-one always has in this country and one still is. One is buying defence, health, social security, services to the States and all the other things on which the Government spends money.

Obviously this Government uses fuel to help its budgeting along. The Government budgeted for a total of about $9 billion in oil revenue this financial year. Even after the latest oil price fall, it is now looking at a total revenue of $9.4 billion. It is amazing to me that in America petrol is 23c a litre, whereas in Australia, depending on where one gets one's fuel, it ranges between 40c and 50c a litre, which is twice as much as in America.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the outback it can cost 60c a litre.

—Senator Kilgariff says that in the outback it can cost 60c a litre, so there is certainly a very great difference. America has done the right thing by its fuel consumers. I must point out to the Senate that when one lives in the country one uses more fuel. In the towns and cities one can travel by train or bus but in the country there is not the same opportunity. In fact, the further out one lives, the more fuel one uses at increased prices. All transport costs are higher because of increased fuel prices. This difference is obvious when one goes to the supermarket to do the shopping. One only needs to look at the supermarket advertisements in big city papers. These ads say `Prices slightly higher in country stores' and often it is not just slightly higher either. On our son's property in central Queensland, when the two big tractors and the one medium size one are in use, the cost of fuel is $1,000 a day or $6,000 a week. Farmers working the big wheat and barley properties also have exorbitant fuel bills. I suppose that would also apply to those folk who grow cotton, and I have seen large amounts of cotton being grown on the Darling Downs. One could mention any of the products that are grown-these farmers all have exorbitant fuel bills, although there be a slight improvement with the reduction in the excise on diesel.

SPEECH.PARA: The high cost of fuel in Australia means that our rural producers are unable to compete fairly on world markets. That of course is another problem-the world markets. When I was overseas last year I went to the European Economic Community to discuss the problems of the sugar and other rural producers in Queensland. The EEC and the United States subsidise their rural producers of grain-including barley-sugar and beet, to name a few. What happens here in Australia? Just recently this Government presented to Parliament a farm package which is, I believe, a real disappointment. The total package is valued at $108m or around that amount. I suppose that we should adopt the attitude of being grateful for small mercies. However, when one considers that the Labor Government has ripped off $442m from the rural sector by taking away 40 tax concessions and benefits, one realises that this Government does not really care for rural Australians. In fact, I believe that once again it is illustrating its motto `The greatest good for the greatest number'. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has said that no government can ignore the contribution of the rural sector to our society and the economy. Sad to say, I believe that this Government has done just that.

One tax concession that was removed by this Government was that for water conservation. In a dry country like Australia, a great part of which is suffering from drought, it is imperative that tax concessions be allowed to farmers who wish to conserve water. I believe the same remarks apply also to the Government's cancellation of the bicentenary water resources program. Sometimes when we have plenty of rain and there are floods, we see the water all disappearing out to sea. It is such a shame that we are not able, because we do not have the money, to dam up many of our rivers. Many rural industries affected by these Bills know how important water is.

It would take me too long today to deal with all the tax concessions that have been removed by this Government, thus making life harder for the people of rural Australia. Among those that I would like to mention are the doing away with the tax averaging and the disallowing of tax rebates for clearing and fencing. These are all very necessary improvements to farm properties. I looked hard to see some of the benefits contained in the farm package brought down recently by the Minister. Certainly it is good to know that there is some relief in the change from tariff to bounty assistance for agricultural machinery used for soil preparation and cultivation. There is a minimal change as far as agricultural chemicals are concerned. I understand that the Government has delayed a decision on this matter until it receives the Industries Assistance Commission report. I hope that the report will be favourable to primary producers.

I believe that a package to help primary producers should have contained a statement to the effect that a capital gains tax would not be proceeded with. The Minister for Primary Industry told the Victorian Farmers and Graziers Association meeting at Horsham on 23 October 1984 that he would oppose in the strongest terms any new capital gains taxes and death duties. On 9 April last he said:

My objection to a capital gains tax is the same as probate in that it has the effect of rendering the rural sector in the long term less viable. The family has to sell part of the property to pay probate or capital gains tax.

In the package that was brought down recently, Mr Kerin said that the capital gains tax is in the farmer's long term interest. It seems to me that Mr Kerin has been telling rural Australians, and farmers in particular, complete untruths. I mentioned this the other day by way of a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button). I asked: `Is it the Government's policy to bring in a capital gains tax?' Senator Button did not answer whether it was the Government's policy, he just berated me for saying `nasty things' about Mr Kerin. He said Mr Kerin was the best Minister for Primary Industry Australia had ever had.

I was in Wagga recently speaking to 3,700 people, mainly women, although there were some men there. If Mr Kerin could have heard the very poor reception received by his representative on that day he would not have been very pleased, and I do not think Senator Button would have said that rural Australia would agree that Mr Kerin was the best Minister for Primary Industry Australia has ever had.

TALK.START.PARA: —But that is all Senator Button could say.

—Yes, being a member of that team, I suppose that was the idea. Instead of assistance such as that which overseas producers receive by way of subsidies, all our rural people seem to get is a hit on the head. Our rural producers will find it hard when they feel the effect of the subsidy just given by the United States to its farmers. It has subsidised a 50,000 tonne wheat sale recently to an important traditional Australian market, North Yemen. The United States was able to undercut the Australian tender because of the subsidies provided by that Government. Our Government does not do that for our primary producers.

SPEECH.PARA: The latest information is that rice will be subsidised into Papua New Guinea. Our cotton producers are experiencing crashing world price structures due to subsidised exports from the United States. What about the barley, dried fruits, and meat industries that are the subject of the levy amendment Bills we are considering today? Our rural producers certainly are not being helped by the fact that there is so much subsidisation of farm products by the United States and by the European Economic Community. Only three days after the rural package was announced Mr Kerin claimed publicly that he had only just realised the full threat of the Farm Bill. We need a rural package that is more relevant to the devastating trade threats that farmers are facing.

I do not know how our farmers are expected to compete against the subsidised nations when we find the unions continually wanting more and more wages for their workers. Of course, the Government agrees with the Australian Council of Trade Unions' demands. I have often said that the ACTU is the de facto government of Australia because so many decisions of this present Government have to be referred to it for approval. If the 3 to 4 per cent productivity claim goes through and superannuation becomes compulsory, our efforts to compete on the world markets will be set back even further. The Government needs to take into consideration that agriculture contributes 40 per cent of our export income and employs one million people, yet, the tax package discriminates against investment in this vital industry. The Government must promote investment and productivity, and not discourage it.

I cannot talk about the problems of rural Australia without mentioning the help needed for the sugar producers in Queensland. This Government has offered some price support in its rural package, but with the increased sugar prices in the world markets-I am glad to say this has happened-there will not be the same need over the three-year period for such a large amount of support. It has taken this Government a long time to take this action, while the Queensland Government responded three months ago with help for the sugar industry. Sugar has played a vital part in Australia's export income over many years. The industry deserves better treatment than that accorded to it by this Government.

There is no doubt in my mind that much more real financial help is needed to all rural industries to stop many thousands of primary producers walking off their properties. Some small farmers have debts of $100,000. Some of these farmers will fall into a financial abyss from which they are unlikely to recover. These people have not taken a gamble in the hope of achieving windfall financial gain. They have simply tried to achieve greater economies of scale-I suppose as a result of research-by expanding their enterprises, even though long term returns to farm capital have been less than 2 per cent per annum and I regret to say, this year will average minus 6 per cent. This year, for every net dollar of income earned by farmers, another $14 will be created along the economic chain. It is regrettable that the farmers will receive only this small amount of money.

It makes me wonder what is the point of boosting the research effort when we have a tax package that is aimed at destroying the incentive to produce, when the Government refuses to pass on the full benefits of falling world oil prices, when it has taken $442m directly away from farmers in three years, and when interest rates are being artificially propped up to save the accord mark II of the ACTU, with an inordinate cost being paid by farmers and small business enterprises in particular. Not only should we be debating research Bills of this nature to try to improve productivity, but also the Government should be doing all it can to help our rural industries improve their productivity and become viable on the world markets. I support the remarks of my Leader, Senator Collard, and commend these Bills to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say a few words about the Barley Research Levy Amendment Bill and the associated Bills. The words will be few because the Bills before the Senate obviously have the support of everyone, their details have already been gone into, and everybody has indicated that they will be passed unanimously. Understandably, people have ranged over a wide range of topics covering the rural industries, the rural sector generally, and the Government's economic policies. I do not want to speak on them at length because those sorts of things are only indirectly related to the Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: I will take up some of the points that have been made. Senator Bjelke-Petersen said that the Government's tax package had killed incentive. That proposition has been put, but if one looks at today's Australian Financial Review the evidence in an article on the front page would tend to disprove it. The article states:
Research and development in Australian industry is undergoing a resurgence verging on a boom despite the gloomy picture painted by the Economic Planning Advisory Council.

Far from languishing in an R and D trough, some businesses are as much as doubling research expenditure, according to industry managers and new figures from the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce.

The article then explains why EPAC should have been so gloomy. It turns out that it was so gloomy because the figures it was using were from the 1981-82 era, which was the era before this Government came to power when the Fraser Government was still the Government of this country. Since this Government has come into operation, private research has boomed in contrast to the situation under the previous Government. That would seem to disprove the cries that have been going on throughout this debate about the economic policies of this Government deflating the part that private enterprise plays in the economy. On page 34 of the Australian Financial Review of today is an article headed `$A on brink of US74c hat trick'. It indicates that this criterion of strong economic health--

TALK.START.PARA: —But the United States dollar is not all that strong.

—Let us take it this way. Until recently, speakers in the debate were saying that because the Australian dollar was falling against the American dollar the economy was going badly. One cannot suddenly abandon that argument and say that now that the Australian dollar is rising against the United States dollar, that is no longer a criterion one can look at.
—It is rising against a falling United States dollar; so it is not all that flash.

—It might not be. All I am pointing out is that one can go through all the various criteria of what is economic health and what is not and pick out some to prove one's case. The sorts of criteria that were picked out until recently now indicate a healthy Australian dollar. I turn to the rural package that has been put forward by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin). It is a most innovative and a most `happies' policy. It deals not only with the economic aspects of the rural sector but also with its other aspects. Mention was made previously of Senator Elstob as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare. In this package attention is devoted to the rural sector and to non-metropolitan residents generally insofar as welfare issues are concerned. If one reads through the package, one can see the great initiatives that are about to be taken and the great advances that have already occurred since this Government came into operation. I mention the depreciation of the dollar. In 1982-83 the rate of farm inflation was 11 per cent a year. It was reduced to 8 per cent in 1985-86 and is forecast to be 3 per cent in 1986-87.

SPEECH.PARA: The package talks about wage moderation which has helped to lower prices. When, in trying to help the rural industry, an attack is made on other sections of the economy, those represented by the trade union movement, an unhappy division is likely to arise which would be best not created. It is invidious to suggest that reducing the living standards of one section of the community would help others. There is no evidence that that would be so. There is no evidence that real wage rates are rising, as is alleged. Wage levels have been maintained. The rate of wage increases has fallen dramatically under this Government.

The debate on these Bills has been used as a means of discussing much wider issues. When one considers those wider issues, one finds that this Government already has done much. The rural policy that is now being put forward will do much more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleagues in this debate on the Barley Research Levy Amendment Bill 1986, the Dried Fruits Levy Amendment Bill 1986, the Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill 1986, the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill 1986, the Meat Chicken Levy Amendment Bill 1986, the Pig Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill 1986 and the Dairying Industry Research and Promotion Levy Amendment Bill 1985. My colleagues have taken this opportunity to send a message to the Federal Labor Government that it is not doing enough for the man on the land. This has become much more apparent over the last few months. The Bills which are before us provide for increases in rates of levies required by the industries to be set by regulation and consultation with the various industries. The levies upon the industries concerned are then put back into the industries in the form of research funds.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has no argument with measures which will enhance our rural industries and we do not propose to impede the passage of these Bills. However, we take the opportunity to make the point that the Federal Government is generally falling down on the job where primary industry is concerned, which is unfortunate. Only two weeks ago the Federal Labor Government launched its rural package. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) claimed that the package would help the farmers and pastoralists of Australia get themselves out of the dreadful situation in which many of them find themselves nowadays. Many of them have huge mortgages and pay escalating interest rates and unrealistic wage costs-all in the face of subsidised competition from the European Economic Community and now, it would seem, from the United States.

The farmers have told the Hawke Government what they think of the Kerin package which was going to solve all their problems. They have clearly indicated that it is just not good enough. It does not even begin to address the problems of farmers, who have rejected the package outright. In rejecting the package outright, one sees how desperate farmers are, because these days farmers would seize upon anything that would assist them. Quite obviously, the package will be to their detriment. It does not even begin to address the problems of farmers, who, as I say, have rejected the package outright.

I ask honourable senators to consider what our rural sector is facing. Interest rates are at their highest for 50 years. Many rural people now, for various reasons, are paying interest rates up to 23 per cent, particularly to stock firms. One wonders how on earth any business can remain active when it is paying such huge interest rates. Fuel prices have risen. Although Labor has made some concessions on off-road diesel, the full flow on effect of the drop in world oil prices has not been passed on. Labour costs have diminished the competitiveness of our primary producers.

While all this is happening the Federal Government is looking for new ways to hit the man on the land financially. Rural assistance packages have a very hollow ring when one considers that just around the corner the Federal Government plans to introduce-at least it is talking about it-a capital gains tax. There is much debate now about the fringe benefits tax to be paid by employers. That the Federal Government is even considering the introduction of such taxes is quite unbelievable in the face of reports that 70,000 families face being forced from their land. This figure comes from a report in the Bulletin of 22 April which is headed: `Rural realities spell doom for 70,000 farm families'. The preface to the article states:

Life on the land in future will only be for the shrewd, the adaptable and the business-orientated, experts tell Nigel Austin. And the gloomy prediction for all Australians, reports Andrew Clark, is that they must adjust rapidly to avoid becoming economic `white trash'.

I guess there is not too much the farmer of today can do to become more shrewd. He certainly has had to do so to survive. To become more adaptable is extremely difficult when one considers the problems of overseas markets and the cost of production these days. Being business oriented, I suggest that most farmers and people on the land these days are business oriented. They would have to be to survive. A graph in the Bulletin of the same date indicates the Australian primary industry slice of the economy. The cumulative share of gross domestic product in 1800 was 55 per cent. Over the very many years from 1800 to the 1980s it has fallen to 6.4 per cent-an incredible fall. In the year 2000 it is expected to be 5 per cent. One can see that the future of the farmer and our primary industries is in considerable jeopardy.

All these difficulties faced by rural producers to which I have adverted-taxation, high wages, interest rates and the like-are within the power of the Federal Government to act upon. On top of that, we have the problems of strikes by wharfies tying up port facilities and shipping and other strikes which have an enormous effect on our private industries and products. Many of our biggest international trading partners continue to hedge their bets by placing orders with our competitors overseas. Many are wary of Australia because of these strikes and our inability at times to deliver the goods. To ensure that they are not held to ransom by wharfies, shipping strikes and so on, they buy a lot of products from our international competitors. As a result, we lose the sale of many of our products.

One more matter to which I referred the other day, and which I must raise again because it is having an adverse effect on our primary producers, is the drought which is well and truly entrenched in the Australian scene. Honourable senators may have seen the article in the Australian of 20 March this year which was entitled `Climatic Shift Leaves Sunburnt Country Dying of Thirst'. That is a fairly dramatic title. On reading the article it is clear that we are facing a very dramatic problem. According to the article, a drought review by the Bureau of Meteorology National Climate Centre for the three months to the end of February classified south-western Queensland northern South Australia and bordering areas of the Northern Territory as seriously rain deficient. This classification means that in 90 per cent of past years these areas would have expected more rain than they have received in the comparable period this year.
The rain situation has not improved since February in most of the areas I have mentioned and in other parts of Australia. I will mention that in a little while. The drought is very widespread.

The article describes the meteorological occurrence know as the El Nino phenomenon which reverses the normally cold water currents of the South American coast resulting in warm current anomalies. This leads to the suppression of winter and spring rains in eastern Australia and, for that matter, in inland Australia. The last dramatic El Nino effect was in 1982-83 and corresponded with a severe drought on the Australian continent. We can well remember that time. Bob Hawke claimed that he had saved the day, presumably because he thought that he had broken the drought.

The article goes on to say that climatic conditions over the Pacific basin indicate that Australia might be facing another El Nino phenomenon. As I have mentioned, there are already areas of Australia suffering as a result of serious rain deficiencies. The Northern Territory is one of them. Queensland, New South Wales, South Australia, Western Australia and particularly inland Australia are in dire straits. As at 17 March, 51 properties in the Northern Territory were declared to be drought affected. They are distributed as follows: Two in the Victoria River region, 11 in the Barkly Tablelands and 38 in the Alice Springs area. These are pastoral leases, cattle stations of considerable size, and they make up a vast area of land. Properties are assessed on the adequacy or inadequacy of summer rains and assistance is provided in the form of concessional carry-on loans, destocking freight assistance, feedstuff freight assistance and restocking freight assistance at the end of the drought. This is given in association with the State and Territory governments.

In addition to the 51 properties which have already been declared drought affected, numerous other claims are presently being processed. The situation is also severe, as I have said, in other areas of Australia. I have mentioned South Australia, New South Wales and Queensland. I realise that drought relief schemes operate in those places but, frankly, the schemes are insufficient. It is up to the Federal Government to bring further relief to these people who are in dire straits because of the drought. I wish to raise again a couple of matters which are very pertinent to the issue of assisting farmers, graziers and others on the land. These matters are an income equalisation scheme and the abandonment of proposed additional taxation. To deal with the latter first, I simply say that the proposed capital gains and fringe benefits taxes will discourage farm investment and make the already heavy burden of the man on the land all the more difficult to bear.

As for the income equalisation scheme, I have raised this matter on a number of occasions in the past. Without wishing to labour the point, the scheme should be reintroduced. It should be looked at urgently. The scheme was abolished in 1983 when the present Government came to office. I imagine that the scheme was abolished as a result of the breaking of the drought. But this was no reason to take it away. Now that we are again in the grips of drought the time has come to reintroduce the scheme. It operated to allow pastoralists in years of drought, when forced to destock, to spread the income generated in the destocking year over subsequent less productive years for taxation purposes. It was introduced because farmers forced to destock would generate uncharacteristically high incomes in destocking years and would therefore incur a very high taxation liability. In subsequent years, having sold off the means of income production, pastoralists would have a very low income, if any. The scheme allowed the destocking money to be placed in a fund which could be drawn on over following years and taxation was paid on the money as it was withdrawn and spent.

This scheme had the benefit of enabling farmers to have some funds at the end of the drought with which to restock. It did not enable avoidance of income tax. It merely meant that income could be spread over a number of years to avoid excessive taxation in destocking years which had been brought on by the drought. I urge the Federal Government to reinstate the provisions of this scheme immediately. Destocking is already under way on many properties. It looks set to increase as feed becomes increasingly sparse and the land and stock deteriorate further. One can only have considerable compassion for the people whom we are discussing in the debate on the Bills. Considering the number of people who live on the land and the importance of primary industry to Australia, we need something other than just mere words-and we seem to have plenty on this subject-or if there are to be more words, they should be balanced with action to relieve the people who desperately need our assistance. Of course, that is very obvious when one sees the delegations and so on that come to Canberra to demonstrate before the Federal House.

I do not believe it is characteristic of men on the land to down tools and, at considerable expense to themselves, travel large distances to demonstrate. I do not think it is part of their character. It surely must bring an awareness of the difficulties of the situation when one sees so many thousands of people prepared to do this and come to Canberra to beg for some recognition of the plight they are in. It is really in the hands of the Federal Government to do more. Farmers and other people on the land can do only a certain amount, and I believe they are doing this. I believe that the Federal Government must recognise this even more so than it is doing at present because, quite obviously, the rural package is insufficient. There is need for a further review, a further look at how the people on the land can be saved.

When one looks at the various articles being written on the problems of the industry one sees the beginnings of a move from the land. Surely it is not the wish of anyone to see that happen. We do not wish to see any more people coming to the cities to live on the dole or in an endeavour to eke out a living. Surely their future and the future of their children is on the land. We have the responsibility to see that their children and their children's children are able, through assistance, to remain on the land.
Debate (on motion by Senator Sir John Carrick) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That, unless otherwise ordered, till 2.00 p.m. this day, matters of public interest may be discussed by senators, provided no senator shall speak for more than 15 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to comment on a very important matter, one whose importance the whole Senate will share. I refer to the incident at Chernobyl near Kiev in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics in which a nuclear reactor apparently has melted down. The matter is one not only of concern to the Russian people but also of world concern. It is a major accident in itself. It signals, in my view, some very significant messages not only to the Russians but to all the world's nations and to every individual. Of all things it is a graphic reminder that the release of massive radioactivity into the atmosphere, wherever that release occurs, cannot be localised or contained in any region but will spread across national and international borders and ultimately will move into the cosmic mix. That is the message of Chernobyl. It is the message to which we should direct ourselves.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, we all very greatly regret the deaths and injuries of Russians who were at Chernobyl at the time or, indeed, anywhere associated with either the explosion or the fall-out. We all express our sympathy to the Russian people. Russia has itself asked for and, I think, has received the assistance of Western technology. We would all want to give that. We will all be watching too the monitoring of radioactive fall-out across the European land mass. We all pray that its consequences will be either negative or minimal. This in itself is the very message of Chernobyl.

In a time of very great emotions aroused by such an accident and a time of natural apprehension, we all tend to make quick judgments, and more so when there is difficulty in obtaining real information about what is happening. Therefore we should try to get objective judgment. There are two main questions to be asked: How did this particular disaster happen? How can any future incidents be avoided? These I will address later.

Fundamentally, I think there is an even more global message, and it comes, ironically, in this International Year of Peace. The Chernobyl meltdown, however major in its current perspective, shrinks into relative insignificance when viewed against the explosion anywhere in the world of a single nuclear missile. Let us make the dimensions perfectly clear. We are talking, of course, of any one of the some 50,000 nuclear missiles that are in the stocks of the five nuclear nations of the world. If we are, rightly, so horrified by the lethal effects of a single power-station meltdown, how much more apprehensive should we be about the possibility of even a single military nuclear explosion, used in a war atmosphere, anywhere in the world? I am not speaking just of an intercontinental ballistic missile, but of an explosion of the massiveness of an intermediate weapon or even of what are euphemistically called theatre nuclear weapons, weapons which it has been thought might be used in Europe.

I put to the Senate that Chernobyl is in itself a global message; it is a reminder that there can be no limited or contained nuclear war, that even the smallest of nuclear disasters has international consequences. It is not, therefore, simply an accident in an electricity generating plant-that in itself must, of course, be examined fully and I intend to comment on it-but a reminder to every living person of the terrible dangers of radioactive fall-out. There can only, therefore, be one message: We must work as strongly as we can to outlaw all nuclear weapons-the biggest and the smallest.

We are, we are reminded by Chernobyl, a very frail global village; we are very frail indeed. We are reminded of how frail is our ecology; we are reminded graphically that at this moment in some parts of Europe, I think Poland and elsewhere, the people are being told that they must not drink the water out of the dams, drink the milk from the cows that have grazed on the grass that may be affected by fall-out or eat the vegetables. That in itself is just a mini-glimpse of the reality of nuclear war in itself, whether attempted to be limited or in a wider field.

We are learning a number of quite important messages, but the overriding message is clear: It is vital that the super-powers reach agreement on nuclear arms reduction, with verification and surveillance and with the ultimate goal of absolute abolition of all nuclear weapons. That, if I can use the in phrase, is the megamessage of Chernobyl. It is a message which could very easily be temporarily obscured in concentration on the nature and consequences of a civil accident in itself.

Let me turn to that nature. Inevitably, those who oppose the mining and export of uranium and the development of nuclear power-stations will see Chernobyl as a justification of their arguments. I think they will be proven to be wrong and that their arguments are in fact out of time and impracticable. Others will seek to blame the disaster upon inadequate safety precautions by the Russians. They will point to the good record in the Western world over the last 30 to 40 years of safety in nuclear reactors; they will not dodge Windscale and its accident or Three Mile Island but will point to the containment of those accidents in themselves. That will have some strong support in facts.

But I put it that neither argument is good enough in this situation. Neither case can be allowed to rest there. Nuclear reactors are in this world to stay and to increase in number, although, of course, Chernobyl will set back their development for some time. The International Energy Agency sees no substitute at all for the proliferation of nuclear energy in the next three decades. Oil and coal, however in glut at the moment, are not seen as being substitutes, and we must always remember that the acid rain and the greenhouse effects from oil and coal are themselves ecologically disastrous and must be contained. We must never think that they are not themselves presenting major health hazards to the world.

The fact is that the world's major industrial nations, on both sides of the Iron Curtain, are committed to nuclear power. If we abolished all nuclear power stations, which cannot be done, that would not in any way divert a body of people, if they were so determined, from making a nuclear weapon. They do not need nuclear power stations. It has to be said repeatedly that none of the material from the nuclear power stations is suitable in itself for making weapons. The fact of the matter is that the enrichment level of uranium for a nuclear power station is some 3.7 per cent compared with 90 per cent for a weapons enrichment plant, so do not let us have some idea that if we do not have nuclear power stations we will not have bombs. Do not let us have any argument to the effect that if we do not mine or export uranium that will save people from getting hold of fissile material and making bombs. The fact of the matter is that every country and every ocean in the world has uranium in bountiful supply and anyone with that intention can get the material itself. So there is no solution in that proposition.

What must we learn from Chernobyl? We must all turn our full scientific scrutiny to every nuclear power station that exists in the world and examine it for any possible safety defects. Above all, we must examine it not simply for the defects that may appear to be emerging from Chernobyl. One of the great dangers is that we see an accident and then look for the details of that accident in other matters while, in fact, other defects are emerging. It may well be that the absence of a containment housing in Chernobyl was one of the major reasons for the dispersal of the radioactivity. It may well be that the particular graphite moderator system in Chernobyl was wrong. But we are not looking at that alone; we must look at everything that may be a defect.

We must not simply say: `It has not happened to us so it cannot happen'. I talk of a world scene. In my judgment, there is a need for full and frank scientific discussions on an international level-international conferences and scientific seminars to bring out the details. There is a need to look at the International Atomic Energy Agency and to equip it with the full power not only to do what it now does, to examine whether any reactor is adding to nuclear proliferation of weapons, but also to look at the safety details and to report in a global fashion. No nation can simply say that it now has the total responsibility for its own nuclear station since the cosmic effects have been demonstrated. We have to look at our own role in this area. The Australian Atomic Energy Commission and the various physics departments of universities in Australia have an enormous amount of information and knowledge about this whole subject.

I believe that fundamental to the solution to this problem-I invite the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) to examine this-is the need immediately to set up in Australia an expert task force drawn from the Atomic Energy Commission and from our universities. We should equip that task force with the power and the responsibility to collect all information about what has happened at Chernobyl, about the fall-out of radioactivity over the European land mass and about the various accidents that have happened in reactors around the world. It should have the power to look at the International Atomic Energy Agency to see whether we can give it more power to ensure that safety factors are being observed.

I regard it as absolutely fundamental that we in Australia should not just sit here getting caught up in what will be the ugliest nonsense-all sorts of pro-nuclear and anti-nuclear arguments-when the real situation is that Chernobyl has sent us a message about the universality of radioactivity and the need for us all to act quickly. I invite the Australian Government to set up an expert task force to be given full powers to make a detailed report which ultimately comes into the Parliament so that this Parliament and the people of Australia can have an intelligent and informed debate on what is now the subject of a debate of natural melodrama and great inaccuracies. I invite the Government to look to that purpose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have enjoyed listening to Senator Sir John Carrick, who preceded me. I wish to raise one particular point with respect to the accident that has happened in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. I ask: Where are all the greenies? Why are they not outside the Russian Embassy as they would be if this accident had happened in the United States of America? We can turn our minds back to the Three Mile Island accident and the public commentators and lobbyists who made much of the United States' incapacity to keep its nuclear business under control. We do not see the same complaints with respect to the USSR.

SPEECH.PARA: The topic that I wish particularly to address today is the public image of Parliament and, in particular, the Senate. The public image of Parliament is not good. One does not have to be bright to express that view. My concern is not so much with the public image of Parliament but particularly with the public image of the Senate. I have for some time expressed the view that the House of Representatives is not called the lower House without good reason. Therefore, I am particularly concerned to see that the public image of this chamber of Parliament is raised. I believe that we should all be turning our minds to ways of improving the image of the Senate, not only with young people, the electors of tomorrow, but also with the people who are voting today.

I accept that our life-line to the electorate is the media. We can achieve some level of communication in our electorates without them, but by and large members of the public judge the Government and the work of each House by what they see on television, hear on the radio and read in the newspapers. If we wish to see an improvement in our image, it is my view that we must be prepared to initiate positive steps to encourage a fuller understanding of our work. It seems obvious that we must do this with and through the media. I have used the adjournment debate on more than one occasion to make comments on the role of the media and have on each occasion pointed out that, without prostituting ourselves to the media, we must work with them and they with us.

Accordingly, I have what I believe is a positive suggestion, namely, that the Senate organise an annual prize or award for outstanding reporting of the Senate. Such a prize or award would need to be something that was seen a prestigious acknowledgment of achievement rather than a buy-off. Accordingly, details of any such award would have to be worked out with members of the Press Gallery committee so that in no way were there rules of court, if one can put it that way, and so that any cherished guidelines or ethics of the media would not be interfered with in any way. A number of questions would have to be sorted out. Would such an award, for example, be made only to the printed media, or would the electronic media also be eligible?

The guidelines for selecting the winner of such an award would have to be carefully worked out. Would we be looking, for example, to make that award to the best article that appeared in the previous year, or would we be more inclined to look for a series of articles that reflected more properly the work of the Senate? Would we be looking for articles on the role of the Senate or covering things that happen in the Senate? There are obviously different styles of journalism and these are the things we would need to consider before instituting such an award. Nonetheless, I believe that if we want our image to improve we will have to take some constructive steps towards that.

Some people may say: `If you each lift your own game, naturally the media reporting of the Senate will improve'. I am not at all sure that that is true and I see nothing wrong with offering an incentive to journalists to consider seriously the manner in which they report the work that we do, not only in the chamber but also in committees.

As I am on the topic of the media in general and their reporting, I ask that honourable senators, if they have not already read a particular article, seek it out and read it. I refer to an article in the Age on 7 April 1986 by Michelle Grattan, headed `Are the media being fair to John Howard?' In this article Ms Grattan canvassed a number of points, but the main point she wished to make was that the media should be turning their minds to the question of comparative standards, which should be applied in reporting both sides.

I hope that the comments I wish to make will be received in a bipartisan way, so I will not go on and pick out the pro or negative Howard aspects thereof, but I think the article does raise some serious questions to which we all should turn our minds. One particular aspect is raised. I quote a section of the article:

Once Howard-or any other leader-begins to slide, the media pressures operate to push him down further. Bad publicity generates bad polls which generate bad publicity. There comes the smell of blood. A fashion of `knocking' Howard has developed. Justified criticism gets beaten up. Tactics and appearances come to be seen as more important than what the man is saying, strategy more crucial than substance.

Those comments would apply whether Howard was Leader of the Opposition, whether the Opposition had a different leader, or whether the Liberal and National parties were in government and we were talking about a Labor Opposition Leader. This article does not tell us anything new, but it does invite us to reconsider our attitude and the media's attitude to the way in which the media can influence the attitudes of the community, not only to leaders but to the role of Parliament in particular.

The problem that I have with the media is the manner in which I believe they comment on both chambers in Parliament. I put it to honourable senators that the media really are a bit like football commentators. They are constantly reporting on tactics, and it is my view that they should give some attention to reporting on substance. I put it to the Senate that, if the Opposition asks a question and the Government successfully avoids answering the substance of that question, the reporting tends to be along the lines that the Opposition has failed to draw the Government on a particular issue, or it may be reported that Government tactics have out-manoeuvred Opposition questions and attacks.

There is a place for this sort of reporting. The capacity to have good tactics in parliament is one that should not be ignored, but I ask: Where is the reporting on the substance-the investigative journalism that in itself questions the Government, rather than giving that role completely to the Opposition? I do not deny that that is a major role of the Opposition, I simply deny that there is no place for the media to take up this task. If the media leaves the questioning of Government all to the Opposition, in my view they are failing in a fundamental role.

I have a number of friends who are journalists, and have had a number of lengthy discussions with one of them over this matter. My friend says that it is not the media's role to be in opposition, but that they should just report on the theatre and the tactics thereof. I could not disagree more. I accept that the media do have a role to report on the tactics, but I express the wish that while the Labor Party is in government, and in future when the coalition is back in government, the media will take up for themselves in a much more substantial way the role of questioning Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take a few minutes of the Senate's time to speak about some serious concerns I have about the Government's stated defence objectives and whether they are being funded in a way that allows the Government to obtain those objectives. I do not wish to debate the matter of whether we are spending enough on defence, whether we are buying enough capability or anything like that. I have always made it very clear in this Senate that I do not believe we do spend enough on it, and I cannot help wondering whether the rapidity of change in our relationships in the region in the last two weeks has not caused all those analysts who live in fantasy land in the Department of Foreign Affairs and the Department of Defence, and who preach the doctrine of no foreseeable threat for the next ten years, to reflect on the fallacies that they have been promoting. But it is not my intention today to talk about that.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to look at the objectives that this Government has set with respect to new defence purchases, because I do not see that it has a hope of attaining those objectives within the budgetary parameters it has defined. I hope it does, but as I see it there are some very real reasons to be concerned that it will not be able to buy the new equipment that it has agreed to.

We constantly have to buy equipment for the defence forces, we are involved in some major programs at present and it is very clear that we will have a whole lot more major purchases in the future. The importance of this analysis of what is going on is that we are nowhere near the end of the road; we are only at the very early part of something that, quite clearly, is going to extend for 20 or 30 years. We are at present operating under a doctrine that we can cut short our operational efficiency in order to put money into new equipment and that at the end of the day we will have an increase in capability. I have no quarrel with that doctrine, but it all turns on the length of time that we give up to our present operational capabilities. If it is for three to five years it is one thing; if it seems that it will run on for 15, 20 or 30 years, as I think it will if we follow this trend, it is another matter altogether.

To put into perspective the scale of expenditure, I point out that the Estimates that appeared before the Senate last year for the August 1985 Budget, for the fiscal year 1985-86, dealt with an expenditure of $6,535m for the Department of Defence. In the Estimates that came through a couple of months ago, anticipated expenditure for the Department was increased to $6,702m.

The Defence vote can be considered in a general sense as going in two directions-first for personnel, and secondly for equipment. Under personnel costs we deal with the pay for servicemen and servicewomen, their training, food, clothing and housing; and the cost of their exercises for operational training-for fuel and ammunition. The other part of the vote-the non-personnel part-goes to buy new equipment, to replace equipment that is worn out or obsolete, and equipment which will give us new capabilities.

For many years now the Defence vote has been organised on a continuous or rolling basis of a five year defence plan. The Department sits down in consultation with the Cabinet or the Executive and the Departments of Treasury and Finance and comes forward with a plan for the next five years as to how the money is to be spent. This is a management system which covers its current costs, meets the new obligations that can be foreseen and tries to avoid unforeseen expenses.

In the final year of the Fraser Government, the five-year defence plan-the 1982-87 one prepared by that Government-provided for an average real rate of growth in defence outlays of 6.3 per cent. When the Hawke Government came into power in 1983 it abandoned the 6.3 per cent figure for the five year defence plan and substituted a 4.5 per cent real growth figure, and in May 1985 the 4.5 per cent was lowered to 3.1 per cent. On page 17 of the Report on the Forward Estimates and Budget Outlays and Staffing 1986-87 and 1987-88, published in November 1985, we find that that figure which was dropped to 3.1 per cent for the five year defence plan in May 1985 has been revised. The report states:
. . . adjustments to reflect the currently approved planning guideline for annual real growth of 3.75 per cent.
This is an increase on the underlying real rate of growth, 3.1 per cent, provided for in the 1985-86 Budget.

Without any fanfare, the Government has lifted its estimate from the 3.1 per cent set in May 1985 to a figure of 3.75 per cent of real growth. We can draw a very clear deduction from that. If the bean counters in the Department of Finance and the Department of Treasury agreed that the 3.1 per cent figure for real growth had to be raised to 3.75 per cent, the Department of Defence had an acute problem with funding the purchases ahead. As everyone in this Senate knows, Treasury and Finance do not give up readily. Let us go back a few years to look at the same document for March 1983. On pages 30 and 31, dealing with the commitment of new funds to the Department of Defence, the Report on the Forward Estimates of Budget Outlays reads:

Precise funding levels are determined annually. Contractual commitments and project commitments (i.e. where a project has commenced and expenditure has taken place, but where contracts for some aspects of the remaining works may not have been finalised) exist in the capital equipment and capital facilities elements of the program to an extent which would mean that a real increase of less than 3 per cent in funding in 1983-84 would lead to some reduction in normal service activity levels.
In other words, the Department was saying that a 3 per cent growth in 1983 was the bare minimum we could accept. The Department has obviously done a lot of work and analysis on this over the years.

The problems that face the Government come from several sources: The effect of inflation and the way inflation has driven the exchange rate down have provided a demand for more funds. The other factor has been the earlier than scheduled delivery of equipment purchased under foreign military sales contracts. This Government has claimed that over its three Defence budgets it has averaged 3.3 per cent in real growth, and it takes great pride in that. But it is very important to point out that that 3.3 per cent increase has really come through the unscheduled forward deliveries of equipment basically bought from America.

In the first Budget the Government has a growth of 5.6 per cent in the Defence vote, but that came about because $80m came through the unscheduled FMS sales. Last year, under the 1984-85 Budget, this Government's second Budget, equipment purchases ran $213.5m over the estimate, yet the total Defence budget overrun was only $205m. So $8.5m was an unscheduled cut out of the personnel sector, insofar as I defined it, of the budget. Of that $213m of the equipment overrun, it was estimated that $160m came from the exchange rate changes and $62m from advanced FMS sales.

Dealing with the provision of capital equipment, of the 1982-83 budget the proportion for new capital equipment was 17.4 per cent. In 1984-85, that 17.4 per cent had risen to 25.9 per cent as a consequence of inflation and devaluation. The basic assumption, as I said, that the Government is operating on is that we can buy new equipment, take a bit of a cut in our current operational capabilities for couple of years and then pick it up later on. That is a valid assumption only if it is for a short and finite period. But I would argue that, clearly, the new equipment costs are going to run for the next 20 years at least. If we are to have a reduced capability for that period, we will end up with very little operational capability in the defence forces. That capability is being cut in a number of ways. We have had a cut in absolute numbers. Last year the Services were reduced by a figure of 1,049; 523 from the Navy; 460 from the Army; and 66 from the Air Force. That was done from a very meagre base of service personnel. Operational training has been restricted, as has expenditure on fuel and ammunition. Expenditure in that area has been cut to a figure that all servicemen agree is at or below what we need to maintain an adequate level.

Let us look at the financial planning in the five-year defence plan. The 1984-89 five-year defence plan, which is a product of this Government, provides for $8 billion for new capital equipment. Sixty per cent of that capital equipment was ordered and in train before the five-year defence plan was written up, which is more or less the normal practice. My source for these figures is a paper entitled `A Look at the Future' by Mr Motem. It originates from a defence information seminar given in Brisbane on 19 October 1984. Of that $8 billion, $3 billion was provided for equipment that was not already in the program, equipment that the Department could see that it needed. That $3 billion was provided on a base of five years, with an expenditure of $58m for 1984-85, $235m for 1985-86, $530m for 1986-87, $940m for 1987-88 and $1,180m for 1988-89.

In a tight budgetary situation it is necessary to maintain a sequence. It is very important that if we agree to a program we spend that money within the prescribed time. If we fall behind for 12 months, two years of three years, we will reach a situation where the expenditure is so enormous that we cannot cope with it. This Government has deferred making purchases that it agreed to make, such as the purchase of helicopters for the FFGs. Those were deferred 12 months and came into a later fiscal year. The Royal Australian Air Force replacement helicopters is another example. They should have been purchased last year. They may be purchased this year, but it may well be that the decision goes past 30 June so that that big expenditure falls back two years.

For 1985-86 the five-year Defence program called for an expenditure of $235m, yet we find on page 83 of the Budget Statements for 1985-86 there is the statement that `an additional $77m is provided for expenditure on new projects to be commenced in 1985-86'. In other words, the Department has called for $235m and is writing only $77m worth of new work. That illustrates my concern, we have an identifiably large number of big ticket items in the year ahead. One is the new destroyer program to replace the six present River class. It would take at least $6 billion to replace our present capability alone. The FYDP program provides for only $200m for fixed-wing aircraft. We recognise that we have to buy airborne early warning aircraft for the Air Force. That figure alone is in excess of $400m, and there is no space for that in the program. We have provision for only $200m for fixed-wing aircraft.

In summary, I do not think there is enough money for the years ahead. We just do not seem to be maintaining the rate of expenditure that the Government set itself for its five-year defence plan. If we do not maintain that rate of expenditure against the time scale the Government set, we will get to a position where we will have such huge expenditures that we simply cannot cope with them. If we cannot cope, we cannot maintain the capability we have.
I have a great concern that is recognised by the Government. It is one of the reasons why it set up the Dibb inquiry. The terms of reference for that inquiry state:
3 (a) to undertake a review of the content, priorities and rationale of defence forward planning in the light of these strategic and financial planning guidance endorsed by the Government;

It is clear from the statements made by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) that the financial guidance amounts to 3 per cent of gross domestic product. On the evidence we have today, 3 per cent of gross domestic product will not maintain in the foreseeable future the capabilities we have today. I think we are moving into a situation where the Government will have to cut capabilities to live within that 3 per cent budget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address some remarks to the current crisis in the area of Chernobyl in the Soviet Union. I think it is indeed deplorable that the Soviet Union did not give its own people, let alone its neighbours, acknowledgment of this accident as soon as it occurred. The secrecy which has surrounded the accident for three days and which continues is deplorable. Although it is doubtful whether a lot of preventive measures could have been taken, part of the whole problem with the nuclear industry is still that it is shrouded in secrecy and the Soviet Union certainly must take a great deal of responsibility in this current crisis for keeping the world and its own people in the dark about what exactly is going on there; what caused the problem; what levels of radiation are emanating from that plant, which is still out of control; what emergency measures might be put in place for the people in the area.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators can imagine what it would be like living in the area around Kiev at the moment. With the winds taking the nuclear cloud around western Europe, many people are indeed in danger of their lives or if there lives are not in danger in the immediate future, in danger of the illnesses which can result from caesium iodine and strontium 90 being in the atmosphere and taken on the winds.

I think that we need to look very carefully at the whole of the nuclear industry. Twenty-six countries have nuclear reactors-there are apparently 374 reactors on line at the moment-and there is therefore an enormous amount of movement of nuclear materials all around the world. There is not adequate control over the movement of such nuclear material, whether it is weapons grade material or the material for so-called peaceful purposes. In fact, a great deal of weapons grade material goes missing as nuclear material is transported from one country to another.

I think that we need to be aware of the fact that there is a very close link between the nuclear power industry and the nuclear weapons industry. If we look at the history of the nuclear power industry, we see that it was promoted from the early 1950s, close on the heels of the Manhattan project, when the proponents of the nuclear weapons industry needed a respectable front for their military activities. They also needed the plutonium, which is a by-product of the nuclear power industry, for use in their nuclear weapons industry.

There was a great deal of subsidy going on on the part of the Government of the United States of America in those early days of the nuclear power industry when it was advertised that nuclear power would be too cheap to meter. That has been proved to be false. It is indeed a very expensive form of energy, apart from being a very dangerous one, but it got its original economic kick-off because it was so highly subsidised by the proponents of the military uses of uranium. That link cannot be denied and it is an area in which I believe the Australian Government is not responsible.

The Government's current reiteration of its commitment to fuelling the nuclear industry in the light of this Chernobyl disaster is morally contemptible, and I would think that surely even the most avid proponents of the nuclear industry will be rethinking their claims of the safety of nuclear power in the light of this recent disaster. Claims about the peaceful uses of Australian uranium are a nonsense. Even if we could prove that the use of Australia's uranium was confined only to the nuclear power industry, that in itself would be bad enough. But, of course, we cannot prove that that is the case. Once Australian uranium enters the nuclear fuel cycle there is no knowing where it ends up. It may end up in terrorist bombs or in the bombs of the superpowers. Even if it is used only in nuclear power generation that, as I said, is too dangerous for us to be involved with.

The nuclear industry is riddled with accidents. Some of the most well known ones, including the accident at Windscale and the Three Mile Island accident, could have resulted in the same accident that has just happened in Chernobyl in the Soviet Union. They were near meltdowns. In the cases of those accidents the experts were befuddled; they did not know what to do. We heard from one of the engineers at the Windscale plant at the time that they sat around and twiddled their thumbs for a couple of hours when it was underway. They really did not know what to do and finally they poured water on the fire, not knowing whether that would actually inflame it further or whether it would have the desired effect of putting it out. When, in fact, after 12 hours it did put out the fire they all breathed a sigh of relief. But it was a huge gamble that they took; they did not know that it would work. It did work in 1957, but those involved were just very lucky that it did. They did not have the technology; they did not know for sure that it would work.

The point that I am trying to make here is that there is not adequate provision for accidents or emergencies of this kind in the nuclear power industry. It has been a matter of luck rather than good management that the plants at Windscale and Three Mile Island did not melt down.

There have been many other examples. There was a severe accident in Kyshtyim in the Urals in 1957 and the area is still highly contaminated. People who drive through that area in the Urals are advised not to stop, not even to wind the windows of their cars down, just to keep going because the area is still so highly contaminated. So when the Soviet Union says that this is the first accident in the nuclear power industry, that is not true. It should come clean and admit that it has had other accidents, including that one in Kyshtyin in 1957. There have been hundreds of accidents related to the nuclear power industry, which have been very carefully listed by Senator Ruth Coleman. We are very grateful to her for that list, which she continues to keep up to date. It is a very valuable document but it is a damnably long list of nuclear accidents.

For Australia to claim that we have a responsibility under the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons to provide uranium I think is missing the whole point about the morality of this debate. Environmentally, nuclear power is unsafe, and it is no longer economically viable. Since the Three Mile Island Accident in 1979 in the United States of America there have been no new orders for nuclear reactors in that country. The economists' predictions that 2,000 nuclear power plants would be operating by the year 2,000 have fallen far short of their targets. They realise that economically the plants are not viable.

For years the anti-nuclear lobby has said that the waste problem is enough reason for the nuclear power industry not to go ahead, because no provision is made for the radioactive left- overs of that industry. Now we can add to that the fact that in the case of any emergency there are no adequate precautions. There are no emergency procedures which can be put in place, which can be guaranteed to contain a nuclear accident of the kind that is operating at the moment in Chernobyl in the Soviet Union.

Some people will argue that it is because the Soviet technology is behind. Some will argue that it is because the particular reactor there did not have a containment dome. Those two things may be true but in the case of a meltdown, containment dome or no containment dome, the bottom falls out of a nuclear reactor and that creates such an enormous amount of energy and such an enormous explosion that the roof lifts off as well. The fact that there is no containment dome there perhaps meant that the radiation emanated from the plant earlier than it would otherwise have done. But if there had been a meltdown at Three Mile Island or at Windscale, exactly the same problems would have emerged.

The containment dome is no provision against a meltdown. It is what people in the anti-nuclear lobby have been saying for years is likely to happen. Now, if it has happened-we are not even sure of the extent of the damage because it is shrouded in such secrecy-it points to the fact that the risks are too great in the nuclear industry. Millions of people live under the cloud of that possible accident happening at any one of the 374 nuclear reactors which are in operation in the world at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Up to that point you would have had our agreement. You lose us there.
