—I think that any one of those reactors has the possibility of a melt-down, because the technology itself gets out of control so easily. There is not adequate provision. Western scientists have been called in to try to help with that problem and they have not managed to solve it yet. As far as I know, the fire still rages and radioactive contamination is still pouring forth from that reactor despite the fact that Western technologists are trying to give some assistance.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that Australia's involvement in uranium mining should stop immediately in light of this accident. I believe that the Labor Government should take note of this accident and rethink its policy. I hope that it will do that at the Australian Labor Party Conference in Hobart in July. Apart from that, we should also consider the existence of Lucas Heights, admittedly a very small research reactor which is encased in a dome. Of course, it is a different type of reactor from the one which is suffering this problem in the Soviet Union at the moment. But the fact remains that there is a possibility of a meltdown at any nuclear reactor anywhere in the world, no matter its size or its type. There is that possibility and, of course, people in the Sutherland Shire who live in the vicinity of the Lucas Heights reactor are very concerned about the leaks which emanate from it periodically. It is not safe as it is operating at the moment, and it should be shut down.

I also want to draw attention to the fact that we invite into our ports nuclear reactors on board submarines and warships of the United States Navy, possibly the United Kingdom Navy and maybe the French Navy. It does not matter whose Navies they come in with, whether they be Soviet, Chinese, French, British or United States; it is the nuclear reactors on board those ships which pose an environmental danger to the people in the ports that they visit.

I am just going to give the Senate a short list of some accidents which have happened with nuclear generators on board ships. The first couple concern Soviet accidents. In September 1981 a nuclear submarine operating in the Baltic had an emergency and was towed to Soviet waters under cover of darkness. Several sailors died from severe nuclear radiation poisoning. There is not a name attached to that submarine accident. This information, by the way, has come from the Central Intelligence Agency. Obviously, because of the secrecy which surrounds all things nuclear, it has not even got the full information. The next accident is better documented. In 1966 a nuclear reactor on board the 17,000-ton icebreaker Lenin suffered a sudden catastrophic accident, a meltdown killing up to 30 people and injuring many more.

The list of accidents on United States submarines, aircraft carriers and other ships which are nuclear-powered is also very long, although not of melt-downs. That has not occurred on United States ships as yet. Again, I think we have been lucky that that has not occurred. That possibility exists anywhere a nuclear power reactor is in operation. In 1980 150 gallons of radioactive coolant was released on board the ship USS Hawkbill contaminating five workers, two internally. In 1982 there was a spill of 50 gallons of low-level radioactive water during maintenance of the USS Sam Houston resulting in the contamination of one individual. In Brisbane in July 1983 an American nuclear warship, the USS Texas, limped out of Brisbane with a gaping hole in its stern after backing into a wharf while trying to turn around in the Brisbane River without the help of tugboats. There was no release of radioactive contamination in that case, but it shows that accidents can happen with these ships and that, because there are nuclear reactors on board, it is very dangerous to allow them into our ports.

In 1963, USS Thresher, a nuclear-powered submarine, experienced reactor problems and sank off the coast of New England with 129 men on board. In 1959 a sodium-cooled reactor on board USS Sea Wolf was replaced and dumped in the Atlantic Ocean releasing 33,000 curies of radioactivity. In 1959 there was an explosion and fire in the reactor on the submarine in which one man was killed and three men were seriously injured. In 1975, the sub-tender USS Proteus dumped reactor coolant into Harbour at Guam. Radiation levels 50 times the federal limits were recorded in the area. These are the kinds of ships which come into Australian ports frequently and into Western Australian ports very frequently, and far too often. In fact, they should not be coming in at all bearing either nuclear weapons or nuclear reactors.

Emergency procedures are kept under raps. There is an emergency procedure, I believe, for which the State emergency services is responsible, but it is not public. The people who are involved do not even know what emergency procedures they should be taking. They are not trained in dealing with any emergency which might arise and therefore there would be a case of total panic in a port in which an accident occurred on board a nuclear-powered submarine or ship. People just do not know what the risks are and they do not know what to do in the case of an emergency.

A committee has been set up consisting of representatives from the Western Australian police, the Western Australian Department of Emergency Services, the Western Australian Premier's Department and the Australian Atomic Energy Commission. Its proceedings have been kept secret since it started work on an emergency plan in 1976. I have tried repeatedly to get a copy of this plan. What is the point of having an emergency plan if it is so secret that even the people who are involved do not know how to deal with an emergency which might arise? There would be total chaos and confusion.

A more responsible attitude was taken by the civil defence services in New Zealand. In 1979 they put out a leaflet warning people what to do in the case of an accident when the USS Haddo visited New Zealand. They talked about assembly points and decontamination centres. These are the sorts of things that people in ports visited by warships should know. Of course, they sound extremely scarey, as indeed they are. If people had the information, I believe that they would not be allowing the visits of such dangerous ships into out ports. One particular line in a leaflet put out by the Civil Defence service in Auckland in 1979 was--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —At a time when relationships between Australia and Indonesia are a little strained, when a single event can lead to unfortunate massive overreactions from both sides, I wish to draw to the Senate's attention a flagship of good will in an institution that has undoubtedly drawn the people of both nations closer together. I refer to the Australian Language Centre in Jakarta. The building of bridges and the understanding and learning of the cultural backgrounds that lead to attitudinal positions are essential if we are to come of age in our relationship with our second nearest Asian neighbour.

SPEECH.PARA: This archipelago nation of over 13,000 islands, spreading 5,000 kilometres from east to west, is the fifth most populous nation in the world. It is in both nations' interest to foster relationships, to look towards what has been achieved as far as co-operation is concerned in the past and to build on those positive projects that have taken place rather than placing undue emphasis on the negatives and on confrontationist positions. I think we should acknowledge that Indonesia has enough problems of its own and acknowledge that it has achieved a great deal in the immediate past. Much of what has been achieved has been based on the sound principles of its Pancasila. As an aside, I think we have to be careful that we do not allow segments of the Press to dominate the thrust and directions of our foreign policy.

The Australian Language Centre was officially opened by the Prime Minister in June 1983. It is remarkable that the co-operation of the Indonesian authorities has been excellent and has assisted in making this centre so successful. There have been a variety of statements as to the nature and objectives of this Australian Language Centre. In fact, it has been variously described as an aid project, a training institution and a visible Australian presence, as well as an English language resource centre.

At the moment the Centre, as has been the case since its inception, is funded and administered as an aid project by the Australian Development Assistance Bureau. Essentially, the Centre is a training institution in that the majority of its activities are directed to the teaching of students on courses. It also has a visible role of an Australian presence at the centre of Jakarta. It is currently under the directorship of Miss Rena Kelly, who has had extensive experience as a lecturer in English language teaching.

The Australian Language Centre is a unique venture of ADAB. Despite inception problems it has very quickly achieved a reputation for high quality services in English language training in Indonesia. It is, in effect, an outpost of Australian educational expertise, and the demand for the ALC services has been a useful barometer of the strong interest in Indonesia in gaining access to Australian technical assistance and educational services. As an aid project, I think we all have to acknowledge that this language centre is somewhat of an anomaly in that it is not sited in a host counterpart institution. As a training institution, on the other hand, it represents the best of Australian resources in education and it has a bright future.

I take this opportunity of suggesting that perhaps the time has come to change the heirarchy and the funding from one of an ADAB aid project to one which is administered either through the educational office in Australia or through the Department of Trade. I believe that it has now come of age and it has a valuable role to play. As a flagship, it has been essentially successful in Indonesia. I would like to see similar institutions developed in other countries throughout the whole of South East Asia, because more and more people not only in Australia but also in South East Asia recognise and accept that Australia is part of this region and that the Australian destiny lies with Asia and with the Pacific.
I think we should acknowledge the following words from Mr Lee Kuan Yew, the Prime Minister of Singapore:

If the relationships between the peoples of Asia and of Australia can develop and grow in mutual regard, they would be a most powerful influence in shaping this sense of shared destiny and nudge our peoples towards constructive and co-operative purposes.

I believe that we have to build on what has been developed in this Australian language centre in Jakarta and I ask the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) whether she can give encouragement to developing similar centres in the major countries of the whole of South East Asia, because that is where our destiny lies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am induced to join this debate by the very notable contribution of my colleague Senator Sir John Carrick and by the interesting comments of Senator Vallentine. I have travelled in Europe on a number of occasions and have noted a continuing and distressing change each time I go there. I have noticed increasing levels of pollution in Belgium and Germany. I am advised that the trees across Europe are dying. I am advised that in Scandanavia 2,000 lakes have been destroyed by acid rain. Part of this acid rain is the result of the emissions from coal-fired power stations. I am advised that in Canada 1,000 lakes have been destroyed in terms of the flora and fauna.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that power generation carries with it risks, whatever the source of generation, whether it is coal-fired power stations, oil-fired power stations or nuclear stations, and it is right that we should today be talking about the Chernobyl disaster-its extent, what can be done about it and what we should be doing. Indeed, I have had expressions of concern from within my community. I had a telephone call last night from a retired engineer, a man with whom I play bowls each week. He rang me to ask had we considered the use of the inert gas, argon, because that was a gas which he had used in not dissimilar situations in industry to stop certain fires. People are concerned. If my colleague Neil Falconer would phone me last night from Sydney because of his concern, I imagine many Australians are concerned.

One of the issues for us is to ask: What form of power generation should we be pursuing? What form of power generation is going to be best for us? There is no such thing as safe power generation. Coal-fired power stations carry with them enormous risk. There is a risk in obtaining the coal. There is the loss of life of miners in direct trauma and the very considerable loss of life which I saw from the dust diseases of the lung-emphysema, silicosis and the other pneumoconioses which are part of the life of the miner-and there are the emissions from the power stations which cause not only the effect to the environment, the destruction of the flora and fauna, but also deaths. The American Medical Association has estimated that 50,000 Americans die each year from acid rain or the effects associated with acid rain.

If I go back to Europe this year and travel through the Schwartzwald, I will find a loss of the trees in this great forest, and expressions of great concern. When I was in Germany last year I was struck by the levels of pollution and asked the locals what it was due to. They blamed it partly upon their form of power generation. So it is all a question of relative risk.

It is quite clear that what has happened in this nuclear plant is a disaster by any standards. What we have to ask, in terms of relative risk, is whether that is a cause for re-evaluating nuclear-powered generation as a mode of power generation or re-appraising our approach to it. I am disposed to think that in spite of the disaster at Chernobyl and our distress at the loss of life and our continuing distress at what appears to be an uncontrolled situation, that the generation of power by nuclear means-nuclear power generation-is probably still the safest and best available. I should probably say that it is the least unsafe. It is my view that we have underestimated the costs both to health and to the environment of traditional forms of power generation.

Let me place that against the background of saying that I share the concern expressed by Senator Vallentine. I would not like to see any disaster to our environment or to our people but I do not accept Senator Vallentine's conclusion that because these risks are there we should turn away from nuclear power generation. I believe the alternatives are worse.

I raise one other matter. This concerns a matter relating to the Office of the Aged. I wonder whether the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) will pass this on to Senator Grimes's office, as it is a concern. The Office of the Aged properly and commendably decided to carry out some community consultations in Victoria. On 9 April, over the signature of Marie Faulkner, the Director-it was signed on her behalf-it sent an invitation to various groups to meet for consultations on 22 April. This letter was sent by mail and was received by the peak organisation in Victoria, the Victorian Consultative Council on Rehabilitation, on 15 April. It was received on 15 April; it referred to consultations which were planned for 22 April, and the Victorian Consultative Council on Rehabilitation then had the problem of how to advise all the people who would be interested in the consultations that they were occurring, how to get the invitations to them, how to get the information back to the Office of the Aged and how to try and set people up when it had at the most a week to organise these matters.

This was against the background of the very slow mail deliveries in Victoria. Indeed, it sent some of the material out by mail. We know that one organisation received the material on Monday, 21 April. So we had a commendable initiative being taken within the Department of Community Services, but because the method used was to depend upon the mail, it was like sending the information by runner. By the time the material arrived, there was no time left in Victoria to make adequate arrangements, certainly not in time for the organisations involved to be informed and to get their representatives to the meeting.

I therefore commend to the Office of the Aged either better planning so that the material goes out sooner or, if a decision is taken late and the Office wants the matter carried out within a couple of weeks, some method other than Australia Post, in light of the present state of Australia Post's capacity to function quickly. I suggest, for example, that the office use the modern electric telephone to get in touch with people directly to let them know that it plans these consultations and would like their presence. If it does so, it will avoid much of the stress that has occurred in Victoria, which was made known to me by a consultative body and by people who have been approached. They simply did not have time to avail themselves of this offer from the Department of Community Services. It could be done better and I believe that it should be done better.
Sitting suspended from 1.50 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate who has already given me an answer, yes. I am just checking the question because that answer will actually do for the first part of the question I wanted to ask him. In his absence yesterday, Senator Richardson spoke on his behalf during an urgency debate. The honourable senator specifically said that he was speaking on the Minister's behalf. He told us that Senator Button and the Treasurer would be having further discussions with the vehicle industry on the fringe benefits tax. To quote Senator Richardson: `The door is still open to change'. He also said that Cabinet would have to consider the outcome of those discussions later this week. In the light of the reports in several of today's newspapers, I ask the Minister: `Did Cabinet last night review the fringe benefits tax?' I will give him a chance to correct his answer of yes, which he has already given. If so, did it agree to any change in the tax? Is the door still open to change or has it been slammed shut in advance of tomorrow's talks between the Ministers and the industry?
—Why don't we all get together and roll Treasury?

—And have fun. I am aware that Senator Richardson spoke in the Senate on this matter yesterday. I believe he did it very well. The answer to the first part of Senator Chaney's question is yes. Cabinet considered this matter last night and there will be no change in the proposed fringe benefits tax on motor vehicles.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation aware that recent reductions in the barrel price of oil have brought about a reduction in the price of aviation fuel of approximately 8c per litre or approximately $2,500 per tank of fuel in a normal aircraft? Is the Minister aware that this reduction saves airlines up to $600 on a return trip from Hobart to Melbourne but that no reduction in air fares has occurred? Can the Minister request the Independent Air Fares Committee to review fare schedules in the light of this information?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tate asks a fairly logical question about the effect the reduction in the price of petroleum products should have upon air fares in Australia. There has been a reduction of approximately 8c per litre in the Prices Surveillance Authority's maximum endorsed price for the industry. However, I am advised that the price being paid by individual airlines would depend on the contracts they have negotiated. I gather from the advice that the Minister has given me on this matter that it does not follow necessarily that there will be a reduction in air fares.

ANSWER.PARA: The details of airlines' fuel supply contracts are commercially confidential and guaranteed. The amounts saved per flight and per airline would depend upon the aircraft type being used. Under the provisions of the Independent Air Fares Committee Act 1981, which, incidentally, was introduced by the previous Government, a review of the level of air fares applying at any time can be undertaken only on the receipt of a request from an operator or at the discretion of the Independent Air Fares Committee which would take independent action. There is no provision for the Committee to be otherwise requested to undertake a review of air fares offered by the airlines. Of course, we are confronted with the difficulty that the Government is not able to take any initiative in this matter. However, the Independent Air Fares Committee can take variations in fuel prices into account. I would imagine that if market forces, in which the Opposition has such faith, operate correctly, fuel prices ought to be considered by the Committee in line with its responsibilities to examine from time to time air fares in the Australian aviation industry. Currently, the Government would refer the matter to the Independent Review of Economic Regulation of Domestic Aviation because of the implications which arise out of the decrease in price. The Government would hope that the Independent Air Fares Committee responds to what is happening to the price of petroleum products and take some independent action in this respect.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Walsh both in his capacity as Minister representing the Treasurer and as Minister for Finance. I refer to reports that union funds total $118m and that unions are now able to offer a wide range of benefits to their membership, including denticare, home loans, holiday homes, et cetera. Do these fringe benefits arise out of employment? If so, will they be taxed and who will pay the tax? If not, does the Government realise that this will aid tax avoidance in that it will mean that tax free benefits--
—Oh!

—I am sure that Senator Walsh will understand this even if other honourable senators do not. I remind him that tax free benefits paid through an association, whether incorporated or otherwise, which is allied to the employment would provide a tax loophole through which one could drive a train.

—I did see some reports yesterday along those lines. I really am not able to confirm the veracity of the reports. However, as I understand it-and I will check this with the Treasurer-the employer of people employed by unions will be subject to a fringe benefits tax the same as any other employer. I gather that Senator Lewis is talking about union membership. My understanding is that they would not be subject to any fringe benefit related tax. Nor, I believe, would the members of a co-operative association-which is a reasonable analogy because as members of a co-operative they would receive trade discounts on purchases at a co-operative retail store-be subject to it. I think that is a reasonable analogy. I will check it out with the Treasurer.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I draw the Minister's attention to the decision of the Equal Opportunity Tribunal of New South Wales to penalise an Anglican, Dr Peter Tralaggan, for acting in accordance with his conscience in refusing to let his home unit to an unmarried couple. Is it a fact that as from 1 August 1986 the Commonwealth Sex Discrimination Act will operate in a similar fashion in States, including Tasmania, so as to require a person with a similar widely held conscientious belief to defile his or her conscience in order to observe the law? If so, what does the Government intend to do to overcome that situation which, since its publication, has been widely condemned by people, including Anglican Bishop John Reid in Sydney, Archbishop Dr David Penman of Melbourne and Dean Lance Shilton?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I answered a question earlier this week on the operation of the Sex Discrimination Act as it affected married couples and discrimination on the basis of marital status. I made it clear that the law as it now stands, and will continue to apply in the States and elsewhere, does prohibit advertisements and attempts to confine the letting of accommodation to people of a particular marital status. There are exemptions in respect of people living in close proximity to the person specifying the requirement in question. If it is a domestic relationship, there is no obligation that this particular rule against marital discrimination be observed. But when, as I would assume is the case in this instance, all that is involved is the letting of accommodation, it is the case that the law prohibits discriminating against people on the basis simply of their marital status or lack of it, as the case may be.

ANSWER.PARA: That was a matter that was fully debated in this Parliament and that remains the consideration that will continue to be the law. If one allows people to have conscientious personal beliefs in the way in which they discriminate on the basis of marital status, where does one draw the line in relation to those bigots around the place who would claim conscientious beliefs as inspiring and justifying their discrimination on the ground of race, colour, religious belief or any of the other categories of discrimination that have been regarded by this Parliament on cross-party lines as being unacceptable? It is very difficult indeed to try to incorporate conscientious objections criteria in this particular way.

The final point that does need to be made-perhaps I should have made it earlier in the week in answering this-is that on the basis of information I have seen from the Human Rights Commission it appears that there are very few complaints that are made on this particular ground. But to the extent that complaints are made, I think they have almost invariably to date been able to be resolved by the ordinary conciliation processes under the existing Human Rights Commission Act and would not appear accordingly to be the kind of issue that justifies the drum beating that Senator Harradine is now endeavouring to give it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question: In view of the Minister's answer, does he therefore describe the comments of Archbishop Penman, Bishop Reid and Dean Shilton as being bigoted in this instance? In respect of the debate in the Parliament, were members of the Opposition given a conscience vote on my conscientious belief amendment? If not, why not?
—Order! The honourable senator is raising another question in the second part of his supplementary question. I will allow the first part of the supplementary question.
—I am not suggesting for a moment that Archbishop Penman or anyone else who may have commented on this--
—You referred to bigots.

—The honourable senator was not listening. If he was listening he was cynically manipulating it for sordid schoolboy debating reasons of his own. What I said was that if aid, comfort and nourishment were given to those wishing to claim conscientious objection rights in relation to marital discrimination it would, under those circumstances, be very difficult indeed to deny a similar right to claim conscientious beliefs by certain bigots.
—That is wrong and you know it. Have a look at the transcript.
—The honourable senator should check the transcript of what I have just said. I think he will be obliged to eat his words.
—I ask the first question today concerning the Chernobyl disaster.
—Hero.
—I am sorry to go to trivia from the last ball-tearing question about sex, but if Senator Ryan will forgive me I think this is a shade more important.
—Order! Will the honourable senator ask his question.

—I ask the Minister for Resources and Energy: Firstly, has the Government any updated information on the extent of the damage and loss of life so far and on possible scenarios for the next 48 hours? Secondly, is there any danger of the other two reactors melting down or catching fire? Thirdly, is it possible that a small but very dirty nuclear explosion could occur in this situation? Fourthly, does the Government still believe that nuclear energy is safe and that Australia still has an obligation to foster the use of nuclear energy? Finally, does the Government still believe that Australian uranium is good and somehow separate from nasty, accident-causing uranium, especially given the fact that Australian uranium has gone to Finland and then to Russia for processing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Union of Soviet Socialist Republics officials have regrettably not yet issued any substantial details of the calamitous accident at Chernobyl. There is still considerable confusion over the situation at that site and confirmed details as distinct from widely media reported details of damage and loss of life are simply not available at present, but I will certainly keep the Senate informed as further information does come to hand.
—There is no reliable information.

—Not as to the full extent of the damage and the matters that everybody is most acutely concerned to focus on, which are the extent of the loss of life and the precise nature and extent of the damage which has occurred.

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware of media reports that United States satellite photographs have shown a second reactor at the site as being now on fire. However, the publicly released Landsat photos of the site, which are the only ones we have seen, do not show sufficient details to confirm this. The four reactors at the site are constructed in two pairs. I am advised it would be unlikely for damage to spread from one pair to the other, although it is not inconceivable that within the one pair there could be some overlap and that may be what has happened; we do not yet know.

As to the question of the possibility of a nuclear explosion which Senator Chipp adverts to, I am advised that there is no possibility whatsoever of any nuclear explosion whether big or small, or clean or dirty, resulting from the damage to the reactors at Chernobyl. As to the general question of the safety of nuclear power, as I noted in my response to Senator Sanders's question on Tuesday, the safety record of the nuclear power industry until this accident had been very good, especially in comparison with other forms of electricity generation and other large scale industrial processes. It is too early to tell what the final results of the present accident may be. As to possible implications for nuclear power generally, as I noted yesterday, this type of power reactor is quite unique to the USSR and it is the case that its safety systems would simply not meet Western standards anywhere else in the world.

Clearly there has been inadequate information available to countries affected by this accident, and the Government is considering what steps can be taken internationally to improve emergency reporting arrangements for nuclear accidents.

I might mention in parenthesis in this respect that I did hear what Senator Sir John Carrick had to say on this subject in his contribution to the public interest debate at lunchtime. I will certainly give close consideration to his suggestions in that respect.

The question of international reporting arrangements and international responses to situations of this kind is a question that I raised yesterday with the Japanese Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Kohno, who was in Australia yesterday but who has in fact been recalled to Japan this morning in order to deal with these questions in that country. There is undoubtedly an emerging international sentiment that something better needs to be done to fill the defects in the reporting and response system that have been shown by this accident.

I do not believe this accident has affected Australia's position in relation to uranium mining and export. As I stated on Tuesday, I believe we do have an obligation to supply uranium to those countries dependent on nuclear power for a substantial proportion of their energy needs.

TALK.START.PARA: —A moral obligation?

—A moral obligation, a legal obligation and a treaty obligation. I am sorry if it offends Senator Chipp, but they are the terms I have stated and which I repeat, provided-that is a very important proviso-those countries satisfy the requirements of Australia's nuclear safeguards policy which is among the most rigorous if not the most rigorous in the world.
—Does Russia?

—Let me conclude my answer by coming to the question of Australian uranium possibly ending up in the Soviet Union. Under Australia's nuclear safeguards policy no Australian uranium is supplied to the Soviet Union.
—Direct?

—Directly. Nuclear safeguards are quite distinct in that respect from the issue of nuclear safety. That ought to be understood. It is the case that Australian uranium supplied to Finland is enriched in the USSR on an all-in all-out basis which ensures that all Australian origin nuclear material is returned from the USSR and accounted for by the International Atomic Energy Agency. I might mention in that respect that the USSR has one of the only-there are only four in existence-commercial enrichment sources available in the world. It is on that basis that the Finnish uranium is dealt with. There is nothing more sinister to it than that.

—I ask a supplementary question. In view of the latter part of the Minister's answer, I ask him a very simple question: Can he rule out unequivocally the fact that no Australian uranium was used in this particular plant in which the explosion occurred?

—I repeat that any Australian uranium which may go to the USSR for enrichment-sent there by Finland or, indeed, for that matter, by other Australian uranium customers-does go into the USSR on an all-in all-out basis. Against that background, on the basis of that explanation, the answer is essentially, yes, I can guarantee that no Australian uranium stays in the USSR.

—Is the Minister for Communications aware of the poor reception of the new Special Broadcasting Service Channel 28 in the Hobart suburb of Taroona? What can be done to ensure an improvement in reception for the people concerned, especially as Hobart generally has apparently welcomed SBS television so enthusiastically? Does the Government have any plans to this end, and how soon can implementation of those plans be expected? Is Taroona the only part of Hobart suffering a general problem in the reception of SBS?

—I do have a note about this. I am advised that the topography of Hobart makes television reception extremely difficult. The Department of Communications is aware that in a number of areas around Hobart reception of commercial and national services operating on very high frequency channels is less than adequate. There were initially concerns that the SBS, using the UHF band, would not adequately cover Hobart. Every effort was made to ensure that the transmission facilities provided to the SBS were the best that could be accommodated on the Mount Wellington site. A comprehensive survey of reception in Hobart is yet to be completed, but preliminary reports indicate that the Service is providing high quality reception to most parts of Hobart, including many areas where the reception of VHF services is normally inadequate. Unfortunately, Taroona is an area heavily shaded from the Mount Wellington site. It is expected that, while the reception may be marginally better than VHF reception from Mount Wellington, it will not be adequate and a translator will ultimately be required.

—The Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations would have noticed the comments by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, that the failure of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to grant a productivity increase would destroy the accord. Would the Minister not agree that this is placing undue and unreasonable pressure on the Commission to tow the Government and union line, thereby placing its independence in jeopardy on the matter of productivity increases?

—I am not aware-nor, so far as I know, do I have a note on that-of Mr Willis having made that statement, but I do not deny that he did. Not being aware of it, I do not think I can comment other than to say that, if the accord were to fail for any reason, I believe it would be a very serious blow to the welfare of Australia and to our continuing economic recovery. I base that assessment on recent experience in Australia and overseas. Recent experience in Australia-as recent as 1981 and 1982-has shown us that when the centralised wage determination policy was abandoned by the Fraser Government in May 1981 at a time of reasonably high economic growth it was followed by a wages explosion of 13 per cent in 1981 and 14 per cent in 1982. Under conditions of reasonably high economic growth there is no reason whatsoever to believe that that experience would not be repeated if the accord were to break down. Moreover, and perhaps more significantly, in the United Kingdom, which does not have the sort of economic growth that Australia has had in the last few years, which has been reducing the unemployment rate, in spite of an unemployment rate rising above 13 per cent, wage outcomes relative to the inflation rate have been higher than in Australia and those unionists who have managed to remain employed, in fact, have gained real wage increases. That is in spite of unemployment levels in double figures and rising.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Finance been drawn to an article in the Courier-Mail on April Fool's Day in which the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, is reported as backing the submission of the Leader of the National Party of Australia, Mr Sinclair, to the Remuneration Tribunal seeking an increase in salary and allowances? Can the Minister quantify the additional Government spending which would be involved if such a submission were successful? Has the Minister considered drawing to the attention of the coalition's Waste Watch Committee such an example of potentially profligate and wasteful government spending?

—Yes, I have seen the Courier-Mail report to which Senator Cook referred. I have already acted on his suggestion that the Opposition's Waste Watch Committee be informed of this example of potential profligate and wasteful government spending. I can also tell Senator Cook that the cost of meeting Mr Sinclair's request, demand or whatever it was is of the order of $28,000 a year. I wrote to Senator Baume, the chairman of the Opposition's Waste Watch Committee, on 9 April. In that letter I said that I was responding to Mr Howard's invitation to provide the Committee with information which would identify and highlight areas of profligate and wasteful government spending and that I thought this was a prime example of such a case. I received a reply from Senator Baume on 23 April--
—Which Baume was that?

—Michael `Patrick' Baume. On 23 April Senator Baume replied that he regarded such money as well spent, which shows us that there is no limit to the self-indulgence of Senator Baume, along with Mr Sinclair, which I suppose is not really surprising given that both of them have a record of having been caught with their fists in the till, so to speak.
—Order! The Minister will withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw, Mr President.

—Is the Minister for Finance aware that officers of the Reserve Bank of Australia are unable to obtain information on their superannuation entitlements? Why is the Government procrastinating over the question of approval of the amended terms of the Reserve Bank Officers Superannuation Fund? Is the Minister aware of the difficulties that the delays are causing officers, particularly those with many years of service who are contemplating or approaching retirement?

—I am, in a general sense, aware of the matter Senator Reid raised. I apologise for not being able to recall the precise details but I will supply an answer either orally shortly or in writing. This matter is before me and I am considering it. I apologise for not remembering the precise details because I am considering the implications of the proposal-implications regarding a greater reliance on lump sum payments rather than pension payments, as any movement in that direction, of course, is at variance with the Government's general policy on retirement incomes. I cannot recall the details but I will supply an answer.

—Is it a fact that the Minister for Community Services has been approached by members of the South Australian Parliament to revoke recent changes to the Child Care Act? If so, what would be the effect of any such changes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have been approached by members of the South Australian Parliament-members on both sides of the South Australian Parliament, in fact-to revoke or amend recent changes to the Child Care Act. The effect of such changes would be to limit our capacity to increase the number of child care places available and to continue the practice of providing an excessively high subsidy to those who are well off in the community, while being unable to assist those who have disadvantages, particularly economic disadvantages but also disabilities and peculiar disadvantages such as the Aborigines have. It would also limit our capacity in future years to contain the costs in child care centres.

ANSWER.PARA: I can understand the members of the Liberal and National Parties in South Australia writing to me about this matter, because they traditionally support people who are better off in the community. I have some difficulty in understanding why all members of my Party in South Australia, except the Premier, Mr Bannon, wrote to me. I have written a reply to them, pointing out that I think they have misunderstood the situation. I particularly could not understand statements they made that what the Federal Government was doing in the area of children's services was insufficient, that it was not providing sufficient places and that, according to them, the places the Government did provide would not be used.

My difficulty in this area has been compounded because I have just been approached by Labor members of the South Australian Parliament requesting that, wherever possible, I should make the opportunity available to them to open new child care centres. I have also been approached indirectly by another group who complained that the last time I opened a child care centre in South Australia I forgot to name the State members who were present. I realise this is a most discourteous thing to do. I think my colleagues in South Australia had better make up their minds whether they want to be in it or not. If they do not want to be in it and if they want to criticise the program, then my Federal colleagues and I will open all the child care centres. If State members want to open some centres, they had better have a look at their attitude to the child care program.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. What will be the cost in both capital and annual leasing expenses of the proposed move of the Sydney operations of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission from the AGC Building in the legal centre of Sydney out to new premises at Woolloomooloo? How much has been spent on improvements, renovations and fittings for and what is the leasing cost of the present area now occupied by the Arbitration Commission in Sydney in each financial year of that occupancy? What will be the total cost of the move? Was this move initiated by the Arbitration Commission itself? If not, who did initiate it and what is the attitude of the Arbitration Commission to this forced move to an inconvenient location?

—I cannot answer all the part of that question off the top of my head. However, I can give a general recollection of the matter, subject to later confirmation. It was accepted that there was a need to relocate the Arbitration Commission from its present central business district premises and it moved to another area. Senator Michael Baume said it moved to Woolloomooloo; I cannot remember whether it is Woolloomooloo. If I remember correctly, the cost of the new premises in that area was substantially less than the same type of premises would have cost in the central business district. I cannot remember all the details. I will get them from Mr Willis. I think I could safely say that the total cost of the move would have been a good deal less than the money that the pensioners and orphans who put money on deposit with Patrick Partners lost when that firm when bankrupt.

—Mr President, I take a point of order. This is the second answer in a row in which the Minister has attacked Senator Michael Baume. I ask you to call him to order, to do his duty as a Minister and to stop acting in that sleazy manner that he is--
—Order! I ask the Leader of the Opposition to withdraw that remark.
—To suggest that a Minister is behaving in a sleazy manner--
—Order! I have asked the Leader of the Opposition to withdraw that remark.

—I withdraw the remark. I take another point of order, Mr President. I will rephrase what I said, since you will not permit me to use that expression. I think the Minister is behaving in a way which is totally unacceptable. He is thoroughly abusive. He shows a total lack of any sense of decorum. I think you should keep him in order.

—Order! I am able to contain the Minister only so far as the Standing Orders of the Senate are concerned. I try to do that to the best of my ability. I appeal to the Minister to consider the matters that the Leader of the Opposition has raised when he is making replies to members of the Opposition from time to time.
—Certainly, Mr President.

—Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware of a public campaign to lift the proportion which the age pension represents of average weekly earnings? Is it the case that in the next national wage case increases, money wages will not increase in line with the practice increases as measured by the consumer price index? If so, will this inevitably mean that pensions, which are linked to the consumer price index, will rise as a proportion of average weekly earnings? If so, what might the resultant proportion be?

—I am aware, in a general sense, of the sort of campaign to which Senator Maguire referred. I can tell Senator Maguire and anybody else who is interested that the latest available data-that is for the December 1985 quarter-show that the age pensions stood at 23.7 per cent of average weekly earnings, compared with a figure of 22.7 per cent of AWE in the March quarter of 1983 when this Government came into office. I think it should also be noted that the depreciation of the Australian dollar, which was provoked principally by the large adverse movement in Australia's international terms of trade, means that the nation as a whole must expect or accept some decline or at least a slower rate of growth in its living standards than would otherwise have been the case. Therefore, the overall cake that is available for domestic consumption has shrunk in real terms. The importance of that point to Senator Maguire's question is that the Government, through the prices and incomes accord, secured agreement from organised labour for a 2 per cent discounting of wages in the present national wage case. But pensioners will not be required to share in that acceptance, if one likes, of the reduced real income because the pension will continue to be indexed on the full CPI movement. Finally, because of those two factors, assuming that other things remain equal-that is, that AWE through the discounting agreement under the accord will increase by less than the CPI at least in the short term, while the pension will increase by the full CPI rate-pensions as a proportion of AWE should rise marginally above their present level.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs aware of the decision of the Central Land Council to transport 60 Aboriginal people from central Australia to the Ranger uranium mine to ascertain the effect of uranium mining in that area before considering negotiations with mining companies on the development of new uranium mines in central Australia? In light of the considerable expense being incurred by the Northern Land Council and the Central Land Council in their quests to negotiate the exploration and development of new mines in an effort to become financially viable and independent of government, will the Minister state whether the Government has any intention of allowing further exploration and development of uranium? If not, will the Government recompense the land councils for those wasted funds? Finally, if the Government has no intention of allowing further development of the uranium mining industry, does the Minister agree that the Aboriginal people involved are being led up the garden path?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have a brief on the matters raised by Senator Kilgariff. I recall that a group of Aboriginal leaders from the central area of the Northern Territory did travel north to the Arnhem Land area to study the effects of uranium mining on the local communities. My understanding of the purpose of the exercise was that it was not in relation to any future intentions of developing uranium mines in the Northern Territory but rather so that the people would have an increased understanding of the kinds of effects those sorts of developments have on the community. In that context, I think it is a most useful development.

ANSWER.PARA: Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory are under a great deal of strain. Those communities who have been in contact with mining or whose lifestyles have been affected by mining are under even greater strain than, say, pastoral Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory. From what I can recollect of what I heard of the expedition it was what one might call a community education exercise and one which the leaders themselves undertook. I think it is rather patronising and even a little insulting of Senator Kilgariff to suggest that they were being led up the garden path when my understanding of the situation is that they made this decision to undertake this community exercise themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Community Services. Will the Minister urgently review the liaison process between his Department and the Department of Social Security which has led to the anomaly of reducing the disabled pension for married couples living independently in the community, while paying the full rate to them if they live in an institution? As it is the policy of the Department of Community Services to encourage and support independent living skills, will the Minister please advise the Department of Social Security that it is out of date in cutting the married pension rate when married couples try to survive independently in the community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the Government's policy-and, indeed, the policy of both the Department of Social Security and the Department of Community Services-to encourage a move away from institutionalisation of aged and disabled people in the community. Both departments have taken significant steps to this end in such things as the review of new nursing home procedures, the development of home and community care services, and the introduction last November of the new carer's pension. However, in assessing income support, the Government must take account of the concept of need, and the concept of need in this area frequently creates what Senator Reynolds calls an anomaly-I am not sure that it is.

ANSWER.PARA: Successive governments of all political persuasions have held that couples living together have greater means of support than individual pensioners, and as a result the married rate of pension has always been set lower than the single rate. That policy has existed in this country for as long as pensions have been in existence. Plainly, when partners enter institutionalised care separately, particularly if one is to be permanently institutionalised, their needs change and for income support services they need to be treated as individuals.

I will check with my colleague the Minister for Social Security, Mr Howe, as to any changes his Department has made in this area recently. I do not think there have been any changes, but basically the policy that the single pension should be more than half the married pension, both for aged and invalids, has existed in Australia for as long as the pension system has been in existence. I will see whether that situation has changed in recent times.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Education. I refer to the Government's response, expected soon, to the Senate Committee report `Towards a National Language Policy'. Will the Minister outline developments towards a comprehensive response by the Government, which she promised 10 weeks ago in a careful statement to the Senate? Is the Government's response still expected some time this month? In particular, when will an Australian advisory council on language policy be announced? Finally, what significance is there that only 10 days ago the Minister appointed a special consultant to co-ordinate the final stages of the Government's response to the report?

—The third part of Senator Teague's question in a way answers the first part. The announcement of the appointment of a specialist consultant to work on the final stages of the development of the response is a major step forward. The consultant in question, Mr Jo Lo Bianco, is extremely well qualified for the task. He is an Italian language specialist who has also done post-graduate studies in bilingual and multilingual education issues. He has been, and I think still is, the Chairman of the Victorian Multicultural Education Committee. He is a member of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation National Commission and has been very involved in multilingual and bilingual matters in that capacity. I believe that through his capacity to consult widely throughout the ethnic communities and his knowledge of the area, he will accelerate the development of a suitable response. Mr Lo Bianco has been appointed for six months and I hope that at the conclusion of the period of his consultancy, we will have a document which will have widespread support, not only in the Senate but also in the community generally.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. Has the Minister seen allegations in the most recent issue of the publication National Farmer that some banks and finance houses are forcing cane growers in Queensland to budget on revenues below those which would be sustained under the Federal Government's proposed underwriting of the No. 1 pool price for the next three years? Has the Minister also noted that the article states that in some cases banks have been forcing growers to budget on pool returns as low as $180 a tonne for the 1987 season, when in fact the Federal Government's proposal would be to underwrite a price of $220 a tonne for the 1987 season? Is the article correct in stating that the Federal Government's sugar package would be worth millions to viable and non-viable growers alike?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article and I believe that some caution should be exercised in interpreting it. In reply to the last part of Senator Colston's question, the value to the industry of the Federal Government's package would depend on two factors, the first being the actual market price for sugar. If the market price for sugar were above what for want of a better word I will call the underwritten price, the Government's offer would become irrelevant. However, on present expectations of sugar prices that is unlikely. The second qualification is that the underwriting funding part of the Commonwealth Government's package depends on whether the Queensland Government does its bit and matches the very generous offer of the Commonwealth, that is, two Commonwealth dollars for one Queensland dollar.

ANSWER.PARA: The latest information I have is that the Queensland Government, at the instigation or insistence of the Premier, still stubbornly refuses to commit that Government to the plan, heedless of the plight of a substantial part of the Queensland sugar industry and the avoidable hardship it will suffer. I also understand that the Minister for Primary Industries in Queensland, Mr Turner, would have willingly accepted the Commonwealth's package many months ago, but he has been stood over by the Premier, or cut off at the knees-to use Mr Kerin's word-and prevented from so doing. Mr Turner wants to do the right thing, but the Queensland Premier refuses to allow him to do it. I suppose that could account for Mr Turner's impending premature retirement. It would be much better for the sugar industry and everyone else if the Premier were to retire instead of Mr Turner.

There has been a significant improvement in free market sugar prices in recent months. In the middle of last year the free market price was as low as US2 1/2c per pound and the last figure I heard was of the order of US8 1/2c per pound. That free market price is notoriously unstable and could change quite substantially in a short period. Because the Government was anxious to prevent any undue erosion of the price to the point where the capacity of the industry to produce for profitable markets might well be destroyed, it offered, subject to the conditions I have already mentioned, to support the No. 1 pool at a price of $230, $225, and $220 for the 1985, 1986, and 1987 seasons respectively. That was subject to being accommodatable within a maximum cost. I understand, however, that when the price was extremely low last year, some banks began using No. 1 pool prices below $200 a tonne when assessing growers' individual budgets. One can sympathise with the banks, I suppose, in adopting a figure like that for as long as the Queensland Government refuses to do its bit, or more accurately, the Queensland Premier refuses to allow the Queensland Government to do its bit, and match on a $1 to $2 basis the Commonwealth Government's very generous offer. But from the moment the Queensland Cabinet decides that it will stand up to the Premier and insist that the Queensland Government do its bit there would be no justification for banks making assessments of individual canegrowers' viability on a pessimistic assumption that the number one pool would return less than $200 a tonne.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. It results from a statement that he made in response to a question by Senator Chipp earlier today, namely, that countries other than Finland are using Soviet enrichment and processing facilities. Is Australian uranium being sent to Russia for reprocessing or enrichment from any country other than Finland? Does Russia retain the end products of fuel rod reprocessing? Can the Minister guarantee that no plutonium from the Russian reprocessing of Australian uranium, used in Finnish or other reactors, is retained in the Soviet Union or any other country for nuclear weapons? If the Minister claims that he can give this assurance, what techniques are used to precisely identify and quantify plutonium yielded from reprocessing spent fuel rods?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —That question displays a rather distressing confusion about some of the concepts that are involved here, in particular confusion between enrichment and reprocessing. When I answered the earlier question I spoke only of Finland and other countries using Soviet enrichment facilities. I did not speak of them using Soviet facilities to reprocess spent fuel rods.
—Tell me they don't.

—I am just making it clear. By enrichment, I could have also added other toll processing exercises like conversion and fuel fabrication because that is subsumed in what happens with that uranium, but I certainly did not mean to include reprocessing of spent fuel rods, with Australian uranium in it, which does, of course, involve the extraction of some degree of plutonium and gives rise to the sorts of questions that Senator Haines has just asked. It is not the case that any Australian origin nuclear material that winds up in Finnish fuel rods is reprocessed in Russia. For that to happen would be at odds with the particular safeguards agreement that we have entered into with Finland. That safeguards agreement makes it permissible for Australian origin nuclear material to be enriched by some other country on an all-in all-out basis, as it is enriched in the Soviet Union in the case of Finland. That particular agreement does not make it possible for spent fuel rods with this material in it to be reprocessed in the Soviet Union. It is a very important distinction and one that I believe must be understood. Senator Haines also asked what other countries may use Soviet enrichment--
—You said `other countries'.

—Sure, there is no mystery about these things; they are all on public record. My recollection is that the agreements with Sweden and also with the European Atomic Energy Community-EURATOM-which is a group of about 10 European countries, also make provision for the transfer of Australian origin nuclear material for toll processing purposes-that is to say enrichment conversion and fuel fabrication-on an all-in all-out basis to countries, including the Soviet Union, with whom Australia does not have a bilateral agreement in force.

ANSWER.PARA: Lest there be any residual confusion about the concept of all-in all-out, may I make it clear. What is already well known and on record is that all-in all-out does not necessarily mean that every single atom and molecule that goes in with an Australian flag sticking on it like a toothpick in an olive is the same atom or molecule that actually comes out again. The principle of equivalence does apply. We are talking about--

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't--

—I do not think I need any more help from Senator Hill. He should confine himself to olives and toothpicks and not try to contribute to discussions about uranium or he will get himself into as much confusion as the Democrats do. I think my answer has probably sown more clarity than confusion, but in the event that it has not, and Senator Haines requires further elucidation on it, I will do my best to oblige.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration. I was going to preface my question by asking whether his attention has been drawn to page 13 of the Sydney Morning Herald, but I perceive from here that he has just got to that section of the paper. However, has the Minister's attention been drawn to the article in today's Sydney Morning Herald by Jock Collins in which he questions the assumption that increased migration stimulates economic growth? Will the Minister give consideration to encouraging further detailed study of this area using alternative methodology to that used in the Committee for Economic Development of Australia study?

—Senator Ray has very good eyesight; I have just reached page 13 of the Sydney Morning Herald but I have not read the article. I understand that the article questions aspects of the Labor Party's policy, as announced by Mr Hurford in recent times. I am afraid that I have not read the details of this policy; nor have I read the article by the Committee for Economic Development of Australia which apparently places this policy in some doubt. I will read the article, I will endeavour to read the CEDA article, I will seek the views of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, and if necessary will take the advice of Senator Ray and get an alternative viewpoint.
—Why are you misleading the Parliament?
—Senator Button is making vile accusations, Mr President, but I will not ask him to withdraw as he is on my side.

—I refer the Minister representing the Attorney-General to the speech by the Prime Minister at the opening of the Constitutional Commission, I think on 30 January, in which he said that the `Government hoped that the Constitutional Commission would maximise public involvement and interest in possible alterations to the Constitution'. Is the Minister aware that the Constitutional Commission is proposing to publish issues papers for the assistance of members of the public who wish to make submissions to its committee? Is he also aware that these papers will not be available until the end of May and that the closing date for public submissions is the end of June, thus allowing only one month for members of the public to formulate, formalise and submit their written submissions? Inasmuch as it is the Government's intention, if I might quote the Prime Minister, `to encourage thoughtful consideration by ordinary Australians of the shape of the future of our Constitution', is the Minister tempted to share my view that a period of one month for submissions by ordinary Australians is not long enough? While recognising the independence of the Commission, is the Minister prepared to wait upon it and ask it to extend the period for a greater period than one month?

—I am delighted to hear of Senator Crichton-Browne's commitment to the process of thoughtful constitutional reform. It is a course I commend to others of his colleagues who have not been conspicuous for any similar commitment in the past. I am not able to confirm what precisely is the case about closing dates and so on for these submissions. I will refer Senator Crichton-Browne's concern to the Attorney-General to see how he wants to respond to it. I simply make the point that these issues have been with us for a very long time. I think the general parameters are pretty clear. The Constitutional Commission consists of a highly representative body of Australian citizens and I imagine that Mr Lionel Bowen is contemplating in the first instance that the real momentum will come not so much from further public submissions but rather from what is generated by this particular body. That may well be the rationale for having a relatively short consultation phase at this stage.
—They have to respond to the issues.

—I understand what the honourable senator is saying, and it is arguably the case that more time than that would be desirable. I will refer Senator Crichton-Browne's expression of concern about this to the Attorney-General to see if he is able to amend the processes accordingly.

—I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a recent report in the Australian Financial Review regarding Marcos links with Australian companies involved in a large meat cartel, the central of these being the Sydney based company Phil-Bai International Pty Ltd whose directors, reputedly, are or were mostly Marcos cronies. At what stage are investigations by the Department of Foreign Affairs and the Department of the Treasury into Marcos's Australian investments? Do they include the allegations related in the Financial Review?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised by the Minister for Foreign Affairs that the Treasury has undertaken a preliminary examination of its confidential records on Philippines investments submitted to the Government over the past several years and has supplied the Department of Foreign Affairs with some factual information, some of which is already public, as well as some confidential information. To date investigations have shown that, on the basis of the available data, Philippine investment in Australia has been small, of the order of $32m at 30 June 1984 and mostly in services and primary industries. Australian officials have also perused the documents made public in the United States by the Solarz Committee. The contents of those documents did not identify Australian transactions or dealings for identifiably Australian transactions that involved Philippine assets.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government will consider sympathetically, as we have said previously, a request from the Philippines Government for assistance in the repatriation of Philippine assets and will give whatever assistance it can consistent with Australian law and policy. No such request has yet been received.

As to the specific reference by Senator Bolkus to the Australian Financial Review report about the Phil-Bai company, I can confirm that the allegations reported in the Financial Review are under investigation. In addition, a special task force from the Philippines was in Australia recently on behalf of the Philippines Minister of Agriculture, Mr Mitra, on Phil-Bai related matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 April Senator Coleman asked me a question about exercises involving the United States off Western Australia. The answer from the Minister for Defence is this: No combined naval exercise between the United States, United Kingdom and Australia is currently planned for the Western Australian exercise areas off Fremantle. An exercise involving United States, United Kingdom and Australian naval units is planned for southern and eastern Australian waters later this year. As with all such exercises, precise details remain classified until shortly before their commencement. State and Territory governments are always advised in advance of any proposed visit to their ports by nuclear-powered warships. This is to enable the safety procedures required under the conditions of entry for nuclear-powered warships to be put into effect by the State and Territory authorities. The Government has no current request for any nuclear-powered warship to visit Western Australia. The Government does not believe that any appreciable hazard to the Australian people arises through our acceptance of warship visits from our friends and allies.

—I also have an answer to a question that was addressed to me yesterday by Senator Archer on the matter of the drug offensive. The Special Minister of State has provided the following response: I am advised by the Minister for Health that the $100m funding for the drug offensive over three years does not include the $10m for extra staff and $7.2m for enhanced computer capacity for the Australian Federal Police over three years promised by the Prime Minister before the 1984 election. The first instalment of these additional resources for the Australian Federal Police has been made in this financial year and has contributed significantly to the law enforcement aspects of the drug offensive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I claim to have been misrepresented. On two separate occasions at Question Time Senator Walsh repeated untrue and defamatory allegations against me similar to those he has been required to withdraw on many previous occasions. The fact that they are false is evident from the report of the inspector into the failure of Patrick Partners. The report, to the Wran Labor Government of New South Wales in December 1976, cleared me of any culpability or criticism in the following terms. I quote from page 58 of the report:

SPEECH.PARA: I am satisfied that at the very least by the end of May, and certainly before the Application for Renewal of Licenses on 4 June 1975, all the Partners (with the exception of Mr Baume) were fully aware that it was at least a real possibility that Patrick Corporation Ltd would be placed in liquidation in the near future. I am also satisfied that all the Partners (again with the exception of Mr Baume) were aware of the involvement of Patrick Intermarine Acceptances Ltd in any downfall of Patrick Corporation Ltd and also of the likely consequences to Patrick Partners itself.

The inspector indicated in the report that I had had very little contact with that firm since I sought to withdraw unilaterally from it in February 1975. Not only did the Wran Government decide to take no legal action against any of the partners of Patrick Partners-presumably because they had done nothing illegal-but also, as the record shows and the report indicates, I was specifically excepted from any criticism by the inspector on this matter. The Minister is fully aware of all this, as he has frequently referred to this report. In these circumstances his repetition of these false allegations represents a gross abuse of the privileges of the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON AN AUSTRALIA CARD

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to raise a serious matter of concern relating to a report of the deliberations of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card. I refer to an article on page 13 of today's Australian headed `Committee Rejects ID Card as Wasteful Exercise', bylined under the name of Alan Fewster. The article stated that the Australian had received a copy of the Committee's main findings and recommendations which were allegedly finalised yesterday. The article then quoted various sections of the alleged draft report, attacking the concept of an Australia Card as proposed by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: As Chairman, I am concerned that the integrity and objectivity of the Committee has been severely damaged by the Australian's article. It is not the first time during the conduct of these hearings that damaging reports have been given to the media. I cite an article which appeared in the Australian Financial Review on 15 April 1986 headed `Committee of MPs rejects plan for national ID card'. There have been others in a similar vein.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can't blame the media for publishing leaks.

—I am surprised that Senator Chipp intervenes in this matter. He will have his time to speak. For those of us on the Committee who attended all or most of the hearings, who have read and sifted through the 200 letters and submissions received by the Committee, who have worked on this report for five months and who have visited every State, this leak is seen as a serious attack on the credibility of the Committee's findings and work. At all costs we have attempted to work as a bipartisan team, free of overt political considerations. Our disappointment is, therefore, obvious.

SPEECH.PARA: Accordingly, I have set in train the following process: First, I have personally contacted all secretariat staff of the Committee and sought assurances from them that they were not responsible for the leak. I received assurances from all of them that they were not responsible. Secondly, I called an extraordinary meeting of the Committee at 1.45 p.m. today and asked each senator and member present whether they were responsible for the leak; and whether they were satisfied with security in their offices. Thirdly, I will ask the Chief Security Officer to provide me with appropriate information. Fourthly, I have called another meeting of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card for Tuesday, 6 May to finalise the report and to establish the need to refer the matter to the Joint Committee of Privileges. At the meeting members of the Committee will indicate to me any problems they may have had with security. This statement will also be presented to the House of Representatives.

DEBATE.TITLE: STEWART ROYAL COMMISSION OF INQUIRY INTO ALLEGED TELEPHONE INTERCEPTIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table volume I of the final report of the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Alleged Telephone Interceptions conducted by the Hon. Mr Justice D. G. Stewart and seek leave to make a statement relating thereto.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The final report of the Royal Commission was furnished yesterday to the Governor-General and to the Governors of New South Wales and Victoria. As honourable senators would be aware, Mr Justice Stewart conducted his inquiry pursuant to letters patent issued by the Commonwealth, New South Wales and Victoria. It has been decided that volume I of the report should be presented to the Parliament today. In those circumstances, I regret that only the minimum number of copies of volume I have been made available. I expect that further copies will be made available as soon as possible. The report consists of two volumes. It has been decided that volume I should be tabled, but not volume II.

SPEECH.PARA: Volume II of the report contains considerable detail of possible criminal offences identified by the Royal Commission in the course of its inquiry. Those offences relate to breaches of Federal and State law. It has been decided not to table volume II because of the prejudice which may result to future investigations and prosecutions. I can say, however, that volume II has been passed to the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions for examination and decisions on future action, insofar as possible breaches of Federal law may be involved. I would expect that copies of volume II would be made available by the New South Wales and Victorian governments to their respective law enforcement authorities.

Volume I of the report contains a comprehensive examination of the extent of illegal interceptions by Victorian, New South Wales and Federal police. It also contains a comprehensive description of specific police operations in which intercepted material was of benefit.

Mr Justice Stewart, at chapter 16 of volume I, makes a number of conclusions and recommendations, in particular, concerning the extent to which telephone intercept powers should be made available to law enforcement agencies of the Commonwealth, the States and the Territories. The Government will give urgent consideration to those recommendations. I should say that the Government is in the final stages of a Bill to amend the Telecommunications (Interception) Act following decisions made at the Special Premiers Meeting on Drug Strategy in April 1985. Copies of the relevant Bill have already been forwarded to the States. Mr Justice Stewart's recommendations will be urgently considered in the context of that proposed legislation. I move:
That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Government for its prompt tabling of the report of Mr Justice Stewart on the New South Wales police tapes-as they are now known rather than as the Age tapes. However, I express my concern that only volume I has been tabled. There is another volume which is confidential, certainly at this stage. The commission that was given to Mr Justice Stewart to investigate as a royal commissioner the New South Wales police tapes is one which the Opposition had strenuously urged upon the Government from the time that the Age tapes, as they were then known, were made so public by the Age newspaper in February 1984. Very shortly afterwards, the Opposition called for a royal commission into those tapes. The Government steadfastly rejected that call and maintained that objection for many months-in fact, for more than 12 months.
