After all the events that occurred in 1984, which I do not need to go over again, the Government was finally persuaded to give Mr Justice Stewart, who was then conducting various other royal commissions of inquiry and who had been appointed as the Chairman of the National Crime Authority, extended terms of reference to inquire into what are now known as the New South Wales police tapes.

SPEECH.PARA: The so-called Age tapes were only a small segment of what has now been revealed as a much wider operation which was conducted over a number of years by a group within the New South Wales Police Force. The Stewart Royal Commission into Alleged Telephone Interceptions was no doubt assisted by the decision that ultimately was made by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) to give indemnity to a number of New South Wales policemen to enable the full truth of this matter to be ascertained and reported. The Premier of New South Wales has played a very sinister part in this exercise over a long period because the sorts of threats that he was making to New South Wales police officers were of the kind for which he has now become notorious, as in his recent threats directed at a witness in a criminal trial.

TALK.START.PARA: —He said that he would put them in gaol.

—Yes, he did. Firstly, the Premier said that there was nothing in the tapes. That was interesting because he had been Minister for Police for a relevant period, so presumably he would have had some authority to say that there was nothing in the tapes. When it became clear that there was something in them he said that he would put in gaol any policemen who were found to have done something illegal. There was no prospect of having an adequate inquiry unless indemnities were given. Although the present Attorney-General seemed to be very reluctant for a long time to do so, he was prevailed upon to give those indemnities. No doubt that is why we now have what was described by Senator Gareth Evans when tabling volume I. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Volume I of the report contains a comprehensive examination of the extent of illegal interceptions by Victorian and New South Wales police and the Australian Federal Police. It also contains a comprehensive description of specific police operations in which intercepted material was of benefit.

That volume has only just been tabled. None of us have had an opportunity to read it but the size of it bears out the description that it is a comprehensive examination of the extent of these interceptions. It is also very interesting that it is described as containing `a comprehensive description of specific police operations in which intercepted material was of benefit'. Clearly this large amount of material has been found to be authentic and of great value to police, who as a result have already carried out successful operations.

What an outstanding contrast this information and this statement provide with not only what Mr Wran, the Premier of New South Wales, had been saying, but also the attitude of Senator Evans, who as Attorney-General month after month in 1984, with his colleagues-I do not see many of them here-continually maintained that there was no proof of the authenticity of the tapes; that they had no value and nobody could rely on them. Finally a Senate committee was established because no royal commission or joint committee was established by the Government. The Senate established a Senate committee to investigate this material. Virtually no co-operation was given by anyone in authority, largely because of the sorts of attitudes adopted by the New South Wales and Commonwealth governments.

The Opposition will read volume I that has now been tabled with very great interest and care because it is highly relevant to the interest expressed in this place and to the inquiries that were undertaken by the Senate Select Committee on the Conduct of a Judge, which ran into various dead-ends and roadblocks along the way. Clearly, the findings of Mr Justice Stewart will be relevant to the examination by that Committee. It is also worth noting that a very interesting article published today in the National Times is about the trial of that judge. It is interesting to note the allegation that information contained in the New South Wales police tapes may have been relevant to that trial. The article stated in fact that the Director of Public Prosecutions sought assistance from the Royal Commissioner in respect of some possibly relevant material that the Royal Commissioner had and on which he may or may not have reported. We do not know. However, the fact is that these allegations have been made in today's issue of the National Times. These allegations will have to be examined very closely.

Indeed, it may have been justified for Mr Justice Stewart to have taken the view that that information was relevant. I do not know whether it was or whether it was not. I think that needs to be examined as well. Be that as it may, it is another matter of concern and is passing strange that if this material were relevant the trial of that judge should have been disposed of just on the eve of the reporting of Mr Justice Stewart. That is another matter that will have to be considered very seriously and examined and which, maybe, should be considered and examined in quarters other than this Parliament. I refer to the other aspects of the statement made by Senator Evans, who said:
It has been decided that volume I should be tabled,
which has been done-
but not volume II.
He went on to say:
Volume II of the report contains considerable detail of possible criminal offences identified by the Royal Commission in the course of its inquiry.
Here is further proof of the authenticity and the value of at least some of this material. Senator Evans continued:

Those offences relate to breaches of Federal and State law. It has been decided not to table volume II because of the prejudice which may result to future investigations and prosecutions. I can say, however, that volume II has been passed to the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions for examination and decision on future action . . .

Obviously there are sufficiently important and serious matters of great value and likely proof contained in this material. As volume I apparently shows, that material already has been of benefit in criminal investigation and law enforcement. Apparently this material is going to be of future benefit because of the so-called sensitivity of the material in volume II. I would like to register on behalf of the Opposition our concern that volume II has not been tabled. I do not know the size of volume II. I acknowledge and understand that it is to be, or that it has been, made available on a confidential basis to the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney). Certainly it should be made available to him. Certainly it should be made available to the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Chipp). I hope that will be done as well.

I must say that I am concerned that there may be a large amount of material in volume II which also ought to be reported to this Parliament. Of course, I can understand that if there are still criminal investigations and prosecutions to be launched in relation to that material it may be necessary to prevent signals being passed to people under examination or investigation leading to prosecution. It may be that at this time not all of the material can be made public. However, I believe that in due course it should be made public. I wonder whether the Government has given full consideration to how much at this stage could be made public rather than simply saying that it is not going to table volume II at all. I borrow a famous word in this Senate, the authorship of which I readily acknowledge. I refer to the word `sanitised'. Senator Evans was a great proponent of tabling as much material as possible in this Parliament and, as he used to say, if necessary in a sanitised form. Therefore, I hope that the Government, if it has not already done so-there is no mention of it here-will not simply take a blanket view that nothing in volume II can be published. I think it should be examined very carefully to see to what extent a sanitised version-to use such a famous and authoritative phrase-can be tabled, even now or at least as soon as possible.

Of course, not having read volume I, I am unable at this stage to say whether we are satisfied with the amount of material that has been reported therein and the sort of conduct that it covers. However, it seems to me that there is a problem in that volume II may in fact be dealing with a mish-mash of conduct, some of which may be of a criminal kind involving breaches of the criminal law, and others which may fall short of that. They may be mixed up together. However, royal commissions are designed to inform governments and parliaments and, indeed, the people about the conduct of, in particular, public officials. If there is material in volume II which may reveal matters relevant to the conduct of public officials but which may be short of being criminal offences, then there is no justification, in my view, for that material to remain confidential. I believe that the Parliament should be given as much information as it possibly can be given about the conduct of public officials.

I remind the Government that when we were in Government in August 1982 and received the fifth Costigan report of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, which contained a great deal of material about the conduct of public officials and government agencies-information certainly of a very critical and damaging kind-the vast amount of that volume of the Costigan report was tabled in the Senate by me on behalf of the Government. We took the view then that even though there were inquiries and investigations to be made with the possibility of prosecutions arising out of a lot of that material, because the conduct of public officials and public agencies was involved, the Parliament was entitled to have that information made available to it. Thus the Parliament was able to make its own judgment about these matters.

I am sorry to say that we have to express a great deal of suspicion because of the way the Government has approached this matter from its very beginning two years ago. I am very sorry to say it but I do have to express a great deal of suspicion and concern about how far this Government wants anyone to know about these matters. There has been a fair amount of covering up and distractions by this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —For almost three years now.

—As Senator Chipp said, for almost three years. We are at the end of our patience. At long last we have the report of a royal commission which, on Mr Justice Stewart's track record, I am sure is as comprehensive as it is said to be. We want to know, indeed we demand to know and are entitled to know, the whole truth, no matter who gets hurt. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I listened carefully to Senator Durack and I believe that I could not disagree with anything he said. I express my concern as a person who has been interested in this matter for three years now. I remind the Senate that I was the lucky recipient of most of the Age tapes before they were even made public. The person who had them felt that they were a little too hot to handle and said: `Chippy, I am giving you these as my personal insurance'. He then announced to the Press that he had done so.
—I think he doesn't like you.

—Not everybody has friends like that. So I have been privy to the contents of the tapes for some time. I have shared the general view the Liberal Party has expressed right from the start that, while there might have been some inaccuracies and some doubts about some of the material, there was too much cohesion and too much activity involved in them for them to be dismissed as the Government earlier dismissed them.

SPEECH.PARA: So almost three years down the track we now have a 400-page report, which is volume I of the final report of the Royal Commission of inquiry into Alleged Telephone Interception. It is rather astonishing to see a statement in that report concerning material which has been denigrated by the Government. I think I can remember Government speakers saying that the Age tapes were worthless, they were a pack of lies, they were inventions, they were illegally obtained. A lot has happened since then. I shall refer to page 285 of volume I of the report under the heading `Identification of Material'. That is the only part of the report I have been able to look at in the short time I have had it. Before I do so, however, I refer to the following statement of the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans):

Volume II of the report contains considerable detail of possible criminal offences identified by the Royal Commission in the course of its inquiry. Those offences relate to breaches of Federal and State law.

That is a 180-degree turn, for which I commend the Government, in attitude to the material. Two years ago the Government was saying that the tapes were worthless, that they were inventions, and so on. We have come from the point where they were considered worthless to a point now where volume II of the report is regarded as so delicate and so sensitive that it is being withheld from the Parliament of this country and given to the State and Federal Directors of Public Prosecutions so that criminal charges might be laid.
I refer to page 285 of volume I of the report to indicate what has come out of this allegedly worthless material. Paragraph 14.35 of the report states:

In order to identify the authors of the transcripts Commission staff interviewed each police witness who admitted participating, or who was alleged to have participated, in telephone interception operations covered by the transcript material in the Commission's possession. During each interview the witness was shown a copy of the following transcript material:
I now read what is a mind-boggling index of who's who in the criminal world in Australia. This is what has transpired from those worthless documents. The report states:
T1A `Mad Dog' 1979 (Target: Morgan John Ryan).
T1B `Rabid' 1980 (Target: Morgan John Ryan).
T1C Morgan Ryan Summaries (Target: Morgan John Ryan).
T1D 1981 Transcripts (Target: Morgan John Ryan).
T2 `A Dazzler' (Target: Ronald Lopes Dias).
T3 `Southern Comfort' (Target: George David Freeman).
T4 `Lucerne/Pasta' (Target: Robert Trimbole).
T5 `Gorilla' (Target: Christopher Dale Flannery)
Those are just a few of the names which have apparently been unearthed by the so-called worthless Age tapes. I commend the Government for tabling volume I of the report today.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not names unearthed by the tapes; they are targets of the tapes. They don't prove anything.

—That is exactly what I said. I am not trying to score some cheap political point. I am just saying to those people who described the tapes originally as being worthless and not worth worrying over, and whose advice to the Liberals and the Democrats was to forget all about it and to get on with something important, that we now have a report consisting of two parts, the second of which has been referred to the State and Federal Directors of Public Prosecutions. The names of people who have been identified as targets have been listed in the report and information not necessarily about them but about the people with whom they are alleged to have associated, has gone to various people. This information has been gained as a result of telephone interceptions.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to sound patronising when I say this, but I am satisfied that nobody on this side of the Senate wants to go on a witch hunt. I believe that the motivations of Senator Chaney and Senator Durack in particular have been noble and have been directed towards ensuring that justice is done and that there is still faith in the system of justice in this country. The kinds of allegations that have surfaced are too horrific to contemplate, even if they are partially true. I commend Senator Chaney and Mr Spender for the very sober and balanced statement they made yesterday concerning the Murphy affair.

I conclude on one point that does bother me. As head of the Australian Democrats, I am going to make formal application to be afforded the same privilege as has been afforded Mr Howard, namely, to be given a copy of volume II of the report on a confidential basis, and that, like Mr Howard, I be allowed to pass that on with discretion to my nominee. I am sure that the Government will grant that, as it has done in the past. The Government has always been extraordinarily reasonable in these circumstances. It is one thing for the leader of a party or for Senator Chaney, Senator Durack or Senator Haines, who would be my nominee, being provided with a copy of this report and sworn to confidence in regard to its contents, but as soon as we get a copy of the report we are virtually prisoners of a system. That is as it should be; it is as it has to be. Therefore, I commend Senator Durack's idea that some work ought to be done on volume II as soon as is possible so that the Parliament itself can see volume II in a form which does not prejudice possible prosecutions of allegedly guilty people.

Unlike Senator Durack, I do not like the term `sanitised' too much. Without being crude, that term suggests to me that a piece of paper which has been sanitised has been made suitable only for a sanitary purpose. I would not have thought that that is the kind of version of volume II of the report that this chamber would want. I would have thought it would have been an extraordinarily useful exercise to allow this chamber to debate the matters that are raised in volume II of the report without the mentioning of names, as was done in regard to the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. I know that this would be a big job. I expect that we will get some useful background out of volume I of the report. We will also get a vindication by Mr Justice Stewart of the actions of the Liberal Party and the Democrats in publicly raising the issue of the Age tapes. However, we will not get anywhere down the track of exposing organised crime and its connection with people in high places unless we can see-I say this without being crude-the guts of Mr Justice Stewart's findings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

In my view the report on Young Australia that we have been provided with falls short in a number of ways. In the foreword of the report I note that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said that he was impressed with what young people had to say and especially with the high proportion of positive and constructive suggestions that they made. My question is: Why is the Prime Minister not interested in other suggestions they made? What proportion was positive and constructive? If we have this information we can make some assessment of the proportion that was negative about the Government and perhaps not constructive. I believe a responsible Government should be adequately reporting the other views of the youth of Australia. It is not appropriate that we only concern ourselves with their hopes and aspirations; we have to understand their disillusionment, fears and apprehensions. In my view any government should want to understand the degree to which young Australians resent the public relations propaganda exercise to which they are now being subjected.

I am not referring in these remarks to the sort of people who are referred to on page 19, callers who were abusive or rang off; I am referring to callers who had genuine complaints to make about the Government or the system in general. These people only had negative remarks to make. These people have views that must be listened to. Young Australians are not dumb; they are not stupid. They understand very clearly how few of their mates have, as yet, been able to participate in the traineeships. The Senate may be interested to know that out of the promised 10,000 traineeships there are now in place only 903. There are 33 in the private sector and the remainder are in the public sector. So the traineeships that were announced to be the great new deal for young Australians have not turned out to be that way. In my own State only 42 young Australians have an Australian traineeship and all are in the Commonwealth Public Service. In fact, a substantial number of these traineeships are in the Commonwealth Public Service.

I would have appreciated a report that not only highlighted some of the positive aspects of this campaign, but also which honestly highlighted some of the problems the Government is having with the campaign. Members of the Opposition could perhaps understand these problems better than they do now and would be in a better position to make some constructive comments to assist the Government. However, if the Government insists on only putting before us the cream on the cake, it must expect the Opposition to continue to question its motives. I notice that not only the Opposition is unhappy. The Canberra Times of 30 April 1986 reported, on page 7, that the Australian Capital Territory Teachers Federation is also unhappy. It wants to know why its money has been cut when in fact the technical and further education colleges are expected to take a large number of the Priority One trainees if and when the scheme gets off the ground.

I also wish to make some remarks about the 26,000 young Australians who bothered to call in and the so-called lucky 127 who spoke to the Prime Minister. This is referred to on pages 1 and 2 of this booklet. I would appreciate the Government giving some undertakings as to just who was going to be an approved user other than the Commonwealth of the ideas put forward by young Australians. I would appreciate the Government giving some undertaking as to whether or not these 26,000 names and addressed are in fact forming a neat little address list for direct mail propaganda at the next Federal election at the taxpayers' expense. The report is noticeably silent on whether the Government intends proceeding in that way.

This is a long report and I have not yet had time to consider the detail. However, I do believe that to give a summary by theme is inadequate because it does not say what the views of young Australians are within that theme and, therefore, is not as instructive as it could be. I welcome some report from the Government but I wish it was more detailed and more honest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not surprised by that last five minutes worth. It is quite in keeping with Senator Vanstone's chronic complaining about this whole matter, although I must congratulate her for lowering the tone of her voice this time so we were not deafened by the case put. The report on Young Australia is quite thoughtful. If Senator Vanstone had read the outline of it she would understand what it is about. It is a report of what is happening to this point; it is a progress report. It does not even pretend to have the final outline of the program of what might come under Priority One, or what might be the programs and response by the Government to the suggestions of the phone-in and/or the radio talkbacks. It does not claim that. The report makes it quite clear that the Government cannot do that until it has more thoroughly examined the response from young people around Australia. Then it will look very seriously at how it might address those proposals.

SPEECH.PARA: I welcome the report because it certainly does remind us that Priority One is a matter of priority concern for the Government. It does keep us informed on the progress of the Government's major concern. On page 1, in the summary of the report Part B, the point is made that 37 Commonwealth Employment Service youth access offices will be opened early this year. I have had the pleasure and the privilege of opening one such youth access office in Elizabeth. The young people who were there for the opening assured me that they had visited that office on a number of occasions. They enjoy getting information and assistance. They feel welcome. They appreciate the support and advice they get. They understand that the Government is committed to providing better opportunities. The Government has admitted that there are enormous problems facing young people and has taken serious steps to address them. I think this should be mentioned. I certainly want to report that the Elizabeth youth access office is achieving very much what it was established to do.

I would like to make a comment about a brief part of this report relating to the difficulties faced in consulting with a group of Australians in the community. Those of us who have had a hand in the formulation and implementation of policies in consultation with women around Australia, before and after coming into government, have some experience in the whole business of consulting. It is not so difficult to get messages from a business or a central organisation out to the community. There are the standard media of newspaper, radio and television and there are booklets, publications and so on. The real challenge is to find ways in which information can be brought into government, in this case from young people around Australia. This report is a very honest and interesting analysis of the outcome of the phone-in and the talkback on radio. The analysis of where people found out about that phone-in is quite interesting. It suggests that one cannot easily dismiss radio reports in South Australia and Queensland, though the figure seems to me to be quite interestingly high for Western Australia too. The Press also seems to be quite significant in getting the message of the phone-in and the talkback programs out to young people in New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory. I suppose in some ways it is a very neat little measure. It goes some way in trying to make an assessment of how best to get the message out and how best to get the message back in-that is, allowing young people to have their say.

The Government is to be congratulated on producing this document. It is unashamed about saying that it has not achieved all the goals that it had hoped, particularly with the traineeships. But if anybody cares to follow that, they should check it out with the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis).
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

Time restricts the amount I am able to say about the outlook for the aviation industry report before the Senate-an information paper prepared by the Department of Aviation. These papers, I understand, are regularly prepared for the Aviation Industry Advisory Council. I am particularly interested in the tables which appear towards the end of the paper, which indicate the levels of activity at various airports around the country. The figures are quite interesting for Darwin Airport, which is dominated by general aviation movements although, of course, there are Defence aircraft movements in and out of Darwin. In 1985 the airline component of these movements increased by 11 per cent, reflecting the increase in the number of internal travellers, business people and tourists who are being encouraged to move to and visit the Northern Territory. Other figures, which I understand come from another Department of Aviation paper, indicate the percentage increase in airline revenue and passengers for both the Darwin and Alice Springs airports.

The number of passengers uplifted and discharged through Darwin Airport in the year ended 31 December 1984 was 294,847. In 1985 the number was 324,825-an increase of some 10.2 per cent. The number of passengers uplifted and discharged through Alice Springs Airport in 1984 was 288,429 and in 1985 the number rose to 336,299-an increase of 16.6 per cent. These figures give a clear indication of the increased passenger traffic flow through these two airports. Indeed, over the past seven to eight years the average increase in the rate of people passing through the airports has been of the order of 9 to 10 per cent annually.

There is no sign of the passenger traffic slowing up. Indeed, all the indicators point to the contrary. With the promotion of the Northern Territory as a unique tourist destination by the Northern Territory Government and by private enterprise, with the establishment of the Yulara Resort and with Alice Springs rapidly developing as a central hub for airlines with routes criss-crossing Australia, it is obvious that demands on the Territory's airport facilities will increase. It is interesting to note that Alice Springs, with a population of some 25,000 people, has airline passengers of the order of some 336,000 per annum passing through its airport. That figure represents 14 times the size of the local population-a very unusual situation.

Negotiations have been under way for some time to have Alice Springs Airport brought under the airport local ownership plan. The Northern Territory Government, the Commonwealth Government and officers of their respective departments have been meeting to identify the scope of the work which will be required to upgrade Alice Springs Airport to cater for domestic wide-bodied aircraft. My understanding is that there has now been substantial agreement between departmental officers on many aspects of the discussions on aircraft size. However, there is still the matter of the size of the terminal to be determined. The Northern Territory Government, backed by a consultant's report, is pressing for a minimum of 8,000 square metres. I understand that the Department of Aviation is pressing for a maximum of some 6,000 square metres. The reason why the Territory is seeking the larger area is that the Northern Territory Government and industry are looking ahead to the anticipated requirements some seven years on from the time of completion. I understand that the Department of Aviation has also forecast that far ahead but that it has come up with far more conservative estimates of needs and is prepared to see more overcrowding in the airport.

The airlines will have to be consulted when some agreement is reached between the departments, particularly in relation to cost recovery. There is some concern, given the volume of traffic going through the airport, that the time frame which has been suggested by the Department of Aviation is too long. I understand that the suggestion is for redevelopment over a five-year period, based on the prospect of an airport local ownership agreement between the Federal and the Territory governments at the end of this year. Time does not permit me to comment further on this matter, except to say that I understand that the Honourable Peter Morris is visiting the Northern Territory next week. He will be most welcome there and he will be most welcome to see the industry there as it is today.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Canberra Commercial Development Authority annual report 1984-85 is clearly quite a disturbing report for the Government. The covering letter from the Chairman of the Canberra Commercial Development Authority was typed in December last year, yet the report has only just surfaced in the Parliament. This is in quite stark contrast with some of the gung ho, cowboy style tactics which marked the last six weeks before the handover of the Belconnen Mall to the Westfield-Superannuation Fund Investment Trust partnership. Curiously enough, last year's annual report was delayed for quite a while because of the time taken by the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) and the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) to work out just what sum was to be paid into Consolidated Revenue. While there has been no statement about the cause of this year's delay, a reading of the report points the way to some possible reasons. On page 4 we find, first of all, the curious sentence:
Authority members Messrs A. R. Hedley and E. W. C. Mathews dissociate themselves from the comments and opinions set out in the foregoing members report.

Just what was in the report that led the two Public Service appointees to disagree so strongly with the other members of the Board? Firstly, there was the chronicling of the Government's decision of 13 May 1985 that the Canberra Commercial Development Authority would not be the developer of the Tuggeranong retail mall. There had been rumours to this effect since the Canberra Times article of 9 March headed `Budget ploy will not draw smiles'. That week the Chairman of the CCDA, Mr Jim Pead, announced plans to build a $35m retail mall at Tuggeranong in accordance with the changes the Government had made to the Authority's Ordinance to give it the go ahead. Part of that article stated:

Sources said that the public works funding for the project was receiving high-level consideration in Budget preparations, but `people who try to advance their own causes usually do so at the expense of others, and it will be a matter of setting priorities'.

The annual report of the CCDA says that the Government reversed its decision on Tuggeranong without any consultation. The Authority viewed with concern the total waste of resources, including the direct cost of $600,000 to bring the project to the ready-for-construction stage. It added that the National Capital Development Commission had changed all the design and development parameters for the complex, so the Authority's planning work went totally down the drain. The Authority commented that the National Capital Development Commission's actions showed scant regard for the protection of public moneys. There is an extraordinary item of $600,918 in the accounts listed in the report which is to write off this loss. I believe this does not reflect well on the Government.

It certainly seems clear that there has never been a coherent government policy in relation to the CCDA. The hasty abolition of the CCDA in February, which is now being argued before the courts, may well prove to be another very costly adventure for the taxpayers. Certainly if the Australian Capital Territory gets self-government-that will depend on the bona fides of the Hawke Government-the local community will be deprived of a substantial source of annual income as a result of the sale of the Belconnen Mall. Indeed, this was the second point made by the Board in its annual report. It was why the President of the Australian Capital Territory Trades and Labour Council resigned last May. It is interesting that the Department of Territories proposes to prepare a final report even though it was only in charge of the operation of the Belconnen Mall for the last two months of the mall's existence under public sector control. Indeed, I wonder whether the Department will provide any statement on the work of the CCDA in bringing retail site competition to the Australian Capital Territory and whether the Department will throw any light on its legal tangles over the dismantling of the CCDA and on its dealings with the respective Public Service unions which are currently in litigation against it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the President I present the third report of the sixty-second session of the Standing Orders Committee, relating to private interests of senators.

INTERJECT.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH SCIENTIFIC AND INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH ORGANISATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation has been operating in this country for close on 40 years. In terms of public recognition of its value and its achievements, it is true to say of the CSIRO that familiarity breeds a degree of contempt. Unfortunately, few people in this country have any idea of the scope of the research being carried out by the Organisation and its involvement at the very roots of Australia's economic, scientific and technological development. To the ordinary person it is still a small, obscure organisation using Government money to conduct even more obscure research on matters of questionable importance. It is the achievements of the CSIRO, more than anything else, that have put Australia on the world stage and kept it there. It will be mainly through the efforts of the CSIRO in the future that Australia will have an opportunity to move from the chorus line to a principal role in the development of a new era.

The CSIRO has the capacity to lead Australia out of economic mediocrity into technological superiority, but that capacity is being stifled by a lack of recognition, a lack of effective communication and evaluation and a lack of finances. The first three the CSIRO can do something about itself. The lack of adequate finances is something that both State and Federal governments, industry and the community as a whole should be concerned about.

The Chairman, Dr Wild, spoke in his report about a five-year development strategy for the CSIRO and he outlined the goals that it hoped to achieve. These include the identification of growth areas, a concentration of fewer research programs focused on significant national objectives, a more systematic evaluation of research, an improvement in the two-way communication of results, and a development of better management practices and procedures.

The CSIRO has already begun to work towards these goals and this is evident throughout the report. The No. 1 criterion for research projects in this five-year development will be their relevance to national objectives. In other words, will the project or research area have a high potential for making a sustained contribution to the generation of national wealth through exports or in the domestic economy? Will the project be capable of contributing substantially to the level and quality of employment in Australia?

Sirotech Ltd, the CSIRO's technology transfer and commercial assessment company, has scored some notable successes during the year. Its main objective is to assist in the process of taking CSIRO inventions and technology directly into industry and bringing knowledge of industry's needs to CSIRO. It is clear that the projects undertaken by the CSIRO are generally not of a short term nature. Some will take years to complete. Some, such as the development of new space technology and communications technology, are in their infancy and will go on into the next century.

It is of vital importance that this organisation be given more financial security. The limited time horizon of the annual budget cycle militates against long term initiatives. Projects that are of national importance must be secured financially until they are completed, but this need not necessarily be purely from taxpayers' money. Industries in Australia, when compared with those in the United States of America and many European countries, contribute very little to the research that will ultimately benefit them. I am sure that the greater spirit of co-operation between industry and the CSIRO will also lead to increased contribution from this sector. I commend this report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 April, on motion by Senator Reid:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few comments on the annual report of the Joint Coal Board. The Joint Coal Board is to some degree an anachronism. It was established by the Minister for Post-war Reconstruction in 1946-some 40 years ago. I would have thought that we were past that stage by now. The general powers and functions of the Board are stated in the report, the first being:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) to ensure that coal is produced in the State-
that is New South Wales-
in such quantities and with such regularity as will meet requirements throughout Australia and in trade with other countries.

The anachronism is perfectly obvious, because in those days there was only one coal producing State, which was New South Wales. Now we have three or four. The report also goes on to say that its function is:

. . . to ensure that the coal produced in the State is distributed and used in such manner, quantities, classes and grades and at such prices as are calculated best to serve the public interest and secure the economical use of coal and the maintenance of essential services and industrial activities . . .

The Coal Board has a total of 263 employees, which is one employee for every 70 employees in the whole coal mining industry in New South Wales. The insurance division of the Board, on its own, has 73 employees, which is one for every 275 employees in the whole coal mining industry in New South Wales. For the 1984-85 period 19,000 mine and associated workers were covered by workers compensation. The report states that during that same period there were 9,922 compensation claims. Almost one in every two of the total number of employees in the whole coal mining industry in New South Wales was the subject of some sort of compensation claim. With a degree of pride the Board announces in the report that it processed approximately 100,000 cheques.

I turn to the marketing division. God knows what a marketing division would be doing in the Joint Coal Board. It has 22 employees. The geology branch has 24 employees and the electronic data processing service, the main function of which is to process the workers compensation claims, has another 22 employees. By comparison, the Queensland Coal Board has eight employees in total, compared with 263 in New South Wales. Honourable senators should bear in mind that in both States there is a fairly prolific and large mines department.

Associated with the Coal Board is the Coal Industry Tribunal, the function of which is to keep the men working. That was introduced during the wartime years, when a Labor Government had been in power for quite some time. Probably the most disruptive sector during the war was the coal mining industry. Honourable senators will recall that it was in fact Labor Prime Minister Chifley who put the soldiers into the coal mines because of the disputations that occurred in 1949.

The point I am making is that it seems that there needs to be a total review of the Joint Coal Board. The objectives for which it was originally established have not been achieved. Looking at the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures, by far the highest industrial disputation is within the coal industry. Yet it has become our major export earner. Recently we had the case of the whole industry being out on strike for six days when, apparently, no one was able to do anything about it. By the look of things, there is every chance that the dispute now going on could escalate into something which will adversely affect our balance of payments at a time when that is the last thing in the world that we need to happen in this country. Having said that, I must say that the Chairman of the Joint Coal Board is a man for whom I have the highest respect. However, that does not derogate from the observation I make that here we have an archaic organisation that has been going for 40 years. I believe that this is something which my colleagues in the Waste Watch Committee should have a good look at.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ACCESS AND EQUITY IN THE DELIVERY OF FEDERAL GOVERNMENT SERVICES AND PROGRAMS TO MIGRANTS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report and Text of Ministerial Statement

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 29 April, on motion by Senator Chipp:
That the Senate take note of the paper.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed from 29 April, on motion by Senator Watson:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of Professor Alec Lazenby on the development of a system leading to the introduction of legislation for plant variety rights in Australia is most welcome. It is welcome on the basis that after many years of discussion and consideration of this issue, the Government now clearly has before it the report of an expert who has come to a series of conclusions, the most important one of which is to be found on page 5 of the report. Under the heading `Impact of Protection', Professor Lazenby says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Inquiry was asked to consider the expected impact of PVR on identified needs. Evidence, largely from other countries, leads me to conclude that incentives based on protection would probably ameliorate many of the constraints facing our crop improvement program. These include increased breeding resources (5.4.1); better use of germplasm (5.4.2); better access to varieties bred overseas (5.4.3); better use of public, and total, breeding resources (5.4.5, 5.4.6); possible better integration with breeding of basic research and new developments in technology (5.4.7); and a more vigorous and stable seed industry (5.4.8). On balance, therefore, I believe that some form of proprietary protection provides a better means of developing Australia's crop improvement programs than do the options not involving such protection, whether operating alone or in combination (5.4.9).

I believe that in his report Professor Lazenby has laid to rest many of the arguments which had been previously put up against the establishment of PVR. However, I am distressed that this is yet another example of delay which should not have occurred. The report of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources came to precisely the same conclusions the best part of five years ago. It came to those conclusions, it presented a report to this Parliament which, if acted upon at the time, would have led to exactly the same series of recommendations being adopted as Professor Lazenby is now putting forward, would have had us five years further down the track and would have saved the cost of Professor Lazenby's inquiry, valuable as that indeed is.

This is the second occasion in quite recent memory on which this has been the case. A royal commission was conducted by Mr Justice Evatt into the question of Agent Orange. That report added nothing, yielded no new findings and arrived at no substantial conclusions which were materially different from those originally obtained by a Senate committee doing precisely the same job. On both of those occasions we had Senate committees established in response to a matter suddenly arising, which took a great deal of time and effort, heard witnesses, considered evidence, debated material, commissioned research and presented findings to the Senate.

In terms of both Agent Orange and plant variety rights, the Government then decided that the Senate committee reports were not good enough so it spent large sums of money-several millions of dollars for Mr Justice Evatt's inquiry; I do not know the cost of Professor Lazenby's inquiry-and a great deal of time instituting further inquiries. When those inquiries reported they did so in essentially the same terms, with the same conclusions and the same recommendations as the Senate committee reports. It is unfortunate that this should be so.

Having said that, I repeat that Professor Lazenby's report is very welcome. I hope that the Government will act now upon it. I suggest that had it acted upon the Senate committee report when it originally came down, it would have saved itself and the taxpayers a great deal of money, it would have been five or six years further down the track and it would have done a great deal for Australian plant breeding and horticulture, the ornamental varieties as well as crop varieties of plants. It is a great shame that once again the Senate committee system was thought to be second best but I suppose that the valuable thing about it is that this is now the second occasion on which an independent expert has come to precisely the same conclusions as well informed members of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Much of what I intended to say has been said persuasively and articulately by Senator Puplick.
—You are making the very point that Senator Puplick made-that it is useless to have idle repetition.
—It seems to me that, if we do not repeat the message regularly to this Government, it does not get through.
—You are doing exactly the same thing that you are criticising the Government for-repeating things.

—No, I am not. We have had no commitment from the Government that the recommendations of this report will be implemented. Therefore, those of us who take the view that they should be implemented must repeat the message until such time as we get a commitment from the Government. The sad thing is, as Senator Puplick pointed out, that the terms of reference of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources and the report on Australian Plant Breeding Needs by Professor Lazenby are almost identical. Yet that is not the full history of the question of plant variety rights in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter was first raised in the early to middle 1960s when legislation was being freely introduced in many other countries around the world. Yet, over a period of 25 years, we have chosen to ignore the fact that Argentina, Austria, Belgium, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, West Germany, France, Hungry, Israel, Japan, Mexico, the Netherlands, New Zealand, Romania, USSR, South Africa, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland and the United Kingdom have all introduced such legislation. Perhaps the only exception is Canada, I am not sure where it stands at present. Even New Zealand has now introduced PVR legislation. We have had 25 years of experience, knowledge and understanding of the effects and ramifications of PVR in other countries. We have not required it of ourselves, yet we indulge ourselves in repetitive debates and inquiries. The evidence is all before us. We chose first to have the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources inquire into the matter and I might point out that that report excluded cereal crops. It did so for one reason-one of the committee members could support the recommendations only if cereals were excluded because of political ramifications from his side of politics. So we excluded cereals hoping that that would at least create the foundation for the Government to proceed with legislation of some sort. However, it chose not to. Then we had Senator Hill's proposed legislation which very much reflected the report. He put forward a Bill which so far has not had the support of the Government.

I find it distressing that the delay of PVR has had serious ramifications for the rural sector. We hear ever so often from the Government that there is very little it can do in the dynamics of the world economy to assist the rural sector. Its continuing complaint is that the forces are external and therefore there is very little it can do to improve the terms of trade or reduce the cost-return ratio. Yet here is an opportunity which has been taken by other countries and which would enable the level of production to be raised very significantly. However, we have ignored it. I rather wonder now what will happen to Professor Lazenby's report. The truth of the matter is that the report was initiated in the first place only because of a dichotomy in the Government. The extreme Left was obsessed with the myths of PVR, but the sensible, moderate people in the Government understood its merits. It has continued, because of this internecine conflict within its own Party, to put off the introduction of legislation. The object of the plant breeding inquiry in the first place was so that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) could throw up another document at the mad Left and say: `Here you are; here is another independent report'. That is not the perception of the Committee. I only hope that now Mr Kerin and the Government have that independent report they will have the courage and the fortitude to press ahead with legislation. If they do care for the rural sector, for the farmers, they will press ahead with it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL AIRLINES COMMISSION AND ANSETT TRANSPORT INDUSTRIES LTD

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 30 April, on motion by Senator Sanders:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

Debate resumed from 30 April, on motion by Senator Vigor:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The interim report `Future Directions for Commercial Radio' is uncharacteristically blunt for the Department of Communications. It starts in the first chapter by quite rightly referring to the extraordinary recommendations of the Huxley report of 1961 in these words:

SPEECH.PARA: In a decision which defied logic and dogged successive Governments for the next 25 years, the Government agreed that 88-109 megahertz (MHz), the frequencies used internationally for FM Broadcasting, should be pre-empted for extra television channels in regional areas.

By allowing the short term interests of television to fashion the broadcasting system, the Menzies Government created a problem that will not be solved totally before 1998, according to the Department. The forward development unit is now examining future directions for commercial radio. Its terms of reference started out as medium and long term time frames. Now it is working to identify options for structural change which will make at least one additional commercial radio service available to communities of 200 people or more outside the mainland State capital cities. The unit is to come up with proposals that discourage any undue concentration of media ownership and control.

In the course of this work, the forward development unit has been directed by the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) to look at the feasibility of allowing commercial AM operators to convert to FM. Except for the current FM operators, the commercial radio industry has claimed that the financial results of the past couple of years show an inherent advantage for the FM mode. Their solution, on the grounds of equal competition, is to allow all operators to convert to FM if they want to. The forward development unit makes the comment that the Federation of Australian Regional Broadcasters conceded that even in regional areas FM allocation will often be dependent upon the clearance of existing television services from `band 2'. Surprisingly it does not specifically address the same question in relation to metropolitan areas. I well recall the lack of interest in FM by existing operators when I was spokesman for a group which applied for the initial commercial FM licence in Adelaide some years ago.

On the basis of average figures for a couple of years, existing operators now put the case that there is some inherent advantage in FM. At the time I was an applicant that was not at all obvious; nobody from AM wanted to convert to FM. While the forward development unit says that `the legislation's enforced lack of detailed figures on stations' operations preclude definite judgments', it is clear that not all AM operators are doing badly in comparison with FM operators. The operators who are operating talk programs are doing very well. I find it significant that FM operators have carved out for themselves a market amongst young people. They have used innovative advertising and promotional techniques and have gained exposure by simulcasting with television programs. Through this practice they have attracted new sources of revenue, as have AM talk operators. Both national and public broadcasting sectors agree with the FM operators that there is no case for giving special protective treatment to commercial broadcasters and cutting off possible future broadcasting options.

It is striking that the Department of Communications cannot fill its engineering positions. This means that expressions on interest cannot be processed. The supplementary licence scheme has not even got off the ground, and basic frequency planning is always done on the run. I think it is extremely important that the problem of undermanning of the engineering section of the Department of Communications should be solved quickly so that effective procedures can be put into effect. We could then get new and exciting broadcasting options in the public sector, instead of just fiddling around trying to give the same programs on different bands of frequencies. We have to nurture the technical excellence which will enable our system of broadcasting to provide a diverse, national, public and commercial broadcasting service to Australians. We also have to give the public sector a chance to attract talented individuals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The interim report by the Department of Communications, `Future Directions for Commercial Radio relating to FM-AM conversion', is indeed a very direct report which clearly indicates that this question is not simply one that goes back to the Huxley report in the early 1960s, but back to the Gibson report in the 1940s in terms of the allocation of space on the frequency bands of Australian airwaves. The report is a very complex one. The issue that is being addressed, the conversion of broadcasting from the AM to the FM band, is beset with a large number of very technical questions. However, there is a threshold question, and it is the only one which I have the opportunity to address in the few minutes available to me today. That is the idea that licences should be granted on the test of commercial viability.

SPEECH.PARA: At the moment, there are essentially three tests for the granting of a licence. The first is the requirement that the licensee is a fit and proper person to hold a licence-whatever that may mean. That is the subject of disputation before the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal and before the courts from time to time. The second is that the licensee has the technical capacity to broadcast. That is something that is fairly measurable and the Department of Communications has standards that allow that to be measured. The third is that the proposed operator is commercially viable. This is a matter which has been tested in a number of cases by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. Although the Tribunal has attempted to lay down some general rules, they have by and large been unsatisfactory. The basic problem is not with the rules that the Tribunal lays down but with the requirement in the Act itself that commercial viability should be a test of a licensee. The report before us rightly describes such a device as conservative and protectionist.

What we ought to be looking at in terms of the long term future of broadcasting developments is that, provided a licensee can demonstrate that he has the technical competence to broadcast and provided that he is a fit and proper person to hold a licence to broadcast to the public, the decision as to whether he applies for and is granted a licence, and subsequently a renewal of the licence, should be entirely his own decision. He should be prepared to take the commercial risk. It may well be that a company which gets a licence is not, on the tests laid down by the Tribunal in the first instance, commercially viable. If that is the case the licensee will fail. He will go broke. The only thing that can be said about that is that the loss, such as it is, is the loss incurred by the licensee and his shareholders only. It is not a loss to the public if a particular radio station fails. It is not as if the listeners do not have other choices. It is not as if somebody will not come along and apply for the licence of the operator who has failed or occupy the spot on the broadcast spectrum when it becomes available. It is an absolute nonsense that now, when we have a whole system of deregulation of communications and broadcasting, when an extraordinary variety of new mechanisms are available for people to get involved in broadcasting, when we have new techniques, technologies and possibilities in the broadcasting system, we should narrow, by the test of commercial viability-a protectionist and conservative device-the entry of entrepreneurs, especially new ones, into radio broadcasting.

In the review of the Act which the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) has under way at the moment, one of the criteria that ought to be removed as a test for licensees, particularly for licensees in the radio spectrum, is commercial viability. The market ought to be allowed to operate and, if people go broke in the market, so be it. They go broke. There is nothing unusual about that. It happens in all sorts of markets. There is no reason it should not happen in the broadcasting market.

We now have reports from the Department, the Forward Development Unit, the Broadcasting Tribunal, the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations, the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters, the FM Applicants for Independent Radio and everybody else which have built up into an absolute log jam because the Government has been unable to make certain very key policy decisions about the Act which I hope it will be able to make in the not too distant future.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate notes-
(a) the continuing uncertainty in the community caused by the failure of the Federal Government to introduce into the Parliament proposed taxation legislation affecting the following matters:
Date of
