ment
Resource Rent Tax...
Discounted and deferred interest securities (DINGO bonds, etc.)...
Interest Withholding Tax on discounts and Hire Purchase charges...
Non-cash business related benefits given to non-employees...
Income averaging for sports persons...
150 per cent deduction for research and development expenditure...
Fringe benefits tax...
Capital gains tax...
Imputation system of taxing company distributions...
Foreign tax credit system...
Provisional tax to be payable in instalments...

(b) that the effects on incentive and industry of the proposed legislation on fringe benefits tax and capital gains tax will be devastating and will detrimentally affect the course of the Australian economy.

The motion we are addressing is in two parts. The first part draws attention to the Government's failure to produce legislation within a reasonable time in respect of announced tax measures that go back as far as 18 April 1984-in fact, more than two years ago. Listed in the motion are a number of issues which have not been dealt with by the Government in the form of legislation. A number of other matters that as yet have failed to come before the Senate are of a lesser nature and are so numerous as to not be worthy of being included in the motion. The second part of the motion speaks of the effects of various tax changes, regarding some of which legislation is still pending. In respect of others, legislation has been, and is being, dealt with by the Parliament. Some of these measures were the subject of the Government's tax statement in about September last year. Many of these changes will have devastating effects upon the economy of Australia and, in particular, upon the welfare of every Australian. I will demonstrate that as we come to argue about particular tax laws.

Let me turn to my first point. Some tax measures were announced on behalf of this Government by the Treasurer, Mr Keating, more than two years ago. They were announced as being good law in terms of the Government's intention to legislate but the announcement contained very scant detail as to the way they will affect taxpayers. I emphasise that point because it is a fundamental principle of all law that people ought to know the exact terms of the law. Certainty in the law is an absolutely fundamental criterion of our democracy. It is no more important than in the area of taxation. The Government imposes a tax upon the people and then fails to tell us in what way the tax will be levied and how it will be assessed. We are not told the details so that we can gain an impression of how it will affect us.

Let us consider some of the laws that are outstanding. As I mentioned earlier, the rent resource tax was announced on 18 April 1984, more than two years ago. On 16 December 1984, discounted and deferred interest securities, known as `dingo bonds', were announced. It is interesting to note that in that case the measure was announced and then immediately withdrawn by the Treasurer because he found that he had got it wrong anyway. We have never heard of it since then. The interest withholding tax on discounts and hire purchase charges was announced on 14 December 1984. We have never seen any legislation on the matter since then. Yet business has had to cope with the problem of uncertainty in the area since then.

On 4 February 1985 the Government announced that non-cash business related benefits given to non-employees were to be subject to tax. Again, this a most sensitive area, particularly in the light of the new fringe benefits tax, yet we hear nothing from the Government on that issue. No law has been introduced into the Parliament since that measure was announced more than 15 months ago. On the same day we heard an announcement that income averaging for sports persons would be introduced. But, again, no legislation has been presented and sportsmen and sportswomen are still in the position of not knowing how the law will affect them. Later, in May 1985, 11 months ago, there was an announcement, with great fanfare, of the 150 per cent deduction for research and development expenditure for industry. This measure was supposed to be one of the centrepieces of the Government's plan for the rejuvenation of secondary industry. Yet business has had no clue whatsoever as to the detail of that law as no legislation has been introduced into the Parliament setting out the exact terms and conditions by which businesses could plan their affairs. This area is of particular sensitivity and interest to the community now because there is so much talk about high technology industry being the way of the future to employ more and more Australians. We hear this continually, not only from the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, but also from his counterpart in the House of Representatives, Mr Barry Jones, who, as we all know, is the Minister for the Future, better known as the Minister for Science.

TALK.START.PARA: —And living by his wits.

—And living by his wits. He certainly needs a light bulb or two to help him along. This is a rather important point to make. We are talking about industries which, according to this Government's claim, hold the solution to our economic woes in the market-place. Yet legislation which goes to the core of decision-making in this area has not been introduced into the Parliament. We have to wait on the lips of the Treasurer in order to find out how we can get on with the job. Eleven months have transpired since the Government's announcements, and there has been no action.

SPEECH.PARA: The iniquitous fringe benefits tax was announced on 19 September last year. We still have not seen the legislation for that tax. We keep reading in the newspapers that it is coming this week, tomorrow, some time, whenever. It is obvious that the Caucus is having enormous problems in dealing with the tax. I hope that it is. Perhaps there is a chance that we will never see the legislation. All we want to know at this stage is whether or not it is coming. Let the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) give us some indication so that industry can get on with planning. It is interesting to note that Senator Grimes is acknowledging apparently that the tax is still coming. He has not given us any clue on the form of it. According to media reports, it will be substantially different from what was announced.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—It will not be substantially different. This is the way that we have to operate under this Government to find out what is happening with legislation. We get winks and nods across the chamber from Ministers who fail to bring in the legislation that sets down the details of a fringe benefits tax which will impact so heavily on Australian industry. We need legislation, and so does industry, to learn how it will be affected so it can get on with its planning for the future and developing job opportunities for Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: Here comes the iniquitous capital gains tax. It was announced on 19 September 1985. Of course, we have heard nothing about it since then. We know no details except for a rudimentary statement put out about two months ago by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) which sets down some of the details concerning personal use items and one or two other matters-but nothing of substance. We need legislation so that we can plan and get on with the job. Nothing will have more effect upon incentives for Australians to develop job opportunities for other Australians than will a capital gains tax. Surely that is a feature to which the Government should give priority. Eight months into the financial year we are unable to find out exactly what this legislation will tax. The tax has been applied since 19 September, yet we do not know in detail precisely what will be subject to tax, how much tax we will have to pay and how the mechanisms for calculating the value of an asset which will be taken into account when assessing the tax will be used. Consequently Australian people and the business community are in the dark.

The imputation system of taxing dividends for companies again was announced on 19 September. There is still no legislation, no statement about all the airy details that attach to that idea. We support the general principle of the non-taxation doubly of dividends of companies. Consequently we are looking very anxiously to the introduction of detailed legislation on the imputation system so that we can get some idea whether it will work effectively. We have heard nothing from the Government since September last year. Although it will not affect companies until the 1988 financial year, details need to be known now so that companies can plan for the future and develop their projects and budgets for those projects for the years ahead rather than having to wait to see what transpires in legislation which may or may not come. Because it will be some time before any legislation has effect, people will be waiting for two, three years or more before they finally see legislation on the imputation of company distributions. It is just not good enough if companies are to plan projects for the future.

Related to this is the matter of the foreign tax credit system which is also of very great concern to the Liberal Party and the National Party. Unless it is substantially changed from what was announced on 19 September, we will oppose it along with the other legislation when it comes to the Senate. The point has to be made now that we still have no legislation and have had from the Government since the 19 September statement no statements on how this would work, which would give us any indication of how it would impact on people.

We have to recognise that businesses and companies located and based in Australia have international aspirations. Indeed, this Government opened the foreign exchange markets in 1984 to allow companies to deal more effectively on international markets. When this Government announces a measure such as the foreign tax credit system, does it not understand what impact this will have on the mentality of companies, their managers and directors who are thinking about extending their operations overseas? Surely this must. Yet the Government delays in bringing in legislation which would allow people to have a clear idea on how to plan and develop strategies for investment overseas.

The last item in the motion concerns the introduction of a new system of provisional tax. Whereas in the past provisional tax has been paid on an annual basis, it is now proposed that it be paid on a quarterly basis. We have had no legislation for this either. One would have thought that it would be a relatively simple matter to introduce. We have to assume that the Government is having second thoughts or is developing alternative ideas and provisions. Perhaps the Government will not go ahead with that proposal, as it has not gone ahead with the quarantining of farm losses. At least it should take us into its confidence and produce legislation so that industry can plan ahead and individual taxpayers who are farmers, small businessmen and professional people, can understand exactly where they stand and can develop financial strategies for the future.

I turn now to the second part of the motion which concerns the effects of the legislation on incentive and industry. The point about the various new taxes which have been announced recently is that they will have a quite devastating effect on industry and incentive. Not least is the fringe benefits tax. It has been the subject of debate in the Senate on a number of occasions, the latest being yesterday. We heard my leader, Senator Chaney, introduce a matter of urgency on the effect on the car industry of the fringe benefits tax. As is already being indicated by statistics emerging from official sources, this tax will have a devastating impact upon the Australian motor vehicle industry. In the first three months of this year we have seen a decline in the sales of motor vehicles of some 25 per cent. Those figures are on record as of the last few days. It is clear that there could well be a fall in the total market of locally produced vehicles of 90,000 or more in this calendar year.

Jobs are at stake in towns such as Bendigo, Ballarat, Launceston and certainly in my home town of Adelaide. South Australia is heavily dependent on the motor vehicle industry. Because Adelaide is the home of Mitsubishi Motors Australia Ltd and General Motors-Holden's Ltd, there will be a great deal of concern by Adelaide people on future job opportunities as a result of this predicted fall in motor vehicle sales.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about your predicted effect on the restaurant industry? Will you tell us about that?
—Perhaps we should talk about it. I do not know how long it is since the Minister has checked with restaurants around Australia.
—I cannot get in. They are all booked out.
—They won't let you in.

—That is the point. The Minister cannot get a feed anywhere. But the restaurants are suffering badly in terms of jobs. They are closing down in large proportions. This will gather pace as time goes on.
—Are you going to get around to that?

—If the Minister wants to argue, let us turn to the matter of the motor vehicle industry. The Minister does not have to believe what I am saying; he can hear it from the industry. He can believe his statistics which are produced every month. Sales have fallen by about 25 per cent in the first three months of this year.
—All due to a tax that is not even on yet.
—All right, I will argue with the Minister about the restaurant industry.
—No, tell us about the car industry.
—The Minister was talking about my predictions. I take his point. However, we have positive proof and evidence that indeed the motor vehicle market is collapsing.
—The tax is not even on yet.
—The impact of the tax is affecting it very greatly.
—Before it is even there?

—Yes, before it is actually imposed, because it is affecting expectation of future costs-as the Minister, and only the Minister, could understand-from 1 July 1986. The tax is not imposed at the time the car is purchased. The tax is imposed as an on-running thing on the employer as the vehicle is used in the business. The point of purchase has nothing to do with it. It is the future use of the vehicle that has everything to do with it. Let us ignore that question. The prediction of the industry itself and, I might say, of the trade union movement and, indeed, of the South Australian Premier Mr Bannon, is that 10,000 jobs will be lost in the motor vehicle industry. Honourable senators opposite do not have to believe me; they can believe the Labor Premier of South Australia, and believe Senator Foreman's union, the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation of Australia.
—They are not opposing the tax.
—They are not opposing?
—They are saying: `Phase it in'.

—Let us just consider whether Senator Grimes can be believed on this matter. I read in the Adelaide News of last night that Senator Foreman supports the tax package, but that the former vehicle builders union secretary opposes the structure of the legislation. Apparently, that is exactly the position of so many honourable senators opposite, particularly those from South Australia. I think that Senator Bolkus has a similar view, and I think that Mr Bilney, the honourable member for Kingston, has a similar view. Their views are reported quite clearly in the Adelaide News of last night. It is interesting to note, for the benefit of Senator Grimes, that none of those people is taking part in this debate today. We would like to encourage them to show how much they oppose this tax. I ask them to walk with us to the other side of the chamber to defeat this legislation if and when it comes forward so that we can give justice to South Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us refer to what some others from the South Australian branch of the Australian Labor Party have to say about this subject. Mr Mick Young, the Special Minister of State, is a prominent and well-known politician in South Australia. Of course, in his clever way he says that the Button car plan has been a success. Of course, he then says that the industry is about to collapse because of the effect of the car tax. Mr Hurford, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, also from South Australia, supported this issue in Cabinet. Apparently, he did not stand up at the right time in support of his State, which will suffer so heavily from the imposition of the fringe benefits tax.

Again, the Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, another prominent South Australian Labor politician, missed the special meeting of his own Caucus called to have this matter discussed. Would honourable senators believe that he missed his own special Caucus meeting! He is a Minister from South Australia. He represents the seat of Bonython, which, of course, covers the largest motor vehicle manufacturing complex in all of Australia at Elizabeth-and he missed the special meeting being held to discuss the car industry! Really, words fail me. This is the way the Labor Party is dealing with this matter. Surely we have to come to some common sense in regard to this point. The clear message is that jobs will be lost in the car industry if this tax is not changed.

The Liberal Party, together with the National Party, will be opposing the legislation when it is introduced. Therefore, we rely on the Australian Democrats. Some of them are South Australians as well. Some of them are Victorians, and Victorians very heavily depend on the motor vehicle industry. If the Democrats fail us-they have already indicated they will because they are going to support the Minister-we really will need the back bench members of the Labor Party to show their strength by coming over to join us on this side of the Senate in order to defeat the legislation. In particular, we ask Senator Foreman to organise a caucus of back bench dissidents to come forward to join with the Liberal and National parties to do the right thing for South Australia. Let us turn to the capital gains tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the restaurant industry? You told us that you were going to tell us about the restaurant industry.

—I explained that to the Minister. I explained that the Minister did not have to believe me at all but that in this case he had plenty of other information to rely on to confirm what I said. As we know, the capital gains tax will have a devastating effect not only on the farming community but particularly on the small business community. I think of the people who run the corner delicatessens, the people who have established the small retail businesses, who buy into a business, pay for the goodwill, pay for the stock and for the plant, and then find, when they come to sell their businesses, that the goodwill value of their business, which has been developed by the sweat of their brows, will be subject to a tax which will treat the profits from the sale of their business not as a capital item but as though it were exactly the same as income. The whole benefit that would have been built up over, say, a 20-year period, during which time a businessman would have built up the goodwill of his business, will be taxed. The businessman will find that the entire capital amount which he receives on the sale of his business will be taxed in one year at the marginal rate of income tax. I think it is absolutely deplorable. It is disgusting. It is outrageous that this kind of attack on the businessmen of Australia should be instituted.

SPEECH.PARA: Everybody knows that one cannot apply to goodwill the principle of indexation that the Government has included in its capital gains tax. Of course, every dollar of goodwill, whether it represents inflation or not, is going to be taxed, although the Government has seen some sense and has applied the principle of indexation to some other assets to take account of inflation. It is the small businessman, the average, little person in the community who wants to strive to get ahead and develop his own business, who will be socked right over the fence by this form of capital gains tax. I really cannot understand what this Labor Party is all about. However, when we consider the tax that it introduced on lump sum superannuation and the introduction of the assets test on pensioners, I suppose then we must appreciate that it has absolutely no regard for individual Australians and it thinks in some theoretical manner about the way that taxes impact on people.

Let us turn to the negative gearing legislation. This has been introduced in the Parliament and is to be discussed in the House of Representatives next week. This legislation is intended to abolish the opportunities for small individuals to be able to put aside money from their incomes into small developments such as home units, or whatever, that can provide them with some capital in retirement, thus allowing them to develop a capital nest-egg for that purpose. Again, this is very much related to the concept of the capital gains tax and it destroys individual incentive in this country. That will happen, although it has taken a long time, nearly a year, to get the legislation on that matter from the Government. Of course, we are still to debate that legislation in the Parliament. The Liberal and National parties oppose that legislation. We will be opposing it in the Senate when it comes before us. The other area of concern to which I would like to draw attention is that of the quarantining of farm losses. Of course, this has been a great bone of contention in country areas in the last few months since it was announced on 19 September this financial year. The truth of the matter is that the Government did not have a clue what it was doing when it introduced that idea. It made the legislation so narrow that farmers who might be contemplating, for example, growing wool and, at the same time, having a wheat property, and using farm machinery such as grain harvesters, and who think that they could earn extra income by contracting out the grain harvesters, will find that they cannot offset losses on the wool growing side, for instance, against income earned from farm machinery.

It is absolutely absurd that the Government should be locked into that kind of thinking. But at last commonsense has prevailed and apparently that proposal has been dropped as part of Mr Kerin's farm package which was announced a couple of weeks ago. It is interesting to note that apparently the game is not yet over because in this place about a fortnight ago Senator Walsh stood up and said: `No, quarantining has not gone'. He said that there still was going to be some quarantining of farm losses or that, alternatively, some other form of taxation would be imposed upon the farmers. Whom are we to believe-Mr Kerin or Senator Walsh? There is a major difference here which needs to be clarified and on which, of course, the Government has gone to water. We have heard absolutely nothing about this matter since it was exposed in the Senate by way of a question from Senator Chaney.

The fundamental thrust of this motion is that the people of Australia cannot go on with this continuing uncertainty about the form of taxation law. As I have pointed out, there is grave doubt about whether many of the taxation laws that are being proposed by this Government are reasonable, whether they are going to achieve the objectives that are set for them and whether they are going to produce effects contradictory to those that are being claimed. I instance again the fringe benefits tax and its effect upon the car industry. I remind the Senate that 10,000 jobs are likely to be lost in the car industry if this tax goes ahead. We have already seen the motor car industry decline as a result of the fringe benefits tax and other measures. I urge all senators from the Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia to support this motion. I implore back bench senators from the Australian Labor Party to join us and to show, as many of them have been claiming in newspapers back home in South Australia, that they oppose the fringe benefits tax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard a half hour of diatribe on taxation from Senator Messner, who I understand is the Opposition spokesman on tax. Two words were conspicuously absent from that diatribe. Senator Messner never at any point addressed the question of equity; he never at any point addressed the question of fairness. As long as the members of the Liberal Party of Australia come forward in the debate on tax and refuse to deal with the fundamental question with which anyone, or particularly any government, has to deal in terms of equity and fairness in the taxation system of the country, the Liberal Party has absolutely no standing in debate, publicly or in this Parliament, on that matter. A fundamental principle of taxation is that all those who pay tax should feel that all the other taxpayers are meeting their fair and equitable obligation. We do not ever hear from the Liberal Party about what is fair and what is equitable or what is a reasonable obligation. I will come in a moment to the record of the Liberal Party, which seems to have a collective amnesia of the events that applied in this country before 1983 in respect of taxation. As long as it does not deal with equity and fairness, it does not have any standing in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: What about the ordinary wage and salary earners whose full incomes are subject to pay as you earn taxation? What about their standing in this debate when they see massive avoidance, tax dodges and rip-offs being perpetrated by those who sit in a position of some privilege and who are able to fiddle their incomes in order to avoid paying tax? Who speaks for them in the Liberal Party? We have never heard anyone from the Liberal Party speak for them. We hear people speak as if that situation were reasonable, ordinary wage and salary earners should pay more and people in positions of privilege should be able to fiddle their income, avoid tax, pay less and dodge their fair share.

Any government has to be fundamentally concerned about protecting its revenue base. The fundamental principle that should be observed in protecting that revenue base is that of fairness and equity. Everyone should be able to know that everyone else is being treated fairly.

With those opening remarks, let me turn to the quite extraordinary motion before the Senate. The motion talks about the continuing uncertainty caused by the failure of the Government to introduce proposed tax legislation. The only people who are continually concerned about that seem to be Senator Messner and his cronies in the Liberal Party who speak out on this matter. All they have to do is just wait. They will not have to wait very long because the legislation is in the pipeline and it will be introduced shortly.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a long pipeline.

—It will be here shortly. Opposition senators can then debate the real effects of the Government's proposal rather than engaging in scaremongering tactics by talking about illusory effects and trying to misrepresent in the popular electorate the Government's tax proposals. That is the Opposition's tactic. Honourable senators opposite are doom-mongers; they are scaremongers. They are trying to pretend that things that will not happen will happen. All they need to do is to sit back and wait to debate the real issues and not the illusions. My advice to Opposition senators in regard to the first part of the motion is to stop talking about the illusion. They should start talking about facts instead of resorting to hyperbole and rhetoric. They should deal with responsible legislation responsibly. Maybe it is not possible to deal with responsible legislation responsibly in the Liberal Party, having in mind that Party's record on taxation.

SPEECH.PARA: The second part of the motion suggests that all the subjects that are listed in the motion under the heading `subject' are approved of. The only taxes which are singled out in the Opposition's motion as having had some alleged devastating effect are the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax. I take it, therefore, that if they are the only two that are identified as having some deleterious effect, all the other forms of tax have been approved.

TALK.START.PARA: —What sort of logic is that?

—The Opposition has identified only two out of a list-I have not counted them-of about 12 or 14. So I assume that the ones that have not been identified are approved. I will wait to see whether members of the Opposition are consistent on that point.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a pick and choose motion. The Opposition seems to have less than a schoolboy's understanding of economics. It seems to believe that it is possible for a government to provide comprehensive tax cuts while at the same time destroying its own revenue base. Anyone with a smattering of understanding knows that it is necessary to have income in order to have outgoings. If one does not have the income, one cannot make the tax cuts that one would like to make. I understand that the Opposition supports the tax cuts that we are going to make this year and next year. However, it opposes the revenue raising measures that we are proposing in order to make those cuts possible. The Opposition also opposes equity in the system.

Let me go to the enormous hide that the Opposition is demonstrating in bringing anything remotely concerned with taxation before this Parliament. I think it is true to say in this debate that the Opposition's hide is as thick as its head on this subject. The electors understand that the Liberal Party's record on taxation constitutes, and has constituted, a national scandal. For five years the Opposition supported the most blatant tax scandal in modern history. Let me just run through a few of the check points on that list. We all recall that before 1983-and I might say that that is the period to which the collective amnesia of those opposite applies-the Western Australian Liberal Party finance committee was constituted by tax avoiders. We all remember the call-girl service which worked out of the Attorney-General's Department under a tax scam in Western Australia. We all remember the problems created by the bottom of the harbour tax avoidance techniques and other massive tax avoidance schemes. We remember the findings of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union in regard to tax avoidance which opened up this issue. We remember the McCabe-Lafranchi report. We remember all of those things. Honourable senators opposite sat in government while our tax base was haemorrhaging and massive avoidance and evasion were taking place. They virtually blinked at these things and did nothing. That is their record.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us what you have done.

—I will tell the honourable senator what we have done; I will tell him what we are about to do. As I counselled Senator Messner a little earlier, if he shows a little patience he will learn. The former Government allowed the taxation administration of this nation to run down. It imposed mindless staff ceilings on the Australian Taxation Office which led to inefficiencies. Revenue went begging because key officers could not be appointed to collect it. The previous Government did nothing to address the basic failings in the system. It watched the base haemorrhage. It watched massive avoidance take place by way of benefits in kind rather than in cash. These benefits in the form of income went untaxed. The former Government repeatedly broke tax promises. I remind honourable senators opposite of the promise that the Fraser Government made to index taxation. That was never done. I remind them of the infamous election campaign in 1977-the fistful of dollars campaign which, once they were elected, they repudiated. That is part of their record. It is certainly not an exhaustive list; it is just enough to bring us back to remembering what it was like during the period of their amnesia. In contrast this Government has instituted a vigorous policy of closing tax loopholes and gaps in such areas as superannuation lump sums, income splitting, the abuse of unit trusts, leverage leasing, the prescribed payments system, sales tax avoidance schemes and many more.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1983 and 1984 we consistently introduced legislation in this Parliament and we sought from the Opposition the recognition of a fundamental principle of any government in dealing with tax avoidance and evasion; that is that as soon as a tax scam is properly identified, there ought then to be retrospective legislation to stamp it out. That means that any tax avoider knows that as soon as his little scheme is uncovered the ill-gotten gains that he has achieved by engaging in that scheme will be taken from him and equity will prevail. Opposition senators have constantly voted down that principle. It is fundamental to be able to control avoidance and evasion and it is a fundamental assurance to all those who do the right thing that those who do the wrong thing will be caught and made to pay. We have re-invigorated tax administration; we have made additions to the resources, as well as a massive overhaul of penalty and compliance provisions. The Government has now instituted the most substantial overhaul of the tax system, the most comprehensive tax reform seen since income tax was established.

Last year was the year of tax reform. In this country there was the most massive public participation in debate on what was fair and equitable in taxation that any country has seen, culminating in the summit and in government decisions to move. Apart from the special pleadings of single interest groups, there is substantial, popular support for the Government's measures which I remind the Opposition-Senator Vanstone is nodding her head as if she disapproves-are based on the concept of equity, simplicity and efficiency. We have embarked upon tax reform which involves the closing of loopholes in capital gains, fringe benefits and tax sheltering areas; the largest tax cuts in Australian history of $41 billion to $42 billion with a maximum rate of 49 per cent being introduced into the scales; and the introduction of an imputation system for dividends, the most substantial change in corporate tax history, implementing the principles of equity, efficiency and simplicity. That is our record of achievement, compared to the previous Government's dismal performance.

I would have thought that the Liberal Party of Australia would have learned something, but it has not. What have we seen as the constructive, alternative policy from the Opposition? We have seen dithering, confusion, and frustration within its own party ranks as to what it should do, a lack of leadership and total indecision. There is nothing comprehensive, cohesive or understandable emanating from Opposition ranks as an alternative. It has chosen to pick off aspects of our total package which includes things that, in some aspects, disadvantage one group or another group, but which are fundamentally based on those rock solid principles of equity, efficiency and simplicity that I have talked about. What have we seen from the Opposition? Nothing that is at all convincing or at all comprehensive.

The White Paper we produced last year on tax reform showed that the Government was losing $700m a year in the form of income that ought to have been paid on benefits paid to employees, such as motor vehicles for private use, free lunches, free school fees and free housing. This involved only some employees, those in the upper echelons of the corporate structure, certainly not those covered by awards and agreements of the various arbitral authorities or those who substantially pay all their income in pay as you earn taxes. But there was that avoidance technique, haemorrhaging the tax base at $700m a year and that haemorrhaging was growing at a rate of 25 per cent per annum. That is the lost revenue that this Government was able to identify from its study and it is the lost revenue that ought to be available so that the equity questions can be addressed.

We are trying to address that matter. We have had from the Opposition the doomsaying, scaremongering tactics that have become all too frequently the case in this place. Let me go to just a couple of them: In December 1985 Senator Messner, in talking about business lunch free benefits, predicted that 11,000 jobs would be lost in the hospitality industry. That was Senator Messner's prediction last year. He predicted today that 10,000 jobs will be lost in the vehicle industry. At the same time last year Senator Knowles predicted that 10,500 jobs would be lost in the hospitality industry. Senator Boswell got a bit more loquacious. He said:

. . . I believe it will be around February or March-there will be a massive fall in the industry. Jobs in the industry will be lost . . . the hospitality industry is the largest employer of youth in Australia. It also provides many jobs for youths . . .

He did not quantify it, he just asserted it. Senator Michael Baume asserted that it would destroy the hospitality industry, and so on. That is the Opposition's prediction. Let us go to the record and see whether those predictions were justified because if they were not we can look at predictions those opposite are making now in the light of what the evidence was then and see how reliable they are as forecasters. The Commonwealth Employment Service job notifications index in the restaurant and hospitality industry has shown 4.1 per cent growth since the Government announced the fringe benefits tax. Just taking the narrower focus on hotels, restaurants and clubs, it has shown an increase of 25.6 per cent in CES vacancies-the reverse predicted by those opposite. Advertisements in major newspapers for new jobs in those industries showed that in December 1984 173 vacancies in the skilled work force were notified. In February 1986 when, according to the Opposition's predictions things should have been worse, there were 307. What we have seen is those opposite who speak for privilege trying to use dire predictions about unemployment of workers as a catspaw to knock down the tax reforms that we are introducing.

If the restaurant and hospitality industry is not sufficient, let us go to the earlier dire warnings, again with almost the same cast as the previous doomsaying movie-Senators Messner, Jessop, Hill and Teague. When we introduced a tax on wine in Australia they went into raptures about how many jobs would be lost and what the damage to the industry would be. I can go through and quote the figures. I see at least one of those senators is in the chamber. I am sure he will be honest enough when he stands up to make his contribution to this debate to say that he was wrong about those predictions at that time. The record is that the industry never performed in the way in which he alleged; in fact it has shown a growth in wine consumption rather than a diminution in wine consumption.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope you are not going to say that the industry is in good shape.

—Since the honourable senator has bothered to interject, I point out that he said that 4,000 jobs will be lost in South Australia, that South Australian wine growers will lose $15m in income and that the Riverland growers will lose $5m in income. That has not been the performance. When the honourable senator rises to speak in this debate I expect he will say that he is wrong. But the point is that the doomsayers' record of reliability in predictions is abysmally wrong. That is their record and one should approach the predictions they make in this debate on fringe benefits tax accordingly.

SPEECH.PARA: I will now deal with the motor vehicle industry. As I have said, the Government is introducing a fringe benefits tax because the tax system has been increasingly subjected to evasion in this particular area. When the blatant paper schemes were closed off in the early 1980s high income taxpayers increasingly turned to fringe benefits as a means of minimising their tax on their total remuneration. At the same time, the Opposition dishonestly supports tax cuts provided by the Government to honest taxpaying people. It supports the tax cuts, but it opposes the measures required to finance them. As a result, it has no credibility whatsoever on taxation or on budget policy.

The motor vehicle industry is the most important component of the fringe benefits tax in revenue terms. This is because a motor vehicle is the most substantial fringe benefit that is provided in Australia. That statement goes without challenge and that is the reason why the private use of company-supplied vehicles is an asset to those who make private use of them, and the advantage people get from that private use should be taxed in some form. Companies in Australia obtain tax reductions for the cost of providing motor vehicles to their employees. That means that 46 per cent of the cost of motor vehicles is paid by the ordinary Australian taxpayer. Where those vehicles are used for business, the deduction is properly given. However, the private benefit of the vehicle should not be granted as a tax deduction. The purpose of the fringe benefits tax is to recoup the deductions provided in respect of the private use of motor vehicles, and that is a totally unambiguous and sensible proposition. If we do not do that, two classes of taxpayer are created and the equity provisions are offended against. `Equity' is a word that is not in the lexicon of honourable senators opposite.

There are two options which are never argued by the Opposition. What the fringe benefits tax will be is never argued by the Opposition, so I will now argue that. There are two options in calculating the fringe benefits tax. The first option is the log book method whereby voluntary log books and full records are kept so that the precisely correct proportion of private use can be calculated and a tax levied accordingly. No one can argue that that is unfair. The Opposition cannot argue that that is unfair. However, the Government has provided a second option which can be applied without keeping records or log books. That option levies a tax on the basis of a statutory formula based on the value of the car and the total number of kilometres travelled in a year. The Government has set the statutory formula at a very concessional level. It is simply not true that the statutory formula is an unfair burden. It is also not true that it discriminates against cars of any particular type or value. Indeed, because the tax is based proportionately on the value of a car, it is totally non-discriminatory.

Those sections of the industry arguing for a flat tax are, in fact, arguing for a deliberate discrimination in the law favouring higher cost vehicles. They are saying, for example, that a Volvo should be taxed at the same rate as a Corolla, which of course is absurd since the private benefit gained from the provision of a Volvo is obviously much greater than that from a small four-cylinder vehicle. It is clear that the statutory formula is concessional. For example, if a motor vehicle travels 15,000 kilometres in a year, the statutory formula will have the effect of still allowing a tax deduction of around 40 per cent of the cost of the vehicle. Since a vehicle which only travels 15,000 kilometres a year would generally have minimal business use, this remains a concessional rate. A car which travels only 5,000 kilometres a year, which is obviously only being used for private purposes, still would get an effective tax deduction of around 30 per cent of its costs. In other words, there can be no argument that in terms of tax principles, fairness and equity, the Government's tax measure is totally reasonable.

Of course, when tax rorts are closed off, this can have an effect on the level of sales in the relevant industry but tax rorts are not a legitimate way of assisting industries. The motor vehicle industry is presently undergoing a contraction of sales for a large number of reasons, particularly the introduction of more expensive unleaded petrol-an Opposition initiative when it was in government-the higher interest rates which emerged late last year and the demand for vehicles in 1985 because of the impending price increases due to the depreciation of the dollar. Each of these effects is likely to be temporary. Nothing the Government can do with the fringe benefits tax will stop these three effects from being felt in the industry. Over time the devaluation will assist the Australian motor vehicle industry as imports become more expensive. It is absurd to look at the tax as a means of overcoming this temporary reduction in industry sales.

As far as the tax is concerned, there has been concern that it would encourage down-sizing from Falcons to four-cylinder vehicles. However, down-sizing will also occur from expensive, largely imported vehicles into the Falcon-Commodore range. It is acknowledged by the industry that the base Falcon-Commodore is around the middle rather than the top end of the distribution of fleet vehicles. It is acknowledged that the tax must have some effect on total industry sales, but this is relatively small compared to the other temporary influences now operating in the industry. Sales increases due to the depreciation of the dollar, the stronger economy and the achievements of the Button car plan will, as the recently released Automotive Industry Authority report suggests, mean that the industry continues to enjoy a satisfactory level of activity.

That is the case in terms of the tax in the motor vehicle industry. The dire warnings, the sober predictions, the doom and gloom the Opposition has cast, have to be seen in that context. The other things that have to be said in this debate are that, to listen to what the Opposition says, one would be of the opinion, or would certainly rapidly gain the impression, that the tax is introduced, is implemented, and is having this immediate effect. Of course, it is not introduced and it is not implemented, yet the Opposition claims it is having all these dire effects. The tax is not there. Therefore if one is to remain consistent, one cannot sit back and argue that somehow all those effects are due to the tax. In what I have said, I have pointed to other causes. I think, too, that as we go to the wire on tax reform the lobbies associated with particular interests in any package of tax reform measures heighten the crescendo of their protests in order to snatch a last minute change from the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Bannon?

—That is a traditional political response to any government legislation on tax. What we are seeing now is that response. As the crescendo heightens, the exaggerations and doom-saying also heighten. The unfortunate effect is that the Liberal Party joins in and takes no responsibility for an efficient, simple and equitable tax system in Australia. As I said in my opening point, until those opposite, as a party or as an opposition, come forward and say that equity is a key consideration, the Opposition cannot expect those people who respect the tax system to meet their full measure of tax if they know that other are avoiding it. The Opposition's whole debate unfortunately comes down to the principle that it uses as a sham argument and as false proposition doom-saying allegations of massive devastation. In reality that is a blind to protect the privilege of tax avoidance from which some high income earners, because they can figure their avoidance techniques at their levels of income, benefit when most other ordinary, honest and decent Australians pay their full measure of tax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join today in discussing this motion on Government tax changes because of a concern for the ordinary Australian who is waiting to see exactly how the tax reforms of this Government are going to be implemented. The motion lists a significant number of policy initiatives of this Government yet to be introduced in legislation. The motion is particularly concerned with the detriments of the proposed fringe benefits tax and capital gains tax. We have just heard from Senator Cook. Yet again we have heard the tired old false class arguments and accusations that Senator Cook regularly comes up with. He consistently attempts to depict the Opposition as being a party of privilege, ignoring his own Party's desertion of ordinary Australians in favour of the new corporate elite of big business, big unions and government.
—And antique collectors.

—And antique collectors. Let Senator Cook look to his Government and to its protection of the rich and powerful friends of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) before he begins to point the finger. Labor can claim no monopoly on concern for equity. Senator Cook made much in his speech of the need for equity and fairness. The Government has to meet its obligation to be fair and equitable by putting its policy into practice and into legislation. Senator Cook asked who spoke for the pay as you earn wage earner. I ask: Who speaks for the small business or the big business that wants to plan? Who speaks for the PAYE person who wants to know from his employer what his salary package will be after the fringe benefits tax is implemented?

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cook makes out that the fringe benefits tax will only affect the businessman. He should tell that to the PAYE salary earner whose salary package will be substantially reconfigured. He should tell the young person with a job at Mitsubishi Motors Australia Ltd or General Motors-Holden's Ltd that this tax will not affect him. Senator Cook says that we should be concerned with equity, efficiency and simplicity. I believe that it is dishonest of him constantly to say that the Opposition is not concerned with equity. He should be acknowledging that we are concerned with equity but we may have a different view on how to achieve it. As to efficiency, I see no efficiency in a government which has had months and months and consultation after consultation and fix-it plan after fix-it plan but which still has not got the taxation legislation before the Parliament. We are eight weeks away from a new financial year. I see no simplicity for the businessman, the lawyer or the accountant who is trying to advise people on the basis of a vague policy statement rather than on the nuts and bolts of legislation. I suggest that Senator Cook ask his colleagues to consider their position with respect to equity, efficiency and simplicity before he starts to point the bone.

There is no doubt that the taxation system needs a comprehensive overhaul. I think that is generally agreed. Any government that tackles this question should be applauded by individuals and companies alike. But any such applause should be forthcoming only when that government finally delivers on its undertakings. While it might be very self-satisfying for honourable senators opposite to decry the record of previous governments, the fact remains that this Government has set the agenda for tax reform, and it will be judged on the timetable of its delivery.

Senator Cook told us, with some sort of limited application of logic, that he believes that because we complain that certain pieces of legislation have not yet been introduced we must endorse them. I believe he has been trying to say that we must be asking for such legislation. Can he not see that the Government cannot run, business cannot run and this country cannot run on the basis of public announcements? We want legislation introduced so that people have a sure base on which to act.

I characterise the essential style of this Government-the Hawke Government-as being cosmetic, muddled and incomplete. It is cosmetic because its promises have not yet been delivered. Its policy has not yet been put into practice. It is muddled because it is perfectly clear that if the Government were not in a muddle this legislation would have been introduced well before now. It is no consolation to know that it will be introduced later this week or early next week. The actions of the Government are incomplete because its program of tax reform is, quite obviously, not complete, and this is what this debate is about. I could cite other programs. The Priority One program is incomplete on delivery of the Government's promises. The youth of Australia know that only too well.

Perhaps we should turn our minds to the criteria by which we should judge a government and, in particular, a taxation system. Some people might say that the tax system should be simple to understand. They might say that it should not impose undue compliance costs on taxpayers; nor should taxes be overly expensive for the authorities to administer and collect. They seem to be reasonable statements. One might also say that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has been at pains in the past to remind us constantly of these desirable objectives for taxation reform. Yet, despite the rhetoric, there has developed a very clear contradiction between what the Treasurer has identified as a good tax system and what he has actually produced since he occupied the Treasurer's office. Those words seem perfectly reasonable. Words to that effect were spoken by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, in a debate in the House of Representatives in 1981. Those were complaints that he was making of the then Treasurer, John Howard. It is my view that the Government should take the words of Mr Willis into account at this stage.

I ask honourable senators to turn their minds to the very great burden of keeping up with legislation which is put on everyone in the community. We all know that everyone is equal before the law and is taken as knowing the law. For certain people, keeping up with the law is a constant problem, because a part of their job is to advise people on what the law is and therefore how they should plan their lives and their businesses. It is obviously important for people who might be in businesses that are not big enough to be advised regularly by top flight solicitors and accountants. Business people who have to make these decisions for themselves have to ferret their way through the Australian Government Publishing Service bookshop to keep up with the legislative program. It is even harder for these people-I am talking about the small business person who cannot afford top flight advice-to keep up with policy announcements. They are not all reported in every paper. Every small business person cannot be expected to go to the bookshop regularly to get a copy of the Commonwealth Record and read all these statements. A problem is thereby created for those people who need to use the nuts and bolts of legislation. I am not talking about whether the principles of the proposed taxation reform are right or wrong; I am saying that the people whose lives will be affected by legislation ought to know the nuts and bolts of the proposed reform so that they can apply it in their daily lives. At the moment the people who need to know the nuts and bolts do not know them.

The seriousness of this point is highlighted by the recent inclusion of professionals in section 74 of the Trade Practices Act, except, of course, engineers and architects, who have been omitted. It is very serious that, when accountants and lawyers advise small business, big business or individuals on what they should do with respect to taxation liabilities, they are being asked to do so in the dark. They do not know the details. Any accountant, lawyer or small businessman would say that the detail is important. One should ask a businessman whether he plans on a day to day basis. Even the smallest local fruit and vegetable shop cannot plan on a day to day basis. It needs to know and plan ahead. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, knows all about planning ahead. We have all heard about his magnificent car plan. Of course, car manufacturers have now heard of a change in the scenario in the form of the fringe benefits tax.

At the moment, business people who are planning for themselves, and the accountants and the lawyers, are being asked to make decisions while they are totally in the dark as to the details of the tax situation, which can bite and can bite hard. It could substantially affect their profitability and therefore the employment that they can offer. Obviously, not knowing the detail can put them in a position of not complying in some way with a tax Act. I think it is unfair and it is not equitable that those people are in this position at the moment. The Government says it is concerned with equity. Where is the equity in the situation that I have just outlined? How can it be fair for these people-accountants, lawyers and small business people-to bear the burden of chance and of guessing the detail of the Government's tax measures?

I turn specifically to the fringe benefits tax. As we get nearer to the stage of legislative reform being put into practice, we hear that the crescendo of complaints is rising, and so it is. Today the Premier of South Australia, John Bannon, said that he was angry at the Federal Cabinet's decision to go ahead without making amendments to the fringe tax proposals. He said that the decision puts in jeopardy reconstruction plans for the motor vehicle industry and would have serious consequences for employment and business in South Australia. That is my State. Let me read to the Senate the text of a Press release issued by John Bannon this morning. In addition to what I have just mentioned, he said:
I think it is a great pity that the Federal Government has not shown any flexibility in this matter.

Mr Bannon said he would come to Canberra to express his disappointment to the Prime Minister and I hope he sticks to that. He has suggested that some compromise should have been worked out and some adjustment made so that everyone would have been in a better position. Mr Bannon made a particular point when he said:
We-
he is referring here to South Australia-
will be affected proportionately more than any other State because of the type of area that is going to lose sales.
Senator Cook may like to consider these comments by the South Australian Premier and take them to heart before he points the finger at this side of the chamber.
Let us look at the last-minute nature of all this. Only yesterday-30 April-Senator Richardson said:

The first and most obvious observation which I think would be known to Senator Chaney and the Opposition, is that later on this week there will be further discussions between Senator Button, the Treasurer, Paul Keating, and the industry. Senator Button and the Treasurer wish to make it clear that the Government is still looking at this question,-
remember, this is on 30 April-
that the door is still open to change and that the Cabinet will have to consider the outcome of the deliberations between the industry and those Ministers later on this week.

If the Government does not know the details at this stage, or did not know them yesterday, how can lawyers, accountants and small business people be expected to know them? How can they advise their clients as to what they should be doing? How can small business plan ahead? We are now in the month of May-eight weeks away from a new financial year. Accountants have only eight weeks to set up systems in order to comply with the requirements of the legislation. Quite obviously they cannot do this if they do not know the details of those requirements. I am not talking about eight weeks for them to set up a system to avoid the legislation; I am talking about eight weeks to put the nuts and bolts of the paper work into place so that their clients can comply with the requirements of the legislation. As we all know, eight weeks is not a long time. While we may be eight weeks away from this imaginary deadline of the new financial year, I submit that we are already well into the time when the business community has to make some financial commitments that might affect the new financial year. Business people are already committed and they have had to do that in the dark. If the Government believes that its legislation is so fair, equitable and simple, it should be simple for it to introduce such legislation. Also, it would be fair and equitable for it to introduce that legislation.

I refer specifically to the fringe benefits tax and the effect that will have on the car industry. It is not just a question of car sales having gone down in anticipation of this tax, even though the Government says that a drop in car sales can only be expected because 1985 was such a good year. It has been said in this place that because 1985 was such a good year, we cannot expect 1986 to measure up to it. But the figures for new car registrations are down significantly. I note that in January 1985 there were 44,053 new car registrations but in January 1986 the number had fallen to 38,465. In February 1985 there were 46,589 new car registrations and that figure fell to 33,751 in February 1986. In March 1985 there were 47,164 new car registrations but in March this year the preliminary figure shows a fall to 35,804. Can we honestly say that that shortfall has happened only because 1985 was such a good year? Of course we cannot.

It is not only a question of car sales going down, but it is also a question of business needing to plan and to know the details. Let me use the example of an accountant seeking to advise a used car firm. The salesmen drive some of the used cars. They might take them home and on the way home they might take them to a potential client to inspect them. It seems that the only option for that used car dealer is to have separate books for every used car or at least separate pages of books for every used car that the salesmen drive. Records must be kept and the mileages shown will be different from one day to the next if the salesmen are taking the cars home and showing them to clients. Will the records be allowed to flow on and, if they are, how will they ever be checked?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is bureaucratic nonsense.

—Bureaucratic nonsense indeed. I submit that the plans we have heard so far to handle the use of company cars will mean a bureaucratic bonanza for people who will sit there with calculators checking figures all day. What will this accountant advise his client, the used car dealer? Suppose that this used car dealer also has an on site fuel tank which does not happen to have a meter on it. Will he have to put a meter on it? The used car salesman will fill his car up before he goes home, not only because he wants to get home but also because he wants to show the car to a potential client. These are the small nitty-gritty decisions that business needs to make. There are big decisions business people must make also and they need to know the details so that they can make decisions other than in the dark.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Messner has already made ample comments on the effect of a capital gains tax. In particular I wish to make one comment-that is, the Opposition is often painted by those opposite, not least by Senator Cook, as comprising people who are only concerned with the wealthy in the community. The effect of the capital gains tax on the goodwill earned by the small business person does not just affect the very wealthy. It affects the people who own delicatessens, fashion shops, fruit and vegetable shops and small machinery workshops. It also affects tradesmen who set up a service business-plumbers, electricians and carpenters. It affects young people who might want to open some computer software shop or sell records and music. All these people will be affected by the capital gains tax and they would all like to know the details of the Government's taxation proposals.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most of them are ordinary people.

—As Senator Parer says, the vast majority are ordinary Australians. I also wish to comment on the 150 per cent tax deduction for research and development. In the last couple of weeks there has been substantial publicity against private enterprise in this respect. Everyone has been keen to jump on the band-wagon and tell private enterprise that it is not spending enough. The Government is not assisting these people to spend more money because the legislation is not in place and therefore people who are prepared to spend money on research and development are not able to spend it in such a way that they will qualify for this tax deduction. It may be difficult to find one's way through red tape, but it is better to know the rules by which one must play the game than to be expected to play it in the dark. In conclusion, I stress that I have participated in this debate not because big business needs to know or because small business needs to know, but because all Australians need to know the details under which their tax will be assessed and because all Australians expect from this Government an equitable, fair and simple taxation system. Given the work that the Government says it has done, it should be simple for the Government to introduce such a system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to join in this debate because the Government's taxation program, both in policy and in practice, is a disgrace. In practice it is a disgrace because what we have is tax law by announcement, not by legislation. These announcements go back many months and in a number of cases the tax law will take effect from many months ago; yet we still have not seen the shape of the legislation. There is no certainty in operating a taxation system on that basis. Business and practitioners are at a loss to know how to meet the details of the requirements that they are obliged to meet because there are simply no details. I will expand on that in a few moments. In relation to policy, the taxation program is a disgrace because it has been ill conceived, without proper thought of the consequences to the economy as a whole or to individual businesses and particularly to employment growth.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to look at a number of examples. The abolition of entertainment expenses as a taxation deduction is the first of such examples. As we know, it is now law. It is a unique tax in the terms in which it has been enacted. It reflected the blinkered approach of this Government and it failure to understand how business-particularly small business-operates. There was a failure on the part of the Government even to try to understand this matter. It has severely hit the marketing programs of many small businesses, particularly service orientated businesses, such as those in areas of public relations, and those that are selling orientated, for example, those in the insurance industry. It has given such small businesses only two alternatives. The first is to change their marketing policy away from entertainment. But many clients expect entertainment in conjunction with a sale. That is not only an Australian approach to business. I remind the Senate of the attitude in Japan, where the whole of marketing is integrated with entertainment. Of course, in business and industry the Japanese are proving to be perhaps the most successful in the world. It is a pity that this Government does not take its lessons from the successful. Rather, however, its ideological blinkers are such that it sees certain sectors of the community as gaining an advantage not shared by all. Those ideological blinkers were apparent again in the speech by Senator Cook. Regrettably, in this area the Government has been inward-looking, small-minded and narrow-thinking in its approach.

The other alternative if small business is not to try to move away from entertainment in its marketing and risk loss of business and profitability, is to continue such entertainment but accept lower profits. If the deductions are not allowed, the loss of allowance will lead to lower profitability and therefore, unfortunately, to less opportunity for reinvestment and for providing employment growth. That is looking at it from the point of view of the businesses that are giving the entertainment, but those that are in the trade of entertainment, in the other half of the equation, must also be considered. They have suffered considerably as a result of this Government's policy in that area.

The second part of this Government's total tax package to which I want to refer was its intention of quarantining farm losses and the announcement that was made in relation to that. Such a proposal showed the same ideological blinkers and lack of vision. Again, there was a failure to understand the value of encouraging investment, profit and income from the non-rural sector into the agricultural sector, a sector which will require a great deal of capital in the future to survive. The days of the simple farm are over. To compete internationally, which our rural community must do, will require sophisticated business practices, capital intensive equipment, expensive marketing research, and expensive consumables such as fertilisers, insecticides, herbicides, et cetera. But this Government, unfortunately, could not see that. Again, with the ideological blinkers of which I have spoken, all it could see was a belief that one sector of the community was being benefited in some unfair way and was getting an advantage over another.

To some extent, stunned by the intensity of the farmers' protests, the Government has backed down in that area, at least in part-although as we are told by Senator Walsh and as we read in the Government's reports, the Government still intends not to allow what it describes as Pitt Street farmers a deduction for the investments that they might make in the rural community. We on this side suggest that, instead of adopting that attitude, what the Government ought to be doing is encouraging investment by the so-called Pitt Street farmers in agriculture in the future, because it will be critical to its future prosperity.

The common element of the two disastrous tax policies that I have mentioned so far is that if the Income Tax Assessment Act had been properly enforced-which, of course, requires a certain will of the Commissioner of Taxation and a certain will of government-the provisions within the Act would be adequate to counter the abuses which the Government claims it has been addressing. Entertainment expenditure that is not incurred in the course of earning taxable income has never been deductible under the old law. I concede that it takes a bit of effort to properly enforce the law. It takes a certain amount of effort on the part of the Commissioner and the Government. But it could be done without any change in the law. Similarly, it is only on-farm expenditure, which is expenditure with a view to earning farm income, which is tax deductible. Many attempts to offset profit from another industry into the rural community have been rejected. Those attempts have been rejected when the Commissioner and the courts have been satisfied that they have not been properly invested in the rural community for the purposes of earning a rural income. What that means, in effect, is that in the case of the quarantining of farm losses, again, further legislation was not necessary if the purpose of the Government was to end abuse, because there are, and always have been, adequate provisions under the existing tax law.

I have dealt with the two areas of the Government's tax package that I have mentioned so far, but this becomes relevant because the same position exists in relation to the third of the Government's disastrous tax policies with which I wish to deal this afternoon, and that is the fringe benefits tax. The Government says: `Here we find examples of abuse. Certain taxpayers are getting tax free advantages. Therefore, we need a new law'. That is not so. People are getting tax free advantages only because the current law is not being enforced, and has not been properly enforced by the Commissioner for a long period.

It is settled law. I remind the Senate of section 26 (e) of the Act. A benefit of this type-I specifically make reference to the word `benefit' because I take it from that section-for example, the provision of a car, is taxable as income to the extent that it is not being used for a person's business needs. That is not in dispute. So personal benefit or personal use of a car is already taxable and always has been. But it is too much trouble for the Commissioner, it seems, and it is too much trouble for this Government to enforce the existing provisions of the Act. Again, the Government says that we need new taxation law. As a matter of taxation law, that is simply not so.

I am sick and tired, as are others on this side, of being told that new tax law is necessary when adequate provisions are already existent under the Act. It does not apply only in relation to the three areas that I have mentioned today. We have seen this time and again in recent years in relation to the anti-avoidance provisions. Whenever there has been a problem we have been told, and continually told, that the existing law is inadequate and that new law is necessary. In many cases that is simply not so. It simply covers up the failure of the Commissioner and of the Government-I am referring not only to the Labor Government in this instance but also to the previous Government of my colour-to make the effort to exhaust the existing remedies. I have said that here, and you know, Madam Acting Deputy President, that Mr Gyles QC, when he was acting as a special prosecutor in this area, was publicly saying it, and we are seeing more and more examples of where the existing law would have been adequate if only it had been properly utilised and properly exhausted, without running to the unnecessary alternative of further legislation.

There is an additional purpose for these so-called new taxes, that is, to raise extra revenue under the guise of simply countering tax abuse. It has been the case with entertainment expenses, it was to be the case with the offsetting of farm income and it is intended to be the case in relation to the fringe benefits tax. We do not know for certain the extent of the tax. I remind honourable senators of the advice we have recently received from the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries, which has calculated that the proposal in its current form has the potential to raise some $570m at existing prices. That is as against the Government's anticipated figure put to us of $350m. In other words, according to the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries, whose opinion should not be dismissed lightly, the Government will receive income from the taxpayer in excess of $200m beyond that which it has claimed is the case. That is the other purpose of this legislation. It is not simply to counter abuse but to impose new and additional taxes, taxes which unfortunately will reduce business profitability and which were introduced by a Government without the vision which is necessary to appreciate the effects such taxes will have on profitability, business opportunity and employment growth.

What will be the economic consequences of the Government's shortsighted policy in relation to the third of the taxes I have been referring to-the fringe benefits tax? Unfortunately we are already seeing the consequences in the response of the public in anticipation of the introduction of this tax. I simply remind the Senate of the figures which were released yesterday when we were greeted with headlines such as `Car industry stalls to a 12-year low' which I take from yesterday's Australian. The article states:
The motor industry has recorded its worst March sales in 12 years, registrations falling almost 33 per cent from last year's record levels.

What have we seen in response? As I understand it, in giving the matter some consideration today the Government has simply decided to reaffirm its position. As a South Australian, I obviously plead for the future of the automotive industry within my State, which will be affected more than anywhere else in Australia. It has been fascinating to see State Labor Premier Bannon's political gyrations on this issue. It is worth while reminding the Senate of the attitude of Premier Bannon last year when he went before the Government's National Taxation Summit and said:
Measures need to be taken to bring fringe benefits within the tax net . . . The single most important untaxed benefit is probably the provision of motor vehicles.

That was the attitude of the Premier of South Australia at last year's Taxation Summit, advocating a taxation policy of this kind. What is his current position? Today there was an announcement by the Premier, under his letterhead and in his position as Chairman of the South Australian Manufacturing Advisory Council, in the following terms:
. . . after careful consideration it--
being the South Australian Manufacturing Advisory Council which he heads-
believed the employment consequences of the proposed tax in the long-term would far outweigh the short-term revenue gains.

That is why I speak of the Premier's most interesting gyrations. Again this Government, blinded in the way it is, is not even prepared to look to the advice of its State Premiers as to consequences of what it is doing, but rather is determined to continue however much the industry and employment in the industry suffer. This Government in its decision is not serving my State well and neither has Premier Bannon.

As a member of the Federal Parliament I could not think of any more inflationary way in which to impose this tax, with its unique notion of being imposed upon employers. What will happen is that quite clearly employers will attempt to pass it onto consumers in all possible cases. What will be the effect of that? Clearly there will be a significant rise in inflation. I remind the Senate that we are adding to an inflation rate which is already more than double that of our trading partners. I would have thought that any Government with a reasonable reason would have seen that this measure would severely worsen Australia's inflation and its ability to complete internationally. But not this Government. It seems completely unable or unwilling to see the light.

I come back to where I started, that is, this Government's practice of imposing so much of its taxation law by the method of announcement rather than by legislation. I accept, and obviously we on this side of the chamber accept, that in certain circumstances it is necessary to date taxation law changes from the date of announcement. But what must be implied in accepting such a methodology is that the legislation will be introduced expeditiously. However, under this Government that is simply not occurring. Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a schedule of this Government's taxation announcements including a brief summary of what they relate to and the dates from which they are to operate.
Leave granted.
