TALK.START.PARA: —A glance at this schedule indicates tax after tax which has been announced-these announcements go back to 14 December 1984-and which not only has not received legislative form but also is already operating. For example, going down the right hand side of my schedule, the first measure was operative from 14 December 1984, the second from 16 December 1984, the third from 4 February 1985 and the fourth measure-research and development expenditure concessions which were announced in May 1985-from 1 July 1985. I could continue but I will not because the schedule has been incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: One measure, the research and development expenditure concessions, has been effective for almost a year, yet we still have not seen the colour of the legislation. Obviously businesses and those who seek to gain the benefit of the measure have to operate pursuant to this measure. How can they reasonably and effectively conduct their business in relation to tax laws which are in effect operative but for which legislation still has not been introduced into the Parliament almost a year later? Any reasonable person would think that is a legislative disgrace. It is a totally unsatisfactory position about which the Government, clearly, should be highly embarrassed. You will notice, Mr Deputy President, when you come to peruse the schedule, that I have left in the quarantining of farm losses proposal which was to be effective from 1 July this year because we do not know whether, for example, when the Government introduces its new notion of applying a tax to Pitt Street farmers it will be dated from 1 July. Again, it is a situation of total uncertainty for business people and investors. It is an example of Government ineptitude which one could almost describe as a scandal.

Therefore, because of the Government's specific taxes I have mentioned today, the lack of vision in its policy on those taxes and its practice of legislating by announcement, making it impossible for businesses and individuals to comply properly with the obligations under which they have to operate, I strongly support the motion moved by the Opposition today. The Government's record of tax reform in all these areas has been one of miserable failure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Messner's motion which makes three major points: Firstly, that the uncertainty surrounding the Government's procrastination on tax measures has undermined general confidence in the Government's decision-making process and its ability to make decisions; secondly, the uncertainty is harmful to business confidence simply because business does not know what is going on; thirdly, the proposed measures, particularly the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax, will be harmful and thus a disincentive to our whole economy. Investment is falling, and no wonder, because investment is based on expectations. An uncertain taxation system will undermine those expectations.

SPEECH.PARA: By looking at the legislative program that should be facing us, we can see why those expectations are undermined. Changes affecting a host of things from negative gearing through to the capital gains tax, fringe benefits tax and so on have been outlined by my colleague Senator Hill. A major item is the quarantining of farm losses. What a great saga that has been. It was announced on 19 September 1985 and was to take effect on 1 July 1986. It was pulled out by the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, on 15 April 1986 and on the following day it was reinstated by the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh. I continue to be totally amazed that the Government cannot see that this sort of uncertainty is one of the major contributors to the failure of business confidence and the possibility of the J curve failing to eventuate. Of course, it is not the only contributor.

Mr Kevin Cashman, the chief executive of Sunbeam Corporation Ltd, has also spelled out other major causes. For example, we no longer make toasters in Australia today. This is just a reflection of all the other little manufacturing industries in which we no longer engage. His reasoning is interesting. The breakdown of costs of making toasters spells out the disadvantages of manufacturing in Australia today. It is in wage costs, of course, that Australia really slips. Comparisons of hourly wage rates for process workers put Australia at $7.40 an hour at the top of the table, followed by the United States at $6.60 an hour, New Zealand at $5.31 an hour and Hong Kong at $2.68 an hour. Mr Cashman points out that in this international comparison only Australians have the privilege of a 38-hour week. Australia has the highest number of non-working days at 52 days, compared with New Zealand at 30, Hong Kong at 22 and the United States at 19. We also have the most generous annual leave. Only Australia provides long service leave. We have the highest allowance for sick leave. One might expect our wage costs to be the highest but not our material costs. Here the curiosities of export pricing mean that the manufacturers in Hong Kong can buy aluminium sourced from Australia at 22 per cent less than Sunbeam can buy the same material in Australia.

Last year the Government described its tax package as a great reform. These claims are now seen for what they were, empty kite flying. The changes were neither a package, nor were they genuine reforms. I will come to that later. The problem is that no-one knows where we stand on tax changes. Many of the proposals have not been introduced as legislation even though their operation dates back to last year or the year before. Other measures have been watered down or removed. I have just mentioned quarantining of farm losses. No one knows where we stand on that matter, apparently not even the Government. If the Government does not know where we stand on taxation policy, how can anyone else in the community know where we stand?

Another example of indecision is the fringe benefits tax. I will mention briefly the car industry. Senator Richardson went in to bat yesterday for the Government. He said that there would be some sort of fringe benefits tax, but what sort of tax will it be and how much will it cost? This would be subject to what the honourable senator called `negotiations'. We all know that that is an attempt to cover up the basic differences between the ideas of Senator Button and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on this and other issues. We will not know what the legislation will be until we see its colour. Senator Button said today that there will not be any change in the legislation. Let us see. Senator Button knows the parlous state of the car industry. Senator Richardson and Mr Keating obviously either do not know about the problems or do not care. They retain their pathological Australian Labor Party bias about so-called equity.

Senator Cook, who preceded me in the debate, mentioned equity and fairness. The basis of option C was supposed to be equity and fairness. As everyone knows, we ended up with a deal made in a motel room with the Australian Council of Trade Unions and a mishmash of a tax on the 600,000 small business people who employ about three million Australians. He talked about tax rorters. We read in the newspapers that in Melbourne tram and bus employees and ex-employees can wander about the town with a letter in their pockets and avoid paying bus and tram fares. He talked about the restaurant industry. He said: `Show us your figures'. He bragged about shutting loopholes. The restaurant industry is patchy. I think everyone would agree with that. But this fringe benefits tax has created its own loopholes. We do not have to delve too far into it to find that where the restaurant industry is doing well, the value of the credit card business has gone down and the cash part has gone up. One does not have to be a genius to work out how that occurs. It is to the advantage of the genuine businessman who is still engaging in legitimate business expenses and the restaurateur who is now getting more cash than credit cards.

The much-cited Idaps Australia Ltd figures this week clearly demonstrate the likely demise of the car industry unless the Government changes course on the tax matter. The figures show dropping sales and dropping registrations. The proposed tax is clearly a very significant reason for the state of the industry. Senator Walsh, quite correctly, has often pointed to motor vehicle registrations as a reliable barometer of general economic performance. He has often waxed lyrical during the good times and has held up his Government's contribution to economic growth as being something to be proud of. Yet in the last few months, he has been strangely silent. Meanwhile, our manufacturing sector is slipping further into the mire.

I will now touch briefly on the fringe benefits tax as it applies to remote areas. Workers in remote areas, whether in mining or in farming, were provided with accommodation at nominal rental. This was done to encourage people from urban areas to work in remote areas. All the associated facilities were provided by the employers. Under the tax package, those who provided the facilities are now hit with a tax on the difference between the nominal rent and the market rate. There has been some adjustment because the mining people, in particular, have had discussions with Senator Gareth Evans. I am also aware that Senator Evans has told them that he does not care how the figures are calculated, as long as the net revenue is the same. Today's Courier-Mail states that the State Leader of the Labor Party in Queensland says that he has some information for Mr Keating which would provide fringe benefit concessions in remote areas. However, when we look at it, what he has to say is a poor attempt at a pea and thimble trick. The article states:
People living in remote areas of Queensland will receive major concessions on the proposed fringe benefits tax.

By way of example, Mr Warburton says that the Mt Isa Shire will save $50,000, but he does not tell the shire how much the tax will cost. He gives a little example. He says that if the Mt Isa Council is providing a home for one of its employees at a rent of $30 a week when the rent for that on the open market would be $100 a week, instead of paying tax on the $70 difference, the Council will be taxed on $30. Of course, the point is that it was not paying tax on that before. It is an absolute confidence trick. I think that that is the same type of formula that would apply to everyone else in remote areas, whether in the mining or farming industries.

Foreign tax credits probably form one of the most disturbing elements in a tax package for which we have not seen the legislation. People are trying to interpret what they think might be in the legislation. Where the tax rate on overseas income is less than that paid in Australia the additional tax needed to bring the total tax up to the Australian tax rate will be payable. Apparently the timing of the tax liability will depend on whether the income is in the form of, firstly, fees and or branch profits or, secondly, dividends from overseas incorporated companies. In the former case, the liability apparently will arise in respect of the year in which the income is earned, whereas in the latter case it will arise in respect of the year in which the dividend was paid or credited.

The list goes on of the uncertainties people have about the tax and the inconsistency of the whole thing. For some time we have had Government Ministers promoting the export of goods and services. That is quite understandable because of the terrible mess our balance of payments are in. Considerable focus has been put on the lack of competitiveness of Australian manufacturing and service industries and their lack of application to overseas markets. At the same time proposals for the introduction of a foreign tax credit system, which appears likely to have an adverse effect on construction companies working overseas, has been announced by this Government. We can do without the uncertainty of not having the legislation-legislation which is critical to decision-making. There are enough problems without the Government dragging its feet on this issue.

Let us look at the other major issues. I cite figures from the Economist dated 19 April 1986. If we look at consumer prices as at the end of March, we see that Australia's figure was up by 8.2 per cent. As we know, it has now risen to 9.2 per cent. At the same time West Germany had an increase of 0.1 per cent; Japan 2.4 per cent; and the United States of America 3.2 per cent. I now turn to the increased wholesale price figures, which are of great concern because the later flow-on to retail prices will exacerbate the position. In the full 12 months to the end of March the Australian figure increased by 6.7 per cent; West Germany had a figure of minus 1.5 per cent; Japan, minus 7.7 per cent; and the United States of America, minus 1.3 per cent. Interest rates have been spoken about previously. We know that we have the highest interest rates since the Depression. As at the end of March, the Australian interest rate figure was 19.1 per cent. In West Germany the figure was 7 per cent; in Japan, 4.5 per cent; and in the United States of America, 8 per cent.
Finally, I note in the Melbourne Herald today-I think this is very appropriate-the editorial heading: `Not so much confusion, as panic'. That article stated:

As the arguments and horse trading drag on, it's not so much an air of confusion which surrounds the Keating tax package. It's an air of panic. The Treasurer has admitted the effect on the car industry of the fringe benefits tax had not been analysed.
The article continued:

This debate is not just an argument among politicians. It affects ordinary Australians and they must have the right to consider the proposals. Yet here we are, in May, and the tax has yet to take its final form. It's a disgrace for which Mr Keating must accept the blame.

And is any of this worth the agony? In the end, with all the fiddling and disruption and dangers, there's little reform. The tax cuts are insignificant compared with the risk to jobs and prosperity. Mr Keating had the beginnings of reform, but they disappeared with the `consensus' of the tax summit. It is time for him-and the Government-to face that and reassess strategy.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Messner's) be agreed to.

ROW.ENTRY: (Senator Robert Ray did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Missen.)

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is dealing with seven allied Bills which cover a wide range of rural produce including barley, dried fruits, livestock, chicken meat, pig slaughter and dairying. These Bills have been introduced at a time when the rural scene faces, beyond doubt, the gravest long term issues of its history. These issues in themselves are not just the recurrent problems of good or bad seasons, droughts or floods or fluctuations in world prices. The problems are far deeper than that. Of course, the rural industries are now confronted with the possibility of a further bad drought.

SPEECH.PARA: Against that background there are huge world surpluses of almost all primary produce including grains, beef, dried fruits, dairy products, sugar and vegetable oil-surpluses that, in many cases, are chronic and inevitably are combined with low prices. Wheat prices, for example, are at a record post-war low. Our percentage of the Japanese beef market has fallen. The sugar industry is in a real crisis. The situation in which these industries find themselves must be taken in parallel with ever-rising production costs, record interest rates, rural indebtedness which has more than doubled in the last five years, farm incomes at bare subsistence levels and negligible returns on capital. To have low world prices in good seasons is one thing; to have low world prices and to be facing in the future, inevitably, some bad seasons is a recipe for tragedy, a recipe for disaster.

Over the years rural employment has steadily fallen as farmers, in their search to cut costs, in their search to increase productivity, have sought mechanisation and new technology. Of course, rural industries are almost wholly single-owner or family undertakings. The number of farms is shrinking year by year. The fact is that more than 49,000 dairy farmers have gone out of production in the past quarter of a century. This in itself is bad enough, but let me fit this into the pattern in Australia in recent times. Let me re-emphasise some of the figures that have been quoted before. Fifty years ago Australia's living standards were the world's highest. We now rank twenty-first, and other nations are rapidly overtaking us. Not long ago we were rated as the world's twelfth largest trading nation. Now we are the twentieth, and slipping badly. We were once ranked as the eighth most competitive nation. Now we are nineteenth-and again slipping. The most graphic statistic is surely this: In the last 20 years our share of world markets has fallen from 2 per cent to 1.2 per cent, and this lower level is under serious threat. Our markets are further shrinking. I repeat: Over the last 20 years our share of world markets has virtually halved.

We are a nation that is dependent on overseas trade to maintain our living standards. We are a nation that inevitably must produce in agriculture far more than our domestic demand. We are a nation that must produce minerals-far more than our demand-and export them. We are a nation that depends upon manufacturing to employ its people. Tragically, however, manufacturing, which used to employ 28 per cent of all our population, has fallen to less than 17 per cent, and is continuing to fall. In the December quarter there was a fall of 0.7 per cent in manufacturing. The trend is, indeed, an insidious one; it is one which bodes ill for the prospects of the young. Sadly, Australia's overseas debt has increased from $3.5 billion in 1970-71 to just about $70 billion today. Just to service the interest on that debt requires an amount equal to the earnings that Australia receives from all of our wool, wheat and beef exports.

Sadly, the measure of how Australia is now regarded by other countries is reflected in the staggering fall in the value of our dollar, not only in relation to the United States dollar but also in regard to sterling, yen, Deutsche marks and other currencies. Devaluation of that magnitude may seem attractive at first to the embattled farming community because it means, in nominal terms, some extra money. But it is plain bad news when taken as a whole. It means sharply rising import costs and higher overseas debt servicing. I quote just one example: The extra cost for our defence forces in terms of overseas purchases is said to be in the order of $400m this year simply because of devaluation. One should not be seduced by the attraction of perhaps a further fall that might give some extra nominal value for the moment. Above all, one should not be seduced by the Government's very tenuous argument that devaluation, now approaching 30 per cent, provides an extra cover, an extra tariff, which would enable the protection of manufacturing to expand, leading to import replacement.

That argument in itself looks attractive, but let me examine it. First of all, it means that the manufacturers would need to be assured that that kind of protection from devaluation and from tariffs would be extended into the indefinite future. In other words, it means that the Government would be signalling that the devaluation would stay at this level, that the world would continue to judge Australia adversely and that protection would therefore continue. That argument, one hopes, is absolutely wrong. One hopes that the world will look towards Australia and see brighter things and that as a result our dollar will move upwards. If that happens we would be asking manufacturers to operate in a market in which their protection is diminishing and competition with imports is increasing. In any case, we are dealing with rural industry and, fundamentally, the rural industries will suffer and pay the price of the increased costs, either from imports or from local manufacturing.

I cannot stress too much these real elements of the approach to the rural problems. The first and fundamental thing that must be understood is that 80 per cent of all rural costs are incurred off the farm-outside the farm and outside of farmers' control. Some of those costs are incurred in the cities. Costs are also incurred in respect of imports, transport, freight and electric power reticulation. I repeat that these costs are not capable of being controlled by the farmer himself. His segment accounts for some 20 per cent of costs. The fact must also be re-emphasised-and I have mentioned this in the Senate before-that freight costs make up 40 per cent of all costs for all kinds of materials, services et cetera. Forty per cent of these costs represents the cost of transport.

We have a rural community confronted with costs on which it cannot make an impact. The rural community struggles for further productivity. In terms of efficiency it is well ahead in the world, but it cannot compete in this world if the prices and costs that are forced upon it from outside continue to rise. The Government talks of a splendid economy. I cannot conceive of a splendid economy, which in fact has a rural community in severe straits, a mining community in no better shape, with coal being threatened in terms of exports and prices, and a diminishing manufacturing industry. If that is a good economy, we have a strange sense of humour in Australia. How can it be a good economy for farmers or others if the consumer price index, as last recorded, has risen to 9.2 per cent, despite the signals from the Government that it would stay at 8 per cent and decline? How can we face a situation with any complacency when we know that that 9.2 per cent is more than double the CPI increase of our trading partners and indeed is many times that of countries such as Japan and West Germany, where the inflation rate is approaching zero?

We have a single burning challenge in Australia. We are facing an economic crisis across the board, particularly in the rural area for one particular reason; that is, we are being costed out of world markets, we cannot compete with other countries. It is nonsense to talk about other countries having lower wages. Indeed, many of the countries that now compete with us have a wage scale and benefits at least comparable with those in Australia. It is true, and it needs to be understood, that the world around us is becoming more self-sufficient in agricultural products both in food and fibre. One of the remarkable events of recent history, and indeed a great tribute to the late Mrs Gandhi and her Government, is that a nation of some 600 million or 700 million people which was so dependent in the decades gone by on imported food has now become basically self-sufficient in food and is showing some evidence of exporting. So, too, are countries such as Thailand and China.

We in Australia have to adjust to the fact that the world around us is no longer what it was 20 or 30 years ago, that the markets are not of the same nature necessarily or existing in the same places. But fundamentally, whatever we choose to export as a product, we come against the one principle whether we are farmers, manufacturers or miners; that is, unless we can get the costs down in Australia to compare with those overseas, we will go on declining. Our living standards will decline and, indeed, unemployment will continue to rise. That is showing up in a whole host of different ways. Our current account deficit is now running at the extraordinary average of about $14.4 billion a year, an increase in recent times of $3 billion.

I have dwelt upon the size of the national debt. Our interest rates in real terms are of record dimensions and although showing some minor signs of decrease are far and away above what they were in real terms in years gone by. So the burden of higher costs and higher interest rates is all on the community and on the farmer. But the Government has gone further than this. The Government, it seems, was out to punish the rural community. How could it have been so insensitive in its earlier approach to the assets test of the social security system when in fact it failed to understand the particular needs of farming communities, and particularly the needs of the elderly? It would have blindly deprived people of their rightful social benefits. How could it be so unfeeling that it set up its principles to eliminate the offsetting of losses? How could it have looked at negative gearing in the way it did in the overall picture? But how could it have looked at capital gains as it still does and still wants to? It is still putting forward a tax which is the reimposition of a death duty or an estate duty?

Let me get to the fundamentals. This Government has as its primary task the lowering of the consumer price index. In recent months it has had a great opportunity to reduce the CPI by at least a further one per cent simply by keeping its promise to the electors. I refer to its promise on import parity pricing and the adjustment of the prices of oil to overseas movements. It was an extraordinary situation for this Government. I cannot think of anything that involved more of the circus-type somersaults that this Government has done on that matter. In the late 1970s and early 1980s the present Treasurer, Mr Keating, railed around this country saying all sorts of things against the Government of the day, my Government, because we had import parity pricing and because, in Mr Keating's words, there was a tax office at every petrol bowser. Everybody knows that he was going to make a 1980 election issue out of this-a major cause for himself. Everybody knows that he said this would not be Labor Party policy.

This Government has not only embraced import parity pricing but also gone further. On the one hand it has said that it wished to maintain it and on the other it has added a further insidious tax. Three years ago the Government introduced an indexing of excises in Australia. That meant that the petrol excise would go up automatically with the CPI without the need for legislation in the Parliament. That in itself was bad enough because it was another hidden tax at the petrol bowser. But when oil prices fell drastically, instead of keeping the election promises, the Government decided to give only part of the relief to the Australian community and to offset that by adding to the excise at the pump. Petrol and oil prices today are at an unreal level. The Government has broken this promise as it has broken many promises. It has failed to maintain import parity pricing and it has found an insidious way of getting more money out of the Australian community through the petrol pump by means of the extra index tax at the bowser.

The Government has completely failed to realise that the farming community, of all communities, is heavily indebted by freight. It is not good enough to do something about on-farm diesel or to make some minor gesture like that; they are the petty cash of the costs of freight. The real costs of freight to the farmer are the movement of goods and supplies to and from the farm, a movement to the farm of the necessary operating material and a movement from the farm of the output of the farms. It would have been a very valuable help to the farmer if a fall in petrol price had been allowed to go right through the whole community to its full extent. This would have meant that in every commodity and in every service sought by the rural community the farmer would benefit. I repeat that hidden in the 80 per cent of all farm costs-in other words, that segment which is incurred off the farm and outside the control of the farmer-is a very major ingredient of freight. Forty per cent of all costs is freight. Here one could have given the farmer major relief; but this was not given. It was a broken promise of a very serious kind and it has, in fact, put the consumer price index up by at least another one percentage point. Every time that this Government, by its actions, increases the CPI or maintains it at a rate so much higher than that of the outside world, the Government does grave disservice not only to the farming community but also to every person seeking a job in Australia.

One must keep in mind that, with all the Government's promises that it would create jobs and with its magnificent argument that it had created some 600,000 jobs, a fundamental which Mr Hawke stated in his earlier policy speech was that before one can reduce one place in the unemployment ranks, 130,000 or more extra jobs have to be found every year just to keep up with the population growth. So in fact what has happened has been a confidence trick. In the apparent rise in the number of jobs-incidentally, many of them part time-there has been an illusion created. First of all, the participation rate has fallen on many occasions below what it was in the time of the Fraser Government, so the comparison gives an illusion. Instead of there being 8.2 per cent of people unemployed-I think that is the figure now-the real unemployment cannot be measured because so many people do not register. The silent unregistered number of unemployed is not available to us.

We now have a situation where the more we fail to get our costs down and the more we fail to help the farmers, miners and manufacturers to export, the higher our overseas indebtedness and inevitably, therefore, the higher our interest rates, and the worse the effect of devaluation on the whole community and the ugliness of the illusion that somehow devaluation is helpful. I can understand the situation in terms of the simple nominal growth of money that may come from trade, whether mining or farming, but the extra costs that devaluation has put upon Australia and the extra burden it has put therefore, indirectly but in a very real sense, upon the rural community, far outweigh any value of the devaluation. In any case, the Government's great claim about this famous J curve-that there would be a turn around and that manufacturers would come in and do import replacements-has no supporting evidence at all. We are facing today a far worse situation in each of our industries-manufacturing, mining and agriculture-than we have faced in the past 30 or 40 years. We are facing today an entrenchment of chronic defects which have been cemented in place by the Hawke Government.

The Hawke Government claims, of course, benefit from the weather. I do not know whether Mr Hawke made it rain so that the farmers had three good seasons. I imagine, therefore, that he will be sufficiently honest and robust to take the blame for any bad seasons that may flow now. The Labor Party railed and ranted in 1982 when the Fraser Government had the courage to indicate that it would bring in a wage freeze over a period, preferably of a year but certainly for six months. The Hawke Government attacked that policy as fundamentally abhorrent to it. It went in and it grasped the wage freeze to itself as the only beneficial economic factor, other than rain, which has occurred in this time. In fact, the wage freeze caused not only a CPI freeze but a fall in real terms of the CPI.

The fundamental benefits that have come to the economy have come from three things. They have come from good seasons, thank God-and one hopes that they will persist but one fears that they will not; they have come from the fundamental wage freeze and its benefits, which have flowed on to everyone; and they have come from the upturn in the world outside. But that is where it ends. The Government's economic policy is to entrench the margin that Australian inflation has above inflation among its trading partners. It has set out deliberately to keep the gap the same instead of shrinking it. How else could the accord have occurred. The accord is basically the indexation of inflation, and the indexation of inflation simply means that for all farmers and miners there is entrenched in it the gap in our production costs compared with production costs overseas. This is an extraordinary attitude altogether.

The Government uses rhetoric to disguise its failures. It talks accord and consensus. The accord, to the Hawke Labor Government, means a behind the scenes fix between the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Government-indeed, doing what the ACTU tells the Government to do and without full consultation with the rest of the community. In other words, it is a confrontation by the ACTU and the Hawke Government against the rest of the community, particularly small business, farmers and others. The whole of the action of the Government has been, indeed, to increase the burden upon the farming community and others. It has had great opportunities to do the reverse. In fact, it has simply added the lead weights to the saddle of the farming community.

I repeat that nothing could have been more insensitive than the piling on of capital gains taxes, negative gearings, the attack through the assets test upon farming people and all these quite ugly things, at a time when farmers were crying out for help. To have pretended to the public that it would give the benefits of import parity pricing and then to impose a snide silent tax which destroyed that was to increase the costs for the whole of the Australian people. The simple fact is that if we are to help the farming people, everybody in Australia has that task before them. It is not a question of whether a city person can score off a country person or vice versa. The fact of the matter is that the farmer cannot be prosperous unless the cost structure internally throughout Australia is reduced. The city person cannot be prosperous unless the farmer is capable of producing and selling his wares.

I come back to what I have said repeatedly in this chamber. Fundamentally what has happened is that the Labor Party over the years has entrenched in Australia a completely false concept of class polarisation, of a fight between labour and management, and therefore a need to struggle to get more and more when in fact the interests of the two are identical and when we should be saying to both: `Work together in terms of getting more real wages and increased productivity, and by so doing you will not only increase exports but also get the jobs for our youngsters who today have not got that choice'. The Labor Government works by confrontation. It pretends consensus. It has failed miserably, and the rural sector in particular is paying very dearly indeed for the almost four years of the Hawke Labor Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contributions to the debate on the Barley Research Levy Amendment Bill and allied Bills, and I commend them to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without requests or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: PROTECTION OF MOVABLE CULTURAL HERITAGE BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 March, on motion by Senator Ryan:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In leading for the Opposition parties tonight I have great pleasure in lending support to the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Bill. The purpose of this legislation is to give some greater degree of control to Australian authorities over material which is being exported from Australia and which is of cultural significance. As part of the new regime to be put in place this particular piece of legislation has been introduced as the product of a long period of consultation, details of which I wish to address later.

SPEECH.PARA: The regime will depend not only upon the passage of this legislation but also on the subsequent passage of the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill which, I believe, is currently before the House of Representatives. That Bill provides for changes in Part III of the Customs Act. In the words of the explanatory memorandum, it is intended to provide the necessary authority for officers of Customs to seize protected cultural objects notified by the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment pursuant to the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Act 1986 whilst those objects are subject to the control of Customs. Once this Bill and the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill are passed, we will have a new regime which will allow for the effective protection in Australia of physical items which are of cultural significance to the Australian nation.

The protection of what might be called our national cultural patrimony is in fact an important step. I think it is important to note that that step is being taken fairly close to our bicentennial celebrations. Many countries have already suffered considerable losses in their cultural patrimony by the way in which artefacts-items of cultural and historical significance-have been traded around the world. Some of them, it must be admitted, have been traded quite legitimately; others have been traded in a quite covert fashion.

For instance, one knows of the outrage that is still felt by many of the people in the Greek community and in Greece at the loss of the Elgin Marbles to the British Museum. This is a vexatious issue, one which continues to be a source of complaint by the Greek Government and its authorities. On looking at a very interesting book by Karl Meyer entitled The Plundered Past on the traffic in art treasures, it can be seen that there is a very significant illegal trade in materials of cultural significance. Interpol maintains a list of the most wanted pieces of art which have disappeared and which, indeed, have been stolen. On this list one thinks, for instance, of Masaccio's painting Virgin and Child, Mem- ling's Portrait of a Gentleman, a famous Toulouse-Lautrec portrait Marcelle, the Caravaggio Nativity, the Correggio The Holy Family, Rembrandt's painting The Flight into Egypt, the Gainsborough Portrait of Sir Robert Fletcher and the Frans Hals Portrait of a Young Woman.

In fairly recent times we have witnessed the looting of the national Anthropological Museum in Mexico City and the loss of absolutely irreplaceable and priceless pieces of pre-Columbian art. I am glad I had the chance to see them before they vanished. It should not be thought that this is simply a small time business. I refer to a report which states that in 1972 the Metropolitan Museum in New York acquired by means which were perhaps not altogether above board a very famous Calyx Krater. That was a Greek sixth century vase from the potter Euxitheo and the painter Euphronios, which is reported to have cost the museum more than $US1m. So one is not talking about small ticket items in this trade.

It should not be thought that these losses are confined to places such as Greece, Mexico or Thailand or to the collections in Europe. Let me document a couple of instances relating to Australian material which fall into this category. Last year, despite or perhaps because of the introduction of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders Heritage (Interim Protection) Act, we witnessed the removal, quite improperly and quite disgracefully, from this country of the Strehlow collection. I refer to the improper removal of the tjurunga stones of the Aranda people. In July 1985 there was a major auction at Sotheby's in England of 76 Aboriginal artefacts, including the Yirwala bark paintings, which went into private collections.

There have been problems with the export from Australia-I will return to this as an example in a minute-of the facsimile of deeds of the Batman grant. It is unfortunate that the principal Australian constitutional documents are in the Records Office of the House of Lords. If the British Government is in any way serious about supporting our bicentennial celebrations, the most useful thing it could do would be to repatriate those documents so that they could in fact form part of the display in-I do not think it will be called King's Hall-whatever the main public vestibule of the new Parliament House is to be called.

TALK.START.PARA: —The People's Hall.

—As long as it is not called Hawke's Hall, I do not mind. I refer to other items of importance and significance to various people. In 1981 a very historic Spitfire mark 8 and a Messerschmitt BF109G were improperly exported from Australia. There have been problems with some rare Spitfires which have been seized by Customs. The value of those aircraft was in the vicinity of $265,000.

SPEECH.PARA: As a philatelist I was particularly interested to see a rare Western Australian stamp, the Western Australian Blue, recently auctioned in London for $30,000. The Western Australian inverted swan stamp-one of the most famous of its kind-is currently lodged in the Dublin Museum. If the Irish wanted to make a contribution to our Bicentenary, I am sure they could return it.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are making a contribution.

—I had in mind some contribution other than having provided the genetic origin of about one-third of the members of this Parliament. Similarly one looks perhaps at the extent to which such matters could be raised with the papal authorities during the forthcoming visit of His Holiness. The Vatican's significant collection of Aboriginal artefacts in my opinion more properly belongs in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently one has seen reports in the newspapers of the Ravensworth finds at Riversleigh, where very important and significant palaeological and anthropological artefacts are being removed from Australia. A very large number of bones of what are now becoming known as megafauna are being discovered in Australia and many of these are leaving the country. I was distressed to see the details of an auction recently conducted by Sotheby's in Melbourne at which a painting by Frederick McCubbin called `Feeding Time' was sold for $693,000. It was subsequently revealed that this painting may well be taken out of the country.

It is important to stress that the introduction of this legislation does not have a retrospective effect; therefore those items that have already been lost from the cultural collections of Australia cannot be recalled. However, one would hope that from time to time some capacity would exist to retrieve some of these items. I give great credit to the announcement made by the then Minister for Industry and Commerce, Senator Button, and Mr Cohen, who was Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, back in November 1984 when they introduced a prohibition on the exportation from Australia of historic film and sound recordings. That was a most important and significant contribution to maintaining the collection of cultural material in Australia which I believe is part of the heritage of all Australians and which should be accessible to all Australians.

I mentioned previously that I wanted to say something about the John Batman deed facsimile. This facsimile was seized by the Comptroller-General of Customs as an illegal export when it was, in fact, re-entering Australia. The facsimile deed was in the hands of a private owner-and quite properly so-and that person sought to send it to London to have it auctioned. It was sent to London, it did not fetch the reserve price at auction so it was then returned to the original owner, so it was thought. However, when the deed re-entered the country it was seized by Customs as being an illegal export under the terms of item B of the Second Schedule of the Customs Act. In the view of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) the deed, as an illegal export, then became the property of the Crown. The power to dispose of it lies with the Comptroller-General of Customs on the advice of the Minister responsible for Customs-that is, Senator Button.

I understand that the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment has advised the Customs Service that that deed should be returned to its proper and legitimate owner in Australia. That advice has been with the Minister for some time and has not been acted upon. I think it is entirely improper that the article, on its re-entry to Australia, should have been seized by the Crown and has not yet been returned to its original owner. I hope that the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) will take this up with her colleague Senator Button and see whether he is now prepared to act upon the advice that he has received from the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment that that document should be returned.

The model which in part has been used as a model for this legislation is the British 1979 Export of Goods Control Order. Under that order a group of expert advisers has been appointed to advise the British Government on whether an item should be permitted to be exported. The decision not to allow an export licence is normally subject to an offer by a public institution which the exporter is not obliged to accept. That offer must be made within a specified time for the purchase of the object and failing such an offer, an export licence is generally granted. For the year 1982-83, which is the last year for which I have the figures, 20 cases were referred to the committee of experts for review after an expert adviser in the first instance had recommended refusal of an export licence. In 14 cases export was suspended for a number of months pending the possibility of an offer to purchase the object at the recommended fair market price from a British public collection. In seven cases public collecting institutions were able to make offers at the recommended price; in five they were not and export licences were subsequently granted. In the remaining two cases the owners withdrew their application to export the objects in question.

Unfortunately, although the British protect their own cultural material and prevent it from leaving the country, they are a little less sensitive about returning other people's. In particular a very famous case arose which was the immediate trigger for this piece of legislation. That case arose as the result of the New Zealand Government attempting under the New Zealand Historical Articles Act 1962 to recover a collection of Maori artefacts which had been improperly exported from New Zealand to Britain. In the first instance the court in the United Kingdom in the Queens Bench division agreed that the articles should be returned. The new owner then appealed and the Court of Appeal in the civil division overturned the judgment of the first judge and its overturning of that judgment was subsequently confirmed on appeal in the House of Lords in April 1983. This case-the Ortiz case-triggered in some respects the question being raised at a meeting of British Commonwealth Attorneys-General where it became apparent that there was lack of uniformity in the way in which these matters were dealt with. As I said, the British were not inclined to give effect to the New Zealand Act and that is a great pity.

It is interesting to note that among the countries that have become signatories to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation convention upon which this Bill is predicated-the Convention on the Means of Prohibiting and Preventing the Illicit Import, Export and Transfer of Ownership of Cultural Property-the United States is listed but Great Britain is not. Again, I think that is extremely regrettable. Back in 1975 the report of the Pigott Committee of Inquiry on Museums and National Collections recommended in paragraph 2.15 that Australia should adhere to the UNESCO Convention. The report said:

To retain rare Australian cultural material, we recommend that the Australian Government introduce specific legislation to regulate or prohibit the export of particular items or categories of items. We recommend that the protection of cultural relics would be furthered if Australia ratified and implemented the UNESCO Convention of 1970 on the Means of Prohibiting and Preventing the Illicit Import, Export and Transfer of Ownership of Cultural Property.
That is one of the recommendations that are being taken up in this legislation, as indeed is the recommendation for the establishment of the Museum of Australia which flowed from the Pigott inquiry.

Australia has a number of unique museums and collections. Apart from the Museum of Australia, to which I wish to return in a moment, it has one of the world's outstanding film and sound archives. A number of individuals and companies and organisations have contributed substantially to building up the collection there. For example, the film and sound archives hold sets of all 156 known titles of recordings made by Dame Nellie Melba and one of the projects which it has in hand is to reissue all of these at some stage. We have a Bill currently before the House of Representatives for the establishment of a National Maritime Museum. That is an important and significant development. I have watched the progress of work one way or the other at the Darling Harbour site, and although one might want to make some comments about various arrangements with the Builders Labourers Federation and the New South Wales Government, that is something that will wait for the debate on that particular legislation. Nevertheless, the Museum, despite the troubles it ran into temporarily before Estimates Committee D last week-Senator Ryan would be painfully aware of that-is a very significant development in Australia's cultural heritage. In Victoria we have an extremely good Performing Arts Museum. Just south of Sydney there is an extremely interesting railway museum. In Newcastle there is an extremely good museum at Fort Scratchley, a museum of the history and development, particularly the maritime development, of Newcastle and the region. We have the Stockman's Hall of Fame and in Sydney the wonderful technologically oriented Powerhouse Museum.

One of the great things that will flow from this legislation will be the capacity of local communities to develop and promote local museums. They will have the capacity for the protection of material; they will have, through the Fund which is to be established as part of this system, a capacity to involve themselves in a more systematic and, I hope, more successful preservation of their own local cultural identity and history. The Museum of Australia in its 1984-85 annual report made a number of comments about its collections. In that report the Museum notes:

There were several notable additions to the collection itself, including the purchase by the Commonwealth Government of the America's Cup winner, `Australia II', the acquisition of the River Murray paddle-steamer `Enterprise', built in 1878, the BP solar car `The Quiet Achiever', an important collection of early Australian postcards, the contents of Dalton's Printery at Echuca Victoria, and three Edwardian mutoscopes or `peepshows' originally from the Glenelg pier in South Australia.
The report goes on to note:

In addition, work began on the accessioning of some 10,000 Aboriginal items from the national ethnographic collection, transferred to the Museum's custody during the year. They have been stored in unsatisfactory conditions in the basement of the former Institute of Anatomy building. Following the transfer of that building to the National Film and Sound Archive, the Museum began transferring these objects to the Mitchell Repository for essential conservation treatment and storage in modern premises.

There are many areas of the world where exploration is currently under way, where great artefacts are expected to be found. For instance, one looks at Egypt and the search for the tombs of Heri-hor and Imhotep; at the Middle East and developments at Akkad and Ebla; at Greece and the developments and the digs at Akrotiri in Thera; the Kas shipwreck in Turkey. In China there is a continuing search for the original bones of Peking Man, which disappeared during the war. One sees almost every week now indications of new discoveries in Central and South America, particularly pre-Columbian art and the lost heritage of the Mayan people. One knows that in Australia there is a great deal of work going on in the preservation and identification of sites of major significance to Aboriginal Australians, and indeed to all Australians.

The international regime that is established under the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation Convention to which Australia now becomes a more effective contributing party will not just help Australia but will reinforce Australia's commitment to helping other countries in the preservation of their cultural heritage. I think that is an important contribution we can make in a reciprocal arrangement with other nations. One knows, for instance, that a number of Australian archaeological digs are taking place at Pella in Jordan and on a number of the Aegean Islands. Under the regime which is established here there is also a method by which we can facilitate the exchange between museums of material of cultural significance. I think that will be facilitated by the extent to which we are prepared to play our part in acting against illegal exports and being prepared to return goods improperly brought into our country. By establishing our bona fides in that respect we will then be in a better position to deal with legitimate museums and authorities in other countries for the exchange of material that will enrich both societies and different cultures.

There are only two matters I seek to raise with the Minister and about which I will be interested in having some further information. The first is whether it is possible for a concerned person or group in Australia to take action under this legislation to prevent the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment from granting an export permission. At the moment the Minister, under this Act, is required to grant a permission for a particular category of goods or a particular item in order for it to be exported. If the Minister is minded to give his approval, can somebody in fact challenge, through the legal processes, the right of the Minister to issue the export certificate? Can somebody require the Minister's decision to be subjected to the same process of review that the refusal of an export licence is subjected to? This involves some complicated questions, in particular the question of standing in this particular matter. The Australian Law Reform Commission, in its report No. 27 `Standing in Public Interest Litigation', has raised a number of relevant issues. I am not in a position to go into those this evening, but I simply ask: As the Minister's decision to refuse a permission is subject to review, is the Minister's decision to grant a permission also subject to review and is it subject to review on the basis of the same tests?

A number of matters have been raised by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills in its third report dated 12 March 1986. A number of these are addressed in amendments which I understand the Australian Democrats will be putting forward. It is not my intention to debate those before we reach the Committee stage, other than to say that one of the items we do need to sort out is whether goods in the possession of legitimate collecting or custodial institutions are adequately protected by the legislation, or would they be adversely affected by any proposed amendments to the legislation, and in particular the proposal for amendments to clause 38 of the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Bill? It is my intention to comment on these particular matters when we come to the Committee stage of the Bill.

Nevertheless, this is an important piece of legislation. I know that legislation of this sort does not generate the degree of enthusiasm or blood pressure that a number of others do, but in the long run I believe it is of equal significance because it goes to shaping some of the very fundamental aspects of Australian society. Culture is a very fragile and delicate flower. Different people see quite different things as part of their cultural heritage. But I think there is growing throughout the world a recognition that one simply does not have a society judged in purely material terms, that the protection that is afforded by this legislation, to some of the historic artefacts of Australia, to some of the important cultural parts of the nation's heritage, is worth supporting.

I would like to conclude by paying particular tribute to the work of Dr Jean Battersby in the development of this legislation. Dr Battersby not only has been an enthusiastic proponent of this legislation, but also has been extraordinarily helpful to Senator Collard, our shadow Minister, and me in terms of providing advice, explanation and assistance on this legislation. I am sure that her work and her support of this legislation will be very much rewarded by its passage. Its passage will be facilitated by the Opposition. We are pleased to see this piece of legislation. We are glad to give it our enthusiastic support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support what I regard as outstanding legislation-the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Bill 1986. As indicated by the previous speaker, Senator Puplick, the Bill provides legislative support for the Government's decision to accede to the 1970 United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation Convention on the Means of Prohibiting and Preventing the Illicit Movement, Import, Export and Transfer of Ownership of Cultural Property. It is particularly pleasing that the Minister at the table tonight is Senator Susan Ryan because it was Senator Ryan who announced this decision at the general conference of UNESCO in 1983. The Bill has particular interest for us in the Northern Territory for a number of reasons. The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) stated in his second reading speech:

SPEECH.PARA: All nations possess objects which illustrate in unique or significant ways their history and culture. In Australia's case, some of these objects date back beyond recorded history to the deep roots of Aboriginal life . . .

The Northern Territory, as is well known, is particularly rich in Aboriginal culture and many examples of what the Minister was referring to exist there. There are many other objects in the Northern Territory related to our early history. They are housed in what is probably one of the most effective and best presented small museums in Australia. However, I will concentrate on the Aboriginal aspect to keep my contribution short. I want to come back a little later to the importance of Aboriginal artefacts but I want to make a couple of other comments before I do so.

I have to be a little parochial for the moment and say that the Northern Territory can be justly proud that it was the first legislature to introduce legislation of this type in Australia. Back in 1962 the Native and Historical Objects and Areas Ordinance was passed in the Northern Territory Legislative Council. I pay tribute to the officers of the old welfare branch of the Northern Territory Administration who had the foresight to see the need for this legislation and to the outstanding head of that branch, Mr Harry Giese, for seeing it through the Legislative Council. As I recall, at that time Mr Giese was an official member of the Legislative Council. People familiar with the history of the Northern Territory will know that back in the days when the Commonwealth Government was responsible for it we had a Legislative Council comprising a number of official members, a number of nominated members and a number of non-official members. I remind the Senate that Senator Kilgariff was also a member of the Council at that time and no doubt was associated with the legislation. I also pay tribute to the work of Mr Ted Milliken and Mr Ted Evans who were involved in the preparation of the Native and Historical Objects and Areas Ordinance.

It was very gratifying to see the bipartisan approach to the legislation in the other place. It was a pleasure to read the Hansard of the lengthy debate. It is not always a pleasure to read the Hansard of the other place, as perhaps it is not always a pleasure to read the Hansard of this place. But on this occasion the speaker ranged over a wide area. There was a good approach by all speakers with the exception of one, to the Bills. There was agreement that the Bill was perhaps one of the most outstanding pieces of legislation to be introduced by the present Government. Many of the speakers in the debate also drew attention to the need to protect Aboriginal artefacts.

I consider now some of the reasons why we need to protect and retain Aboriginal artefacts of various types. The first obvious reason is that these artefacts are part of Australia's heritage. We are not sure about the length of pre-history but I think it is fair to say that our history would probably go back 40,000 years. The Aboriginal civilisation certainly is unique. It is one of the oldest in the world. The objects which can be displayed are very valuable in the education of non-Aboriginal people. I speak of education at all levels. The public is generally ignorant of Aboriginal culture. If we can use some of the artefacts to assist in the education of the public generally it will help to break down some of the barriers and racial hatred which still exist within Australia.

I do not believe that it is unfair to say that generally Australians are ignorant of the wealth of Aboriginal culture. I mention the problem of the improper display of objects. There is a limit to the number and type of objects which can be displayed to the public generally, to women, to non-Aboriginal people and to the uninitiated. So, although there are limitations on what can be shown, there are still many objects and artefacts which could be used to help in the education of the public generally.

As a sideline, it is interesting to note that Aboriginal society had very strong sanctions against persons removing or selling artefacts. The selling came late, of course, but the improper removal of artefacts from their place of secretion, because they were put away in secret, attracted the ultimate penalty in some cases. In other cases it was a matter of spearing. So even from early times the Aboriginal people were aware that some of their artefacts might be taken and improperly displayed. We need to retain and make sure that nothing happens to these Aboriginal artefacts because they are vital to the education of the Aboriginal people. I suppose that tjurungas, particularly, could be compared superficially to teaching aids for those who are responsible for the education of young men. Some are used as an aide-memoire for the elders who are carrying out the instruction and some are used by the older people to help them to remember the early times.

Some honourable senators may have seen a particularly touching scene in one of the Attenborough films about the desert-I cannot recall the title of it-where an Aboriginal man was sitting, caressing a tjurunga in an almost trancelike state while he remembers his initiation, perhaps, or the dreaming of his group. We need to protect tjurungas because, at a deeper level or, shall we say at a deeper significance, they are an integral part of many of the ceremonies. They are brought from their secret repositories and shown to those who are being initiated or those who are moving up the ladder towards higher degrees.

Some objects, particularly those of deep significance, are vital to a clan or group. If the clan or group lost them it would be completely disastrous, basically because the clan or group would lose its spirit. The clan or group would be ridiculed by other clans and would be called a rubbish clan because it had lost its dreaming. Not only would it not be able to perform its ceremonies, but also it would be said to have lost its laws. The elders would have no authority. I know of one case in the Northern Territory where this happened, where what we can call a loss occurred-it was not a loss at all; it was theft and subsequent selling-and it led to total disruption of the clan involved. The clan virtually disintegrated. There was a loss of spirit and the elders lost their esteem. The clan lost its pride. Fortunately action has been taken in the Northern Territory to secure the return of those objects which will bring back dignity to that clan.

There are features of the Bill which I would specially like to commend. The Bill facilitates Australia's accession to the UNESCO Convention. The Convention has broad definitions of cultural material and, as we know, its primary focus is on illegal international traffic. It also calls for a number of things. It calls for a national inventory of protected cultural property. It speaks about support for collecting institutions-both financial and other sorts of support. It sets out rules for curatorial conduct so that objects, artefacts and other items can be safeguarded. There is a call for a sharing of techniques amongst the various groups responsible. It calls for educational measures, which I have already mentioned, and for control over dealers, a matter I will discuss later.

The last item in the Convention is the supervision of archeological sites. This matter is covered in the Northern Territory. I regret to say that I am not sure whether it is covered in all of the States. I have a feeling that it is not. If it is not, there will be additional gain in the passing of this Bill. Another feature of the Bill which I commend particularly is the establishment of the National Cultural Heritage Committee which has as its role the giving of advice on the heritage control list and the maintenance of a register of export examiners. One might say that this is most essential because this problem has faced the Customs section in its attempts to control imports and exports. There was a long delay in many cases in trying to get unanimity among experts-whether the item should be allowed in or out of the country. The Committee advises on the operation of those controls which have been established, on what can be sold and to whom it can be sold overseas. Most importantly, it advises on allocations from the heritage fund.

It is vitally important that appropriate people be appointed to this Committee. I am very pleased that the Committee will include a nominee of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Those who have knowledge of the Aboriginal situation will know that it is practically impossible for one Aboriginal to advise, shall we say, across the board. Usually, one person can speak only of his own area. Perhaps it will be necessary to have a panel. If this is not possible, it is even more important to select the right sort of person who has the capacity to draw on resources. We know that the full resources of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the quite extensive resources of the Institute of Aboriginal Studies will be available to anyone who has to fill that very difficult role.

The third feature of the Bill which I particularly commend is the establishment of the National Cultural Heritage Fund. This is a vital aspect of the Bill if we are to retain material in Australia. In other words, if material is to be sold, as in the case mentioned by the previous speaker, it might be possible for the fund to top up the figure which could be achieved in Australia, as against that which might be achieved at Sothebys or other auction sales. This topping up might make it possible for material to remain in Australia. Of course, the Convention calls for the return of material, or the exchange of material if it happens to be under the care of governments. This has already been hinted at. For example, the Convention would say that if the Government in Ireland had an article and the Government in Australia had an article in one of the museums or universities, there could be a transfer back of those items to where they belong.

I should make the point that there needs to be care in the allocation of funds from the National Heritage Fund but I am confident that the Committee will watch over the taxpayers' money and spend the heritage dollars wisely. Although I sit on the Government side of the chamber I am sure that many honourable senators on the other side hope and trust that the Government will make adequate funds available for the job to be done properly. It would seem to be an ideal situation for government and private enterprise to co-operate. There is no reason why governments and major corporations could not join together as they have done to support the Australian Opera and other cultural activities in Australia, to see that sufficient money is available to retain or bring back those items which are part of our heritage.

Some concern was expressed in the other place that Aboriginal artists must be protected; there must be some sort of a free market and some control of this free market. My concern is that the Aboriginal artists, those producing new art and craft, if we can call it that, the people in the Aboriginal communities who are doing bark paintings, carvings, weaving and so on, should be adequately compensated. This source of income to Aboriginal people has the great advantage that it also satisfies them in some of their traditional ceremonies.

There is a great and growing interest in Aboriginal art and craft and, in fact, in art and craft all over Oceania. It seems appropriate that the artists, not the middle men, should profit. Fortunately artist co-operatives and similar organisations have been established to safeguard the artists' interests. It might be fair to mention that the missions in the early days were the first in the field to make sure that the artefacts were sold for a fair price with a good return to the artists. I must make the point that care still needs to be taken with others involved in buying and selling, those whose only concern is with money.

Several speakers in the debate in the other place and one speaker in this place have spoken of the need for a museum for Aboriginal artefacts as well as for other artefacts. Many of the artefacts cannot be displayed to the uninitiated but several museums around Australia at present-I know of those in the Northern Territory, including an outstanding one at Yuendumu-exist for those objects which cannot be displayed but which are outstanding examples of people bringing together their sacred objects and putting them in a safe place. I remind honourable sen- ators of the excellent displays in museums and art galleries but remind them that there is a need for this material to be readily available. I hope to see mobile displays being used rather than static displays in the Centre or in the capitals.

I draw attention to something which will be of interest to us all-that is, the involvement of the President of the Senate in this area. I refer to page 585 of The Whitlam Government 1972-1975, which was written by former Prime Minister Gough Whitlam, in which he had been talking about trying to arrange cultural co- operation agreements. After speaking about some of his work in Italy, Greece and other places he said:
My official involvement in these matters was to come full circle nearly 10 years later in agreeably ironic circumstances. For the Cabinet meeting due on 12 November 1975--
the day after a rather significant event in the history of Australia-

Doug McClelland had submitted a recommendation that the Australian Government ratify as soon as possible the 1970 UNESCO Convention on the Means of Prohibiting and Preventing the Illicit Import, Export and Transfer of Ownership of Cultural Property. This convention had been adopted in November 1970 and had entered into force in April 1972. The Hope Report, tabled in September 1974, recommended ratification as part of a concentrated effort to secure this element of the national art for future Australians. In April 1975 I asked Bowen to bring to Cabinet a submission on the ratification of the convention as a means of preventing the loss of Australia's cultural property overseas, particularly Aboriginal artefacts. The Pigott Report strongly recommended that `the necessary legislative action be taken to enable Australia to implement the undertakings required by the Convention'. At the time of McClelland's submission the convention had already been ratified by 25 States.
Mr Whitlam then went on to speak of the inactivity of the Fraser Government. He said:

During its first five years in office the Fraser Government took no action on the convention. It then set up an inter-departmental working group of seven departments, a Hydra-headed monster which miscarried as soon as it went into labour. It lacked sufficient sensitivity or agility to adapt to the election of the Hawke Government and sufficient candour to recall the intentions of my own. Barry Cohen was not impressed with its insipid conclusion that `there appeared insufficient practical advantages for Australia to ratify it'. Other Ministers collaborated with him in approving ratification. On 27 October 1983 Susan Ryan announced a decision to the General Conference of UNESCO. By that time 53 other nations had become parties to the convention.
Mr Whitlam finished this section by speaking of his own involvement. He said:

The ratification of this important convention, symbolic of all our efforts to reserve Australia's cultural heritage, and forestalled by Kerr's coup, was thus to be formally completed by Sir John's successor at UNESCO. It was to be my last official act in a process of reform and agitation, in both Government and Opposition, to stimulate the arts in our country and refurbish our cultural institutions, a process which provided, across the whole field of our concerns, a most remarkable illustration of the totality and permanence of our performance.

In conclusion I note that the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, Mr Cohen, in the other place drew attention to the support which he had received from former Prime Minister Whitlam in drawing up the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Bill which I commend to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Bill 1986, which is urgently needed to preserve the cultural heritage of Australia. One may ask whether it is important to preserve the cultural heritage of Australia. I think in its own right it is important, but also it is important because, as I think Senator Puplick hinted, Australians have shown an increasing interest in their national past. It has now become something which is important to a lot of people. I think that the extraordinary success of the Golden Summers exhibition in Sydney and the enormous numbers of people who went to that give an indication of just how much this is becoming, one might say, fashionable. Maybe it goes further than that. Possibly there is now some groping for a sense of national identity. For instance, our film making has started to show that. Of course, that is a process to be encouraged. This Bill then becomes very necessary and very important if we view it in that context.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats would like to see the Bill passed as soon as possible. In this regard, I note with concern that the Bill was debated in the other place last November, some six months ago. For one reason or another, it has only recently been introduced into the Senate. This delay has been a cause of great uneasiness because, as I understand from the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment and from people interested, there has been a considerable movement of valuable items overseas by people anxious to get rid of them before the Bill could apply. I can understand that. However, I think it is an argument that if we want the Bill actually to fulfil what it is attempting to do, it should pass now, be proclaimed and come into application. While the disposal effect could easily be exaggerated, it is a fact that when legislation of this kind is mooted it provides a signal for people who want to take certain steps in regard to their possessions before it becomes law. That is a reason, and a very good reason, for the quick passage of this sort of legislation through both Houses of this Parliament.

The fact that this Bill has taken so long did incline me, I might say, to look with a jaundiced eye at one of the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills in regard to this matter. It felt that any extension of the scope of what should be included should be a matter for legislation rather than regulation. I suggest that there are two arguments against that. One argument is that we may want actually to extend that scope quite quickly. The second argument is that it has taken so long to get this Bill through. If we are going to have this sort of legislation regularly taking so long, then I think it is desirable that it should be a matter of regulation, which, after all, does have its remedies in either House of Parliament, if anyone wants to have an argument with it, by the simple method of disallowance.

The Australian Democrats believe that the Bill has been badly needed for a long time. As Senator Robertson said, our Aboriginal heritage is, of course, vast but nevertheless highly idiosyncratic in that a great deal of it is individualistic and cannot easily be replaced. Fortunately, many movable items of that heritage remain here today. Even during the relatively short period since European settlement of this country we have developed a unique heritage, which must be preserved. This heritage includes not only those things which first spring to mind, such as the paintings and other art works of the past, but also such things as shipwrecks and their contents and the early films-which the National Film and Sound Archive is doing such a good job of collecting and preserving-which are very important to this country. I refer also to military honours awarded to Australians, the gold brooches depicting mining tools which are unique to our gold rush era and many other disparate and unique items which must not be allowed to disappear from Australia forever, as so much has disappeared from so many other countries in the past. I hope that it is possible for us to learn from that.

This Bill should provide a reasonable balance between personal and national interests. I think that, on the whole, it does that-with a few minor exceptions which we will deal with in amendments. One only needs to walk through the British Museum or the Victoria and Albert Museum to wonder at the extraordinary ability of the British, during the colonial, imperialistic era, to acquire, often by highly doubtful methods, other people's property. I agree with Senator Puplick, who said that most of that ought to be back where it came from. Of course, there will always be the classic example of Lord Elgin's acquisition of essential parts of the Parthenon, with the so-called Elgin Marbles in the British Museum.
