It would be highly desirable if the Greeks and, indeed, anybody else could see the Parthenon in one piece where it should be, on the Acropolis in Athens. I heard recently that an original Batman deed was offered for sale overseas not long ago but that this sale did not take place when the owner was apprised of the terms of the Bill. Obviously, we came very close to losing that irreplaceable piece of our heritage. The sooner this Bill is passed, the sooner we will have a rock solid means of protection for those items.

Our Aboriginal heritage is vast and quite unique. It is deplorable that the vast majority of Australians know little or nothing about this heritage. That can lead to unwitting destruction of or damage to invaluable items of Aboriginal heritage. The richest treasure-chest of Aboriginal lore, the Strehlow collection, as Senator Puplick said, was reportedly moved out of the country in May 1984 when it was feared that new Federal legislation prompting from land rights activists could lead to confiscation of the collection. That collection, which is widely believed to be Australia's largest and most valuable, contains objects of ceremonial and sacred significance, recordings of secret songs, films of ceremonies now extinct, paintings by notable artists such as Elizabeth Durack and Albert Namatjira and books and manuscripts of Aranda language, hymns, myths and marriage laws. These were accumulated by Professor Ted Strehlow during his work in Central Australia between 1932 and 1977. That collection is of fundamental importance to all Australians, black or white. The collection, which apparently has been returned to Australia, is now in Darwin pending a decision on its future. These priceless collections and artefacts which are an integral part of Australian history must be kept in this country at all costs and we must support legislation that would achieve that end.

We have circulated amendments which differ significantly from those originating from the Scrutiny of Bills Committee which were circulated by us last week. These now have the virtue perhaps of being more straightforward. They directly address two major points. Firstly, they address the power of the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment to delegate and the issue of ministerial discretion to return any confiscated objects to their proper owner or custodian. I take on board the point that Senator Puplick made. We put the word `custodian' into the amendment with that in mind, because we were aware of the difficulties which the Department was having with this.

Sub-clause 24 (1) provides that the Minister can delegate to a person any of the Minister's powers under the Act, other than the power of delegation. Of course, that is something which is contained in a good deal of previous legislation. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee noted that the powers capable of delegation included the appointment of the National Cultural Heritage Committee-in clauses 17 and 18-the power to make arrangements with State Ministers in relation to the exercise of powers under the Act by officers of the State, and the power to give directions as to the disposal of forfeited objects. The Committee suggested that if these powers were to be delegated at all, they should be delegated only to the senior officers of the Minister's Department. We would agree with that. The amendment proposed by us would not go quite as far as the Scrutiny of Bills Committee suggests but it does reserve to the Minister, obviously and plainly and necessarily the power to delegate, and also responsibility for the appointment of the National Cultural Heritage Committee. Delegation of the remaining powers would only be to the Secretary to the Department or Senior Executive Service officers.

I would hope and expect that the Government and the Opposition will support that amendment, which I believe reasonably limits bureaucratic power because it places the obligation for decision making on specific and senior members of the Minister's Department. The Australian Democrats would like to see that provision extended to other Acts which in fact do not have it now.

I suggest that our second amendment ought to be philosophically acceptable to the Government and the Opposition because it protects the rights of the owner or legal custodian of an object in the event of its theft, disposal or illegal sale. The departmental officers have had a good deal to say to us in this area and we have listened carefully to them. As a result, this amendment has been altered quite substantially, so I believe that it must now allay their concerns. Basically, it obliges the Minister to return a forfeited object to its owner or custodian, except in two cases. One is where the owner is overseas and the matter is plainly outside Australian jurisdiction. We believe that a ministerial direction can properly apply there. The second is where the owner has been convicted of making an unlawful export under this Bill. That seems to us to be reasonable. If the object has been taken away and sold overseas with the connivance of the owner-and I believe that that has happened in the past and it is thought it might happen in the future-I think the Minister should have a discretion as to whether or not he gives that object back. Granted those two things, I would have thought that it was very important for anybody who has any respect for private property to ensure that some rabid left wing Minister at some stage who believes that everything should be owned by the states does not in fact use the powers of the Bill to say: `All right, here is an object which belongs to somebody'-perhaps to Senator Grimes, for instance-`We will not give it back to him because it is in the hands of the state'. That is what we are trying to avoid and overcome with this amendment. I suggest that that is something that many other people in the country also want to have achieved. The point about the first of these exceptions is that it is reasonable that the Minister should have a discretion where an offence may well have taken place but where it is not possible to obtain a conviction.

I have outlined these amendments briefly at this stage because of the relatively late hour at which we have circulated them. I am anxious that they be given due consideration, especially by the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes), who is in the Senate at the moment and who I think may well be interested in them. Honourable senators will be able to give them some thought before the Bill reaches the Committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief in my remarks. I want to make one or two brief points in relation to the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Bill 1986, which Bill has been dealt with in the House of Representatives. I think it is worth while saying at this stage that it is fairly heartening to see that the Bill has the support of most members of the Senate. I suppose, for that matter, it even has the support of the Australian Democrats notwithstanding the minor amendments which they propose to move. I think every member of this place and the other place agrees that it is time that this sort of legislation was brought before the Parliament. The following clear statement is made under the heading `outline' in the explanatory notes:

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Bill is to provide for the protection of Australia's heritage of important movable cultural objects by introducing export controls and to extend protection to the cultural heritage of other countries through import controls.

I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that the 1970 United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation Convention on the Means of Prohibiting and Preventing the Illicit Import, Export and Transfer of Ownership of Cultural Property was signed by 54 countries. I believe that Australia is now taking up that UNESCO Convention. The stage is certainly being set for future protection by Australia of its own heritage as well as the protection of world heritage and particularly the heritage of the 54 countries that have signed the Convention. The following point is made in the explanatory notes:
Under the Bill the export of Australian protected objects is prohibited unless an appropriate permit or certificate has been issued by the Minister.
The explanatory memorandum continues:
A national control list of protected cultural property will identify categories of objects prohibited from export or requiring export authorization.

I think that is an important point in relation to the Bill. It is important that a national control list be established and be made available so that people can clearly understand and know what objects are listed. It is also important that the Minister, through the Bill, be able to give the right sort of protection to those objects should objections be made. The explanatory memorandum continues:

On receiving an application for a permit or certificate the Minister will refer to a committee which in turn will submit the application for expert examination by appropriately qualified people. On receipt of expert advice the committee will submit a report to the Minister with recommendations concerning the granting of a permit or certificate.

The Bill gives further protection by ensuring that the right advice is given to the Minister in relation to any certificate that may be issued to allow the export of any material that might be considered to be valuable. That protection for the Minister and the decisions that he takes is built into the Bill. The Bill also contains a protection for the community and people who might hold goods of some value that we might consider to be art or heritage. It is also worthwhile noting that the explanatory memorandum states:
A Fund is established under the Bill to facilitate acquisition of objects prohibited from export under the legislation.

I think the establishment of such a fund is a very reasonable and worthwhile provision in the Bill. If a decision is made to prohibit goods from export, there will be some reasonable chance that the people who own those goods will receive some return rather than being left in a situation where their goods are confiscated or they have no opportunity to dispose of or sell their goods and gain some financial return for them.

When we talk about our heritage and history I think we need not only to look at the white settlement that has taken place but also to look in some depth at the Aboriginal community. We need to consider what is happening in that area. If we are talking about protection of heritage we ought to go a little further and consider doing some of the things that have not been happening in relation to Aboriginals. The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen), in his second reading speech on this Bill, said:

The definition of cultural material given in the Convention is broad, embracing archaeology, pre-history, history, literature, art and science and includes a range of material which I mentioned a moment ago. Although its primary focus is on illegal international traffic, the Convention proposes other forms of protection, including a national inventory--

I believe that is important. The Bill provides for the establishment of a national control list. In addition to mentioning the national inventory of protected cultural property, I also want to refer to the need to support collecting institutions. I think it is fairly important when we talk about collecting institutions that we do not just confine our remarks to museums and those collecting institutions that are already established throughout Australia. I think it is important to draw attention to some of the action that has been taken by the Aboriginal communities to set up collecting institutions in the near future. I was lucky enough to visit an exhibition at the Queensland University which was set up by members of the Kombumerri Aboriginal Corporation for Culture. That exhibition displayed art, artefacts, weapons and everything else that the tribe could find that belonged to its ancestors. It included a very sound and professional display of photographs showing the history and ancestry of the Kombumerri Aboriginal tribe. That collection included photographs of tribal kings. All of these things were exhibited at the Queensland University as recently as 3 April 1986.

It is also worth while noting that the exhibition contained a model of a museum that is to be constructed by the Kombumerri Aboriginal Corporation for Culture at Burleigh on the Gold Coast. That museum is to be constructed of reinforced concrete which will be coloured to match the colours of the earth. It is to be a living museum in which Aboriginal people will talk to school children who may care to visit the museum. They will talk about the culture of Aboriginals. They would gather together all the heritage items that they could that originally belonged to the tribe so that members of the tribe who, at this stage, had not even seen and did not know anything about their heritage, could again draw some pride from the fact that they belonged to the Aboriginal group that gathered around Burleigh Heads in the very early days of Australia. It is interesting to note that the building will be constructed of reinforced concrete. It will cover 3,700 square metres. The museum will be built on a sacred bora ground. The bora ground, which still exists and is exhibited on the Gold Coast at Burleigh Heads, will be granted to the Aboriginal tribe by the Gold Coast City Council. So there has been a real move to do something for the Aboriginal people in that area.

We are looking towards the Bicentenary and towards celebrating the history of this country. This legislation will take particular note of collecting institutions. This exhibition showed very clearly that members of the Aboriginal group are trying to do something for themselves. I believe that it would be very sound and that it would be a forward step for the Government to look at the exhibition to see whether or not its construction could be funded from the Bicentennial fund. The Government claims in this legislation that it will support collecting institutions. I believe that any support from the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) and the Government towards the development of the museum on the Gold Coast by the Kombumerri Cultural Centre would be a step in the right direction and would certainly be an action that would be supportive of the legislation before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have much pleasure in supporting this legislation. At present we do have legislation covering the export of some historical items. That has not been in place terribly long. It has been welcomed, but one of the problems with it is that it acts as a brake on the honest, but it does not act as a brake on the dishonest and people can evade the requirements of the current legislation and export illegally. I fear that one of the defects of the current legislation regrettably is that nothing will be done to stop this loophole in the existing legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: In general the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Bill extends the coverage from the rather restricted groups of objects that are covered by existing legislation to much wider parameters. It defines the export procedures, it prohibits imports of objects covered by similar legislation or parallel legislation in other countries, it creates a national cultural heritage committee and a register of expert examiners and, importantly, it creates a national cultural heritage fund. In assessing this legislation a philosophic element comes into it. Obviously the drafters of this legislation had in mind the achievements and the experience of Australia and the belief that the achievements and experiences of the inhabitants of this country are worth retaining for the enrichment of the present and future generations. That is something that all of us in this Parliament support. Australia has a national culture and that is not as widely recognised as it might be. We are the inheritors of the traditions and practices of our forebears and the people who lived here in ages before us and we are the trustees for the future at the same time. We have made many great achievements. We have developed this country, but we have got an equally large task ahead of us both in a social and a physical sense. I think it is appropriate that this legislation is being brought in so that we will be able to draw on the experiences and the achievements of the past and gain some guidance for the future.

Most of the speakers in this debate so far have tended to talk about the common or the better known parts of culture and have tended to view the cultural heritage of Australia almost exclusively in terms of art and literature and, to a lesser degree, poetry and music. Undeniably that is very important. I have derived a lot of pleasure in my life out of art galleries and classical music. I hope that when I leave this Parliament I will be able to spend more time going back to reading things other than the great welter of paper that comes over my desk each day. I take the view that the cultural heritage of the country is very much wider and embraces what we have done since human habitation has occurred in Australia. That includes the way we lived in the past, the ordinary households, the community and social practices, the organisations that existed, education, the way we were governed, business practices and particularly the technological achievements of the community. Australia has been slow to recognise the importance of these tangible records of the past. We have certainly lost a great deal of these records overseas. There are many examples of this. Just randomly, there are the Batman documents that were spoken about recently, a rare Western Australian blue stamp, the Strehlow collection of Aboriginal artefacts that I think was mentioned by Senator Mason, and the whole range of Aboriginal artefacts that has gone over the years since European settlement has taken place in this country has been enormous.

I support this Bill because it will tend to restrain further loss of these artefacts from Australia. I am a little bit ambivalent about it because I recognise that some of the things that we want in this country will have to be bought overseas and if other countries have the same sort of legislation it will act against our interests but clearly, on balance, we should support the Bill rather than oppose it.

I said at the start that one of the problems with existing legislation is the fact that dishonest people can evade what we have in place. I have two broad criticisms of this Bill. I frankly do not know how to overcome them. The first is that there is no way to enforce an adequate curatorial practice on someone who owns something of national significance. I think most collectors of artefacts-whether they are stamps, Aboriginal relics or old machinery-are motivated by the best of ambitions. They are preserving things that may have been lost if they had not taken the effort to preserve them. Most of them certainly do not do it for financial gain or any other such reason, they do it just for preservation. But one has to recognise that collectors do have a strain of eccentricity amongst their numbers at times. I have met some pretty odd collectors of some odd things. The point is that if a person owns something of national significance there is no way to compel him to look after that property. In an extreme case if they have a piece of rare furniture or a painting they could leave it out in the weather and we can do nothing about it under this legislation.

The other shortcoming of this legislation is that there is no prohibition or restraint on a person selling to another party when he knows that that party is going to break the law and covertly export the article of national importance. It often happens in these situations that when a person is selling something that is quite rare he does know a bit about the purchaser of the object. Oftentimes he can make a judgment of that person's intentions. It is very easy to export objects, particularly since the introduction of containerisation. Inspectors cannot see what is in a container and it is a major effort to demand that a container be opened and there would be thousands of containers leaving Australia every month. The policing of the regu- lation is very difficult.

I think the legislation goes some way to covering these defects in so far as it provides the National Cultural Heritage Fund. It means that an offer can be made to someone who is not prepared to look after something or who wants to sell the object so that he can get some money for it. The fund will provide a bit of an outlet. However, there are people who are avid collectors, both for museums and for private collections, for whom the laws of governments have no meaning whatsoever, and regrettably they will be able to operate in the future with almost as much freedom as they have in the past.

The preservation that has taken place in Australia is varied. The popular fields of art and literature are probably pretty well catered for. Literature, of course, is readily reproducible and, apart from first editions, there is no problem there. There are excellent art collections in the State galleries, particularly the New South Wales and Victorian collections, but the smaller States also have good collections. It is surprising how successful the National Gallery has been, given its newness, at putting together a worthwhile Australian collection. I think the art and literature side in Australia is pretty well catered for.

A weak field in Australia has been the field of technology and science. Most of the speakers tonight have concentrated on Aboriginal artefacts and archaeological specimens and things like that. I would like to take a few moments to look specifically at one area in the field of technology, an area that is clearly covered by the legislation and one that is of particular interest to me. I refer to the field of aviation. I take the view that Australia's achievements in aviation take second place to those of no other country. As a nation, we have formally done nothing to preserve and display those achievements that previous generations of Australians have made in this field. I do not believe that any country has produced a greater array of pioneering talent than Australia has, particularly in the first half of this century.

Aviation is relevant to our culture. It is relevant to technological innovation and development. It is very relevant to transport. With the great distances within Australia and the great distances from Australia to other countries. It is deserving of more attention than the Australian nation has given to it so far. In the designing field, at the end of the last century Lawrence Hargrave, with his box kites and gliders, was a world pioneer. There were later designers like Harry Hawker, who as a lad from Australia became Tom Sopwith's chief designer in the early days of aviation in Britain and later formed the Hawker Aircraft Company, which became Hawker Siddeley Aviation Ltd. He was a world figure. Edgar Percival was another designer from Australia who spent most of his life in England. I think Edgar Percival, as a very old man, is still alive.

In the pioneering airmen field we had people such as Ross and Keith Smith, who made the first flight between England and Australia; R. J. P. Parer-Senator Parer's uncle-and J. C. McIntosh, who involved themselves in a very long saga in 1920, flying out from England to Australia; Kingsford-Smith and Charles Ulm, who made the first crossing of the Pacific, which pioneered an air route, and the later reverse crossing from Brisbane to Oakland, California, with Bill Taylor in the Lockheed Altair in 1934; Bert Hinkler with his record-breaking solo flights; Ron Adair, Norman Brearley, Horrie Miller and Hudson Fysh. We have a collection of pioneers that no other country can match. America might have its Lindberghs but we have a whole bunch of people who proved themselves as pioneers, which, as I say, no other country can match. Even in the current generation we have Dick Smith, who a couple of years ago made the first solo helicopter flight around the world.

The achievements of those pioneering airmen opened up the great air routes. They showed that it was feasible to run airlines services around the world. We played a major part in the development of airlines. Norman Brearley formed Airlines of Western Australia in 1920. Kingsford-Smith and Ulm formed the first Australian National Airways Pty Ltd, and the Holyman Brothers formed the second ANA after the first ANA went broke. There was Horrie Miller and, of course, probably the greatest of all, Hudson Fysh, who started Qantas in 1921. Guinea Airways was a small company started in Australia that operated in New Guinea and was the biggest freight airline in the world up to the time of the Japanese invasion of New Guinea in the 1940s.

With respect to the building of aircraft we also have a proud history. I find it amazing to stand in the hangar at Longreach-the same shed that Qantas built in the 1920s-and reflect that the legendary Arthur Baird, the chief engineer, just set to work and built a fleet of DH50As for Qantas. He did not assemble the parts from England, he built the aircraft there. After he had built those he built the DH50Js, which were a bigger aircraft, and he just did it by eyeballing it with his innate skill out there in remote Longreach. Throughout the war thousands of aircraft were constructed in Australia. This was in a country that had never before made its own car or even a refrigerator. We built about a thousand Tiger Moths. We had Dragons, Wirraways, Boomerangs, Beauforts, Mosquitoes and Mustangs. After the war, of course, we had the Sabre and the Mirage.

Australia, with all these achievements, has never felt motivated to recognise what we have done in this field. I believe it is now time that we did something to honour those people who have gone before in the field of aviation. For some reason we had a very good collection of aircraft in this country in the 1960s. Aircraft tended to survive in Australia a lot longer than they did in other parts of the world, but because we had no national museum to preserve those aircraft, we lost a very large number of them overseas. There was no legislative restraint on their sale at the time.

It is very difficult to preserve old aircraft. They need space. That space is usually at airfields, and because of the policy of high rentals for hangars which has always existed, once aircraft are not used it is not really possible to keep them in a hangar under shelter. I know this is so as I presently own two old aircraft, one of which I have owned for nearly 20 years. Hangarage is an acute and an expensive problem. In the absence of a national museum for aircraft we have had aircraft either turned outside to rot in the weather and be burnt by the fire crews in the end or sold overseas.

Since I have been a member of this Senate I have written to every Minister responsible for museums, both Liberal and Labor, putting the case for a national museum. I must say that I have got absolutely nowhere. A report on museums was commissioned by the Whitlam Government-Museums in Australia 1975. Recommendation 2.12 states:
We recommend that early priority be given to a national maritime museum in Sydney and to a national aviation museum at a growth centre.

That was eleven years ago and since that time nothing has been done. The proposition I have put to successive Ministers is not that we go out and spend a few hundred million dollars building a museum but that we have a fund of a few hundred thousand dollars so that when aircraft become available we can buy them for the Commonwealth. We have no shortage of storage space-the Commonwealth does have plenty of storage space-and so long as we acquire the aircraft, we have a nucleus for a museum later on. As I say, I have got nowhere, and in the eight years I have been here we have seen the loss of some very valuable aviation assets. Sid Marshall, who was the chief engineer for Guinea Airways before the war, had one of the great private collections of the world. When Sid Marshall died the collection was broken up and some of those significant aircraft went overseas.

We have seen the loss of one of the original aircraft from Point Cook, the Maurice Farman. That was sold out of Australia within the last ten years to Frank Tallman, at Tallmantz Aviation at Orange County Airport. He did a lot of the film work for Hollywood. The aircraft was subsequently resold at a very much higher price to the Canadian national aircraft collection. That aircraft was one of the original aircraft from Point Cook. It had a great place in Australia's aviation history. It has now gone to the Canadian national collection and we can never buy it back.

The point about aircraft is that those old ones are not being made any more. They are progressively being moved into museums around the world. Once they go into a museum they are not available for purchase. In the light of this legislation the Government is under a greater obligation to abide by the recommendations of the report of the Museum of Australia in 1975 with respect to an aviation museum.

I have taken a path that is different from that taken by other speakers tonight because, as I said earlier, although art galleries, music and literature give me a great deal of pleasure, I do believe-and I will argue this in any company-that the technological achievements of a society are as much a part of its culture as its painters. This part of the Australian culture is one that has been gravely neglected. We now have some really wonderful cultural centres in Australia-the new centre in Brisbane and the centre in Melbourne, to name but two. It is a matter of great regret to me that we do not have a science and technology centre such as the Toronto science museum, which has been in existence, probably, for at least 15 years. People can go and see the application of science and technology in all its forms in their daily lives.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Powerhouse Museum in Sydney is going up.

—I hope that the Powerhouse Museum will fulfil that function. We do live in a technological age. We are part of it, and it is as much part of our culture as our art and music. I have much pleasure in supporting this Bill. I hope that we will have an aviation museum in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Bill, as has been outlined, is to provide for the protection of Australia's heritage of important movable cultural objects by introducing export controls and to extend protection to the cultural heritage of other countries through import controls. As honourable senators would be aware, there is a large degree of unanimity on the object of this Bill. My only concern about it relates to some of the methods being adopted to achieve this laudable object.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has had a lengthy look at some parts of the legislation and it is concerned about their consequences. I am glad, however, that the Government has responded to at least one of those concerns and will be introducing an amendment at the Committee stage relating to the question of delegation of powers, which we believed was originally intended to be delegated in a manner which was inappropriate. I thank the Government for responding, although it surprised me that the legislation had proceeded as far as it did along those lines with that inappropriate delegation. I am not being churlish about that. I congratulate the Government on recognising that that provision was inappropriate, particularly as the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) had responded to the Committee, saying that it was true that there were problems with proposals on the delegation of power and that in future legislation, as a result of the Committee's concern, close attention would be given to restricting the exercise of the power of delegation-but only in the future. I am glad that the Government will move to make it apply to the present.
There are some other matters that concerned the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. One of them relates to clause 32 (1) (b) which would permit an inspector to:

(b) enter upon any land, or upon or into any premises, structure, vessel, aircraft or vehicle, on or in which the inspector believes on reasonable grounds that any thing forfeited or connected with an offence against this Act is situated,
and may seize any such thing found . . . upon the land or in the premises, structure, vessel, aircraft or vehicle, as the case may be, if-
(c) the inspector believes on reasonable grounds . . . and

(d) . . . entry is made in circumstances of such seriousness and urgency as to require and justify immediate search or entry without the authority or an order of a court or of a warrant issued under this Act.

The Committee has recognised in the past that whether such a provision for search and entry without warrant in a circumstance of seriousness and urgency is justified is a question of policy. It drew to the attention of the Senate paragraph (b) of clause 32 (1) under principle 1 (a) (i) in that such a power of entry and search without warrant might be considered to trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties. The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment responded:

As the Committee noted, it is a question of policy as to whether or not such a provision should be inserted. Breaches of the Act particularly in relation to illegal exports are likely to be discovered at short notice and in circumstances where urgent action may be required. It is therefore desirable, I believe, to have such a provision enabling speed and flexibility for deterrent action.
Nevertheless, the Committee continued to draw attention to paragraph (b)--

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you opposed to it?

—As a matter of principle, I am concerned about the exercise of such power without a warrant or a court order. I need convincing that this speed and flexibility is required in this case. I concede that it is a matter of government policy, and so be it. I just wish to draw the attention of the Senate to what seems to me to be a problem in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee's next and most serious concern related to the forfeiture of protected objects. Clauses 36, 37 and 38 deal with procedures for the forfeiture of protected objects and the disposal of objects so forfeited. I understand that in the Committee stage the Australian Democrats will move an amendment related to this matter. I simply want to draw attention to the general principle involved and to two aspects of those provisions that certainly concerned the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. The first point is that objects may be forfeited by purely administrative procedures without the intervention of a court and, secondly, the disposal of forfeited objects is left entirely to the discretion of the Minister.

The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment did provide a substantial response to the Committee. Although he gave assurances as to how powers under the Act would be exercised, his response, in the Committee's view, tended to confirm its view that in many cases the return of protected objects to their lawful owners or to the person having proper custodial care may depend on the goodwill of the inspectors and of the Minister of the day. I find that to be a totally unacceptable proposition.

The operation of the provisions may best be illustrated by way of example. The Committee has put up this example: Let us suppose that an Australian protected object is stolen from its owner, or someone with custodial care, and an attempt is made to export it from Australia. It thereby will become liable to forfeiture under clause 9 (2). The inspector who seizes the object is given a discretion by clause 36 (2) to notify the owner or the person who had the possession, custody or control of the object immediately before it was seized-in this case the thief-that the object has been seized and that it will be forfeited unless, within 30 days after the service of the notice, the person on whom the notice is served claims the object or brings an action for recovery of the object. In this case the thief will have good reason for not coming forward. The object in question may be forfeited to the Commonwealth without any requirement that a court determine that the object is in fact a protected object and without any requirement that a court determine whether in fact the person attempting to export the object was its rightful owner or had in fact proper custodial care. The owner or the custodian may indeed remain blissfully unaware of the entire proceedings. By virtue of proposed section 38, on forfeiture all title and interest in the object vests in the Commonwealth and the disposal of the object is left to the discretion of the Minister.

The Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee had a second example. Suppose that the rightful owner is, by good fortune, served with a notice under sub-clause 36 (2) and brings an action for the recovery of the object. On this occasion a court intervenes but it is merely permitted to determine whether the object is liable to forfeiture under sub-clause 9 (2)-that is, whether the object is protected and whether an attempt has been made to export it from Australia otherwise than in accordance with a permit or certificate of exemption. Where a court determines that an object is liable to forfeiture, it is required by sub-clause 37 (3) to order that the object is forfeited. Once again, title and interest in the object would vest in the Commonwealth and its return to its rightful owner would appear to depend on the Minister's goodwill.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is even if the Government gets it in bad title, which is what would happen if it were stolen.

—That appears to be the situation. You can call it `bad title'. In this case it is good title because there is a legal basis for its acquiring that title-the breaking of a law. However, the question is who broke the law. That is the problem and the consequence of someone who is not the rightful owner or the person with proper custodial care of the object being the person who broke the law or even being aware of the law having been broken.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recognises that these provisions follow those in the Customs Act 1901 and the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 dealing with the forfeiture of seized goods and live animals and plants respectively. However, the Committee remains concerned in relation to three aspects of the provisions. First, where a protected object is seized there is no requirement that the inspector notify the owner or the person with proper custodial care if the owner is not the person who had the possession, custody or control of the object immediately before it was seized. Secondly, where a protected object is seized and a notice served under sub-clause 36 (2), the owner or person who had the possession, custody or control of the object has 30 days to claim it or to bring an action for its recovery. If these steps are not taken the object is forfeited without the inspector's reasonable belief as to the fact that the object is a protected object and there has been an attempt to export it in contravention of the Act being tested in a court. Thirdly, where a court finds that an offence has been committed in relation to a protected object and that object is forfeited to the Commonwealth, its return to its lawful owner or the person having proper custodial care depends on the goodwill of the Minister even though the owner may be entirely innocent of any involvement in the attempt to export the object.

While the Minister says that it is envisaged that the Minister would return the object by virtue of exercising his discretion in relation to forfeited objects, there is no requirement that the discretion be exercised in favour of the lawful owner or the person having proper custodial care. The Minister could, for example, give the object to an appropriate cultural institution if he wanted to. As one who generally objects to having excessive discretion within the bureaucracy and the Ministry, I do not think this is an appropriate way in which to handle this matter.

There are some other matters that concern me. I shall conclude briefly by pointing out that the Committee suggested in its Alert Digest No. 16 of 1985, first, that an object should be forfeited only on the order of a court and not, as is proposed, on the basis of the belief of an inspector and the failure of the owner or the person who had the possession, custody or control of the object immediately before it was seized to take steps within a limited time to recover the object. The inspector seizing the object should be required to satisfy a court that the object is in fact a protected object and that an attempt has been made to export it, or in the case of its being a protected object of a foreign country the government of which has requested its return, it has been imported, as the case may be.

The Committee's second recommendation was that a register should be established of the owners of objects on the National Cultural Heritage Control List so that where such objects are seized in the course of an attempt to export them, the owners may be notified as a matter of course and not merely at the discretion of the inspector seizing the object as is proposed under sub-clause 36 (2). The third recommendation was that an object so seized should be returned to its owner or custodian unless that owner of proper custodian is convicted under sub-clause 9 (3) of knowingly exporting or attempting to export the object. The Committee noted that there is already the power to order forfeiture in such circumstances under sub-clause 37 (4).
In relation to the second suggestion, the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment has responded in this way:
The National Cultural Heritage Control List will not be an itemised list of objects. It will consist of a list of categories of cultural material . . .

The Committee accepted that it had misconstrued the nature of the control list. However, the fact that the list will merely set out categories of protected material served to confirm the Committee's fears that it may prove difficult to identify the lawful owners of protected objects which are liable to forfeiture. The Committee continued to draw sub-clauses 36, 37 and 38 to the attention of the Senate under principle 1 (a) (i) and pointed out that by permitting protected objects to be forfeited otherwise than by order of a court and by leaving the disposal of such objects to the discretion of the Minister rather than by requiring return to their lawful owners or persons having proper custodial care in appropriate circumstances the clauses may be considered to trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties.

Given those concerns about the manner in which this legislation is proceeding, I simply wish to restate that I join with other senators in supporting the thrust of this Bill. I simply express some concerns about the methods by which this objective is being achieved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank honourable senators for their contributions and their support for the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Bill 1986. It is very encouraging that there is such broad support for this important Bill. In closing the second reading debate I draw attention to the amendment that the Government will move to clause 24 of the Bill and indicate that the Government will not accept the amendments to be moved by the Australian Democrats. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I foreshadowed a moment ago, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 11, clause 24, lines 6 to 8, leave out all words after `writing' insert: `delegate to-
(a) the person holding or performing the duties of the office of Secretary to the Department; or
(b) a person holding or performing the duties of a Senior Executive Service office within the meaning of the Public Service Act 1922, being an office in the Department,
all or any of the Minister's powers under this Act, other than this power of delegation or a power conferred by section 17 or 18, sub-section 28 (3), (4) or (5) or section 38 or 47.'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —You may have noticed, Mr Chairman, that there is a slight difference between a very similar amendment circulated earlier by me on behalf of the Australian Democrats and the Minister's amendment which somewhat puzzles me because when one looks at the Minister's amendment one sees that it includes sub-section 28 (3), (4) and (5) and section 38 and section 47. My amendment stops at `delegation or power conferred by section 17 or 18'. Section 17 or 18 is virtually the appointment of the National Cultural Heritage Committee. I understand that that is a very important matter which the Minister should deal with, but if one extends that one finds that the Government's amendment also includes the power to make arrangements with State Ministers in relation to the exercise of power under this Act by officers of the State. I would have thought that that was perfectly reasonable for the head of a department to undertake, and I cannot for the life of me see why it is necessary for that power to have to come back to the Minister on all occasions. Perhaps the Minister can guide me on this but I can see situations arising where a State officer looks at quite a small matter in Queensland, Tasmania or Western Australia. That matter will then have to be dealt with, not by a senior officer of the Department such as the Secretary but by the Minister himself unless I have misunderstood this completely.

SPEECH.PARA: The same thing applies to the next bit, which is:
The power to give directions as to the disposal of forfeited objects.

I should like the Minister to note just what that means. It is a power to give directions as to the disposal of forfeited objects in any substantial sense, that is to exercise a discretion over whether they are disposed of against the wishes of the owner. I understand that not to be the case. I understand that there used to be objects which clearly, under the Bill, would be forfeited. I would have thought that if there is a small painting or picture which is forfeited, or if there are a large number, perhaps a collection of 40 or 50 objects, that is not a thing which would necessarily have to engage the attention of the Minister. I cannot quite see what the reason is. Possibly I do not understand it clearly, but I would like the Minister to give me a little information on those two points, please.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will support the amendment put forward by the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan). We believe that it is a sensible amendment in that it limits the power of delegation in line with some of the principles laid down by the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills report. We are not concerned to the same extent as Senator Mason is over sub-clauses 28 (3), (4) and (5). We believe that where negotiations are to take place on a Minister to Minister level, that should not be a matter delegated. As far as clause 38 is concerned, which touches on directions on the questions of forfeiture, we believe that it is appropriate for that not to be a delegated power. Clause 47 touches on the matter of annual reports and financial statements. Again, we do not believe that this is power which ought to be delegated. So we are perfectly happy to support the Government's amendment to clause 24. While I am on my feet, perhaps I may say to the Minister that at some stage I would be grateful for a response to the question I raised in the second reading debate about the reverse implication of the legislation in terms of people seeking to prevent the Minister from granting a certificate in the circumstances in which he is minded to grant one.

—I table the explanatory memorandum relating to the amendment moved on behalf of the Government to the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Bill. I thank Senator Puplick for his comments. I think they explain the position that the Government is in in respect to the Australian Democrats' amendment, in that there are a number of matters which have been enumerated by Senator Puplick which we judge to be properly a matter of ministerial decision and not a matter for delegation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the point. It is a fine point. Senator Puplick was perhaps right, in that as it was in negotiation with a State Minister it should be carried out by a Minister. Even there, though, I would have thought that if it were a routine matter, and in this case it would not be a negotiation with the Minister but with his Department, the head of a Commonwealth Department would at least be able to carry out that function. However, it is not a matter of vital importance. The Government is perhaps giving more ground on this than it needs to. I suppose that is a good thing one way or another. Senator Puplick may not have realised that yet, but indeed it is.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter is much more important and requires a little more explanation than the Minister has given me. As regards `The power to give direction as to the disposal of forfeited objects', as Senator Puplick said, this touches on the matter of forfeiture. But it does not, to my mind, surely, touch on the matter of forfeiture where there is any discretion as to whether an object is to be forfeited. Surely, it touches purely on how an object can be disposed of once it has been forfeited. It seems to me very strange that that is going to have to come back to the Minister on every occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Mason, I think you are getting on to clause 38, are you not?
—No, I am not. I am speaking to the last section of the amendment which is before the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to the query from Senator Mason-he has attempted to respond to his own query by his own amendment-the Government believes that the disposal of the forfeited object by the Minister is the most appropriate course of action. If one looks at the Australian Democrats' amendment, one will see that it creates more problems than it would cure. The Democrats' amendment would allow the return of an object to an owner who is under investigation, or one who, if the owner's conviction had been on the basis of probabilities, would have been convicted. The reference to `custodian' in the Democrats' amendment is unacceptable. The Bill refers to a person who is an owner or is in possession, custody or control. This reflects the reality of persons who have an interest in an object. This Bill is concerned with export controls, not with the domestic arrangements relating to the location or title of the important objects. Much cultural material owned by one person may be legally in the possession, custody or control of another-museums, dealers, agents, exhibiters and so on are examples. Frequently, ownership of important cultural material is deliberately concealed, for good reason or for bad. The Government's provision allows flexibility for the disposal of the property. Issues of equity relating to the interests of the owner are catered for in the procedures specified in the Bill prior to forfeiture occurring-that is, during the court proceedings prior to forfeiture being ordered.

SPEECH.PARA: I also bring to the attention of the Committee sub-clause 35 (2). It is unusual in Commonwealth legislation relating to seizure in that it provides the Minister with the power to return the object to the owner after seizure but at any time before forfeiture to the Commonwealth occurs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I really was referring to the last part of the Minister's first amendment. When she looks at the Hansard she will see that that is the case. It is not a matter on which I want to detain the Committee. I think the Minister has been addressing herself now to our second amendment. Is that so?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —(Minister for Education) (10.26)-Yes-which we are also rejecting.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 19, clause 38, lines 1 to 11, leave out the clause, insert the following new clause:
``38. (1) Where a protected object is forfeited by or under this Act-
(a) all title and interest in the object is vested in the Commonwealth without further proceedings; and
(b) subject to sub-section (2), the object shall be dealt with and disposed of in accordance with the directions of the Minister.

``(2) Where a protected object is forfeited by or under this Act, and the Minister is able to ascertain the name and address of the owner or custodian of the object, the Minister shall return the object to the owner or custodian unless-
(a) the owner or custodian is not a resident of Australia; or
(b) the owner or custodian has been convicted of an offence against sub-section 9 (3) in relation to the object.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not support the Australian Democrats' amendment. The confusion which would result from the expression `owner or custodian' being included in the Democrats' amendment would be detrimental to the effective working of the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Bill, in particular where both owner and a custodian can be identified. The owner, for example, being perhaps a traditional Aboriginal or Aboriginal community, and the custodian being a museum or institution which is currently in legitimate custodial possession of a particular object seems to us to raise a problem that where both the owner and the custodian are known and identified, and both have rights, very considerable confusion would be caused by the addition of this amendment to the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: We are conscious of the matters raised by Senator Michael Baume. We believe that the Government has attempted to address those matters. There have been certain assurances given by the Attorney-General's Department as to the way in which this would occur.

I mention finally that I believe that if this procedure were put in place, we would in fact have, in terms of our relationship with other countries, an unenforceable legal situation such as that which arose in the Ortiz case. Therefore, we would be prejudicing our international standing and relationship in this matter and adding to domestic confusion. For those reasons, we will not support the Democrats' amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Puplick. This is a little bit out of order, but in response to the previous question put by Senator Puplick--
—Why don't you make him an Assistant Minister? He is doing a terrific job.

—Because we have two minutes to go and we would really like to conclude the Bill. In answer to Senator Puplick's previous question about a review for an interested party of permission granted by the Minister, the Bill is recognised as intruding in specific circumstances on the rights of the owner. The Minister when issuing a permit does so on the application of an owner, which in turn is referred to a committee for advice and also to expert examiners in that area. Thus, the design of the Bill takes into account the right of the owner where refusal occurs. The question of the interests of the public is taken into account in the whole design of the Bill. I thank the honourable senator.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to delay the Committee, but I predict that the failure to accept this amendment will cause a great deal of trouble. I do not think it is clearly understood. To meet Senator Puplick's point, the amendment could be altered, I suppose, to say: `the owner, or in the event of the absence of an established owner, the custodian of the object'. Surely that would meet Senator Puplick's point.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the weeks of the first term in each academic year I have been in the Senate I have received letters from parents who have students at Canberra High School, some of whom for the first time discover that the school has no gymnasium and others who have an additional child going there and discover that there is still no gymnasium in place. In the chamber tonight are two honourable senators, Senator Ryan and Senator Peter Baume, who have had responsibility for Australian Capital Territory education and know the story very well. I shall not go over the whole 18 years of the history of the Canberra High School since it moved from Acton to its present site in Belconnen. I will, in a minute, seek to incorporate in Hansard a letter about the matter which the Principal of the school has written to Mr Scholes who, as Minister for Territories, is now the Minister responsible for schools in the Australian Capital Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that Canberra High School, the second high school in Canberra, was moved to Belconnen 18 years ago. A gymnasium was part of the plans then but successive governments have not put the gymnasium in place. This means that students at the school are deprived of being able to take part in a number of activities: Indoor basketball, gymnastics, dance, badminton, volleyball, indoor hockey, indoor soccer, indoor cricket, netball and aerobics. There is no adequate indoor facility to run student lunchtime activities. A number of other activities that go on in other schools cannot be done at Canberra High School. This means that the school has to hire other facilities and students have to go away from the school for a number of these activities. That is an additional cost for which the school does not receive additional funds.

Canberra High School is the only high school or secondary college in the Belconnen area that does not have a gymnasium. The new secondary college is being built with a gymnasium, but somehow the gymnasium for Canberra High School always finishes up at the bottom of the priorities for capital funding. Something else always seems to be more important. Many students have missed out on activities, including sporting activities which they should be able to enjoy and which students in other schools enjoy. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter written on 24 February to the Minister for Territories by the Principal of Canberra High School, Mr Thomas. I hope that perhaps this year the way may be seen at least to get on with the job of placing this facility at the school.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Canberra High School
Bindubi St, Macquarie, ACT 2614.

24th February 1986
Mr G. Scholes,
Minister for Capital Territory,
Parliament House,
CANBERRA, ACT 2600
Dear Mr Scholes,

I write to inform you of a situation that has been progressively deferred for the past eighteen years. In 1968 Canberra High School was relocated from its original site in Acton to a new site in Macquarie. The old building was built in 1938 and it now has both the Canberra School of Music and the Canberra School of Art on its grounds.

When the school was relocated in 1968 the plan allowed for a gymnasium. This gymnasium was not built and despite continued representation and promises of it being completed the facility has not been built.

All new high schools in Canberra are now built with a gymnasium as a standard facility. This facility is necessary in Canberra with the harshness of Canberra's cold winter and heat in summer. I believe that physical education skills are essential for all children if they are to live a healthy and satisfying life. High school should offer exposure to many skills but unfortunately children at this school are not able to experience many of the indoor activities.

In 1988 Canberra High School will celebrate its golden anniversary. Many of Canberra's top public servants have been educated at the school and the school has an enviable reputation in both academic and extra-curricula activities.

Despite constant representation to Ministers of Education, Chief Education Officers and the NCDC this school does not have an indoor facility for students to be able to experience many of the potential lifetime activities.

It has come to our attention that with the talk of budget cuts, and cuts in the building programmes, that once again the Canberra High School community will be forced into waiting ``for a more appropriate time''. It appears to me that children, parents and students in this community have waited long enough for a facility that is now recognised nationally as a standard item of equipment.

If this facility is not going to be provided what alternative is going to be provided? Will students from this school be given bus vouchers to gymnasiums in other districts? Will the Schools Office pay the cost of our hiring of gymnasiums for Volleyball, Badminton, Basketball, Gymnastics, Dance etc.? This currently costs our students who have to pay the fee when we hire another facility.
This school endeavours to educate children as well as possible. I believe we are achieving this aim under very difficult and unnecessarily poor physical conditions.
This community has waited long enough.
Yours sincerely,
